PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 October, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of 17 bills deals with a range of issues with respect to restructuring the regulatory framework of the Aus tralian meat and livestock industry. In particular, a number of the bills relate to changes in the method of levying charges or levies for purposes related to such things as marketing and research in the meat and livestock industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition supports passage of the bills. However, we have two issues we wish to raise specifically. The first relates to the Livestock Transactions Levy Bill 1997. This bill was the subject of an inquiry by the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee. The Senate committee took evidence from various representative organisations in the meat and livestock industry and the wool industry and, as a result of that evidence, the committee unanimously concluded in its report that the bill should be withdrawn until a round table conference was held.

The committee came to that recommendation because, whilst in principle there was strong support from the majority of the industry for a transaction levy to replace the current slaughter levy, there was a great divergence of views as to just what form that levy should take. Some argued, as the bill proposed, that it should be based on a per head basis. Others put to the committee that it should be an ad valorem rate. Other groups suggested the possibility of a mixture of a per head and an ad valorem levy.

There were various proposals which related to exemptions from the levy. As a result of this divergence and, in some cases, conflicting views on the actual method of applying the levy, the committee reached the unanimous position that the bill should be withdrawn and discussions held to try to sort out an agreement so the bill could be reintroduced or redrafted to reflect any such agreement. I reiterate that that was the unanimous position of members of the committee, both government and opposition.

Following the committee's report, there was strong representation from major representative organisations seeking that the Senate pass the bill as soon as possible. That seems to be the view being adopted in regard to lots of legislation at this point in time. But, given the overwhelming indication from the industry that that is what they desire, the opposition has proposed that the bill be passed but with a cessation provision such that the bill will operate for a period of two years from its commencement date.

We have done that because, as I said, we do support the in‐principle position of moving to a transaction based levy. We still retain our concern that there is some disagreement within the industry as to precisely what form that transactions levy should take. We believe that one way to ensure that it is properly introduced and is accepted by the industry over time is for the bill to be given a life of two years.

At that point of time when it expires, hopefully, things will be working okay, and the government of the day would be required to then come back to the parliament to either seek to put further legislation through to continue the system as it exists at that time or to make any necessary changes that have been demonstrated to be needed during the two years. So we have proposed an amendment to the Live‐stock Transactions Levy Bill and that has been circulated in the chamber. It is in the form of a request because, as I am advised, this is a money bill and is not capable of amendment directly by the Senate. So we have proposed that the clause `Cessation of operation of Act' be inserted into the bill, and we will be requesting that the House of Representatives agree to that. I understand that the government is agreeable to our proposal in that regard. I do not think I need to say anything more about that particular legislation. I think my colleague Senator O'Brien may wish to add some further remarks as he was also a member of the committee that dealt with that bill.

We also have concerns with the Australian Meat and Live‐stock Industry (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1997 . I acknowledge that we have only just been able to draw these concerns directly to the attention of the government this morning. I apologise for that. We were proceeding on the basis that this legislation was coming on tomorrow. Nevertheless, the government will recall the speech in the second reading debate given by the member for Burke, Mr O'Keefe, in the other place on 27 October. He stated:

I also foreshadow concern about a provision in the Australian Meat and Live‐stock Industry (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1997 which accompanies this legislation on the Australian meat and livestock industry reforms. In proposed section 45 of the repeals and consequential provisions bill, there is a section headed `Certain staff members taken to have resigned'. As I understand this particular section, it relates to people who are at the moment employees of statutory corporations such as the AMLC and who, when those bodies are phased out, will obviously be without a job.
The bill provides that those people will be offered an equivalent of employment opportunity. But it also provides that, if they choose not to take it, they are deemed to have resigned.

Mr O'Keefe then goes on to indicate that the opposition would be considering what provisions it might seek to move in regard to that section of the bill. The concern is that persons who are offered employment in one of the other bodies to replace the Meat and Livestock Corporation but who decline such employment will be taken to have resigned. In such case it is intended that they would lose, as we understand it, their rights to redundancy, which would otherwise be available if they were to be made redundant.

Our concern is that, as we are advised, this is actually contrary to an enterprise agreement between the CPSU and the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. I am advised that the agreement reached between the union and the corporation provided that choice was of paramount importance. The advice states:
Clause 4 of the AMLC Agreement incorporated the concept of employee "choice" in the event of privatisation.
Bear in mind that at the time this agreement was negotiated the future of the AMLC was still not finalised. It goes on:

Under that provision, where employees chose to transfer to a privatised part of the AMLC's existing operations they agreed to be treated as though there had been no break in continuity, ie "uninterrupted service". In voting to support the Agreement, staff agreed that in those circumstances they would be willing to forgo an entitlement to redundancy payments.
It was also the understanding of the parties that those employees who chose not to transfer to the privatised operation would retain their entitlement to redundancy payments.

That is the concern that we have. The provisions of clause 45 with consequential provisions in clause 46 would be contrary to that agreement and certainly to the employees' understanding of that agreement. Consequently, we have circulated amendments to the Australian Meat and Live‐stock Industry (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1997 . If they have not been circulated, they will be shortly. Those amendments would delete clause 45 and more consequential amendments to clause 46.

I indicated to the government just prior to commencement of the debate this morning that, given that this has only just been raised now but was foreshadowed some time ago, there may need to be some further consultation before the matter is finally resolved this morning, if that is possible. I would be interested to hear the government's view on this.

Therefore, if there is a need—and I think there certainly is—to discuss this matter further, I am proposing to proceed to deal with all the other bills in the package and adjourn these two bills to be brought on later this morning once we have resolved the issue. Alternatively, if we are unable to resolve the issue, the bills will need to be brought on to enable the opposition to put its amendments and have them determined accordingly. I indicate that the opposition supports the totality of the package of legislation with the proviso that we are proposing amendments to the Live‐stock Transactions Levy Bill 1997 and the Australian Meat and Live‐stock Industry (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1997 .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that there appears to be agreement in relation to the Live‐stock Transactions Levy Bill 1997 amendment that the opposition proposed, it may seem unusual that I rise to speak in this debate. However, we do have a situation where effectively a unanimous committee report has recommended that this bill be amended substantially prior to its passage. I thought I needed to touch on the position that members of the committee took in relation to this bill in the second reading debate, given the slight variation in position. I will seek to explain why the position now taken is entirely consistent with the committee's findings.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee hearing on this bill was called on rather hastily, given the time of year in which the proceedings commenced and the amount of time available to conduct hearings. I, firstly, would like to congratulate the various organisations who, on very short notice, appeared before the committee and presented their points of view. Subsequently, the government, through the department, presented its point of view in relation to this legislation.

What came out of those hearings was that the committee was quite confused about the overall position of the industry. Indeed, there was a significant body of evidence which indicated that, although there were many organisations supporting the proposed transaction levy arrangement, most, if not all, of the organisations—certainly the producer organisations—supported the existing scheme. However, it was felt that perhaps there was a problem in its administration because of the processors refusing to continue to collect the slaughter levy on into the future.

Given that there did exist, as it seemed to the committee, a situation where a scheme was cobbled together in a reasonably short period and did not necessarily have broad support from producers themselves, if one disregards the position taken by their representative organisations, it was suggested during the hearings that in some areas the votes taken within organisations to support the proposal were carried by very slim majorities. Given that situation, what the committee felt minded to do was seek a reconsideration of the proposal for the transaction levy which effectively transfers the responsibility for payment of the levy from the processor to the producer.

I believe over time that will effectively transfer the cost of the levy from the processor to the producer, and it will impact on the return they receive from their stock. However, that is a matter which the various representative organisations around the country, with a couple of notable exceptions, have indicated to many senators that they support. As they are the representative organisations of the growers and, as a significant majority of those organisations have, subsequent to the report, indicated to senators that they believe it is in the interest of the industry that the bill be passed, the opposition is not intending to stand in the way of that wish.

However, the concerns which the committee have expressed about the operation of the scheme remain. As a result, we propose and, as I understand it, the government accepts that, to ensure there is the ability for parliament to review this legislation within two years, a sunset clause is to be introduced by means of an opposition amendment. The intent of that is, if there are the problems which have been raised in the hearings, to allow the various industry bodies, if it is their wish, the opportunity to come back to the parliament and suggest alternatives or variations to the scheme. That can be done in a number of ways—by amending the legislation at any time by, for example, simply removing the sunset clause or making some other significant changes or in removing the sunset clause amending any regulations that arise out of the legislation which affect the operation of the levy so as to give effect to a scheme which is equitable and acceptable.

A significant concern was expressed in the hearings that, because the transaction applies at the point of sale, unless there were significant exemptions in the regulations arising out of the legislation, a transaction levy could be payable on a number of occasions because it is sold on a number of occasions prior to being sorted. That concern may well be addressed in regulations arising out of the legislation. It is a significant concern. The opposition will be looking closely at the equity of any regulations that arise out of this legislation. Having said that, on the understanding I expressed about our amendment, which I think is well-founded, the opposition will not oppose the passage of the Live‐stock Transaction Levy Bill 1997, if amended in the way that we suggest.

Senator Forshaw referred to the consequential amendments legislation. I support his suggestion that, perhaps in the committee stage, that matter be dealt with separately. If need be, the committee stage can be adjourned while other legislation is being dealt with to allow the further consideration of that matter. With those brief remarks, I commend our amendment and the other legislation to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have discussed this. I thank Senator Forshaw for his apology in relation to the late notice. We have had time to consider those matters dealing with clause 45. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) has considered the concerns. We believe that the concerns are unwarranted and that the package is fair. We have had a close look at this. The matters have been raised before; it is not as though it is a totally new issue.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not think there are any breaches of agreements. We think it is fair to all parties. It offers a person moving from one organisation to another fairness and equity in these matters. I am not sure whether the precedents upon which these transfer provisions are based are exhaustive. The precedents in this section include the Moomba‐Sydney Pipeline System Sale Act 1994. That was a Labor government bill which involved moving staff from one organisation to another. There is also the Repatriation Institutions (Transfer) Act 1992. Again, that was another Labor Party bill where people were moved from one repatriation organisation to another. There is also the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Sale of Assets and Abolition) Act 1990.

So there are three precedents. These measures are based on them. We do not believe that any delays or further discussion would move things further, because the government has a firm view on it. Even though we like to consult on these things and try to find common ground where it is possible, we do not think that it will progress things here. The government is quite keen to see this legislation dealt with as quickly as possible. We have a very heavy legislative burden, which we seek to get through before lunchtime so that we can get on to the Wik debate. I think any further delay will delay the consideration of the Native Title Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that this matter was only specifically drawn to the attention of the government this morning. However, it was, as I said, flagged in the second reading stage in the other place. You might say that that means it has been under consideration for some time. The problem we have is this: on the advice I have received—it seems that it is very good advice—the clause is contrary to the agreement reached between the union and the Meat and Livestock Corporation. That agreement is the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Enterprise Agreement 1997 and it sets out certain rights and entitlements of employees, specifically in clauses 4 and 9. That agreement was negotiated at a time when the future of the Meat and Livestock Corporation was still being sorted out.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, under the provisions of this legislation—the Australian Meat and Live‐stock Industry (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1997 —clause 45 deems that staff members who are offered employment in one of the new bodies but who decline it are deemed to have resigned. Further, what is even more draconian in terms of the impact of that position is that clause 45(5) states:
If a person is taken to have resigned under subitem 2, the resignation is not to be treated for any purpose as a termination of employment at the initiative of the person's employer.

We have a situation where employees of the Meat and Livestock Corporation are going to fall into a number of categories. Those not offered employment in one of the new bodies will be afforded all their rights as redundant employees. Those who are offered employment and accept it will continue on with no substantive change to their rights or entitlements. However, for those who are offered employment—in other words, are asked to move from the public sector to the private sector—and who decline that offer, this legislation will deem them to have resigned. Once that comes into play, they are then not entitled to take that to the Industrial Relations Commission under, for instance, the unfair dismissals provisions. So they are snookered well and truly. In effect, even though they are currently employees in the public sector pursuant to the Meat and Livestock Industry Act, if as a result of this legislation they offered employment in the private sector and they decline it, they are going to be assumed to have resigned their public sector employment.

We are advised that that is totally inconsistent with the agreement reached with the union. I will return to that. The agreement recognises in clause 4 the concept of employee choice in the event of privatisation. Under that provision, where employees chose to transfer to a privatised part of the Meat and Livestock Corporation's existing operations, they agreed to be treated as though there had been no break in continuity; that is, they continue with uninterrupted service. In voting to support the agreement, the staff agreed that in those circumstances they would be willing to forgo an entitlement to redundancy payment, because they accepted, in effect, a transfer of employment from the public sector to the private sector and a continuation or uninterruption of their service. All their entitlements follow them through. They therefore accepted no entitlement to redundancy. They were not seeking to cease one day as a public sector employee, pick up redundancy and then the next day start with the new privatised body as a new employee. They have specifically not sought that, something in my many years of experience in the union movement I saw happen quite often in the private sector—by way of agreement. But that is not to apply here.

If employees who are offered employment or who are asked to transfer from the public sector to a new privatised body in the private sector exercise their right to choose not to take up that transfer of employment, they are deemed to have resigned from the public sector and they lose the entitlements that all of their fellow employees will receive who were not offered employment; yet they are in no different position because their employment in the public sector is being terminated. There is no job for them. They should not be, in effect, put in a position with one arm twisted behind their back and told, `Your public sector employment is going to cease because the Meat and Livestock Corporation is going to cease. It will be replaced by private sector bodies. You either take the job within the private sector or you lose all the entitlements that you have accrued, which may be many years of service in the public sector.' That is totally unfair and inequitable and, as I said, contrary to the understanding and the words of the agreement reached between the union and the corporation.

It has been made very clear to me that at the time that agreement was negotiated there would be a corresponding entitlement. Those employees who chose not to transfer to the privatised operation would retain their entitlement to redundancy payments. In that context, we have a clear difference in position between the government and the opposition. We are saying and the union is saying that the provisions of proposed clause 45 are completely at odds with the understanding in that agreement. The fact that very few, if any, employees are ultimately to be affected is not the point. The point is whether or not this legislation is consistent or inconsistent with an enterprise agreement.

This is a government that says it wants enterprise agreements both in the private sector and in the public sector. This is a government that is proceeding down the path of deregulation of these bodies. We have indicated our support for the rest of the package of legislation. We have indicated our support for the industry to have a greater role and say in that regulation. Why should the current employees who have had the entitlements of public sector employment be denied those rights simply because they decline to be forced into a position of taking employment in a private sector body that will replace the Meat and Livestock Corporation?
I urge the government again to think about this issue and to support our amendments. I move:
Schedule 5, item 46, page 40 (line 21), omit paragraph (1)(b).
Schedule 5, item 46, page 40 (line 28), omit paragraph (2)(b).

Alternatively, as I said, I have offered the opportunity to adjourn debate on this bill to see whether we can sort this out. We can bring it back within the time that is prescribed for the rest of this legislation this morning and finish it off. It is not going to delay the government's program at all. It is a fairly straightforward issue: either we are right or you are right, and we believe we are right. As I said, it will not delay the program at all. I urge the government to either accept our amendments or alternatively at this stage take up our proposal to have further consideration of the matter this morning. I can guarantee you that we can still deal with the matter within the time frame that is envisaged to deal with the rest of this legislation. I am once again making the offer to the government to adjourn and discuss the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our position hasn't changed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be pretty unfortunate if this debate were extended longer than it needed to be, because otherwise it appears that this legislation is basically uncontroversial. I am interested to know what position the government and the department take in relation to this matter, given that I understand the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation were not made aware of the content of this legislation; they were not aware of the intent of the government to override the agreement in this regard. I say that because I have been given a copy of correspondence dated 14 November from the AMLC to the Community and Public Sector Union. They say:

SPEECH.PARA: It is simply not true that the AMLC has attempted to override through legislation employees' rights to choose whether or not to transfer to a private successor body. As you know, the legislation was drafted by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. We were given limited opportunities to make comment. In fact AMLC and MRC made unsolicited representations to the department to have the draft legislation changed. These requests were ignored. We obtained a copy of the tabled legislation from the Internet, probably like you did. If you are in any doubt over our role in the drafting of the legislation, I suggest you contact—
a name is mentioned—
DPIE, who has been one of the main architects of the legislation.

The AMLC position, at least as they expressed it to the union, is that they did not seek the provisions in the legislation which would override the agreement that they apparently freely made with the Community and Public Sector Union. It is, of course, a serious principle to override the terms of a freely reached agreement by legislation and there ought to be expressed by the government in this debate good public interest reasons for doing so. We have not in this debate heard anything from the government as to why the agreement should be overridden. Perhaps their view is that it is not being overridden. But that is the difficulty we are in. As I said at the start, it would be unfortunate if we were to unnecessarily prolong this debate, with Senator Forshaw's suggestion of moving, for example, that this committee report progress while we do that. We should proceed with another bill and come back later this morning at least knowing where everyone stands on this.

As I say, it may appear a small issue to the government. It is certainly a significant issue to those people affected by it. It would be a matter which no doubt will take the time of other bodies if this legislation passes in the current form. I think the potential for injustice is great and contrasts the opportunity to rectify issues easily at hand. I strongly suggest that we ensure we do not create an injustice for want of taking a very simply taken opportunity to review the provision, given the material that is before the Senate at the moment.

It may be that the government knows full well what it is doing in this regard. It would not be a very honourable position for the government to take if that were its position. As I said, there ought to be very strong public interest reasons expressed in the debate as to why a freely reached agreement ought to be overridden by this parliament in the way that Senator Forshaw suggests it is being overridden. We can easily deal with that by passing 15 of the 16 bills in this debate and coming back to resolve the 16th later this morning.
Progress reported.

BREAK.XREF: MIGRATION AGENTS REGISTRATION APPLICATION CHARGE BILL 1997
MIGRATION AGENTS REGISTRATION RENEWAL CHARGE BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 November, on motion by Senator Herron:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997 and two associated bills. This bill seeks to implement the will of the government to create a migration agents registration authority and to effectively and dramatically change the immigration assistance industry. The industry is currently regulated but this was not always the case. There were some protective measures in place prior to 1992 but these offered little protection to consumers.

SPEECH.PARA: The migration agents registration scheme, MARS, was established in 1992 under the stewardship of the then Minister for Immigration and Local Government, Gerry Hand. MARS was a response by the then Labor government to complaints about unscrupulous conduct and to reports of poor, negligent and incompetent advice being given by people holding themselves up to be experts in migration. Allegations about consumers being exploited and often asked or forced to pay enormous fees for services abounded. Recipients of migration advice were recognised by the then government as a particularly vulnerable group. Many of the group did not speak or understand English and were unaware of avenues of complaint when poor or unethical service was rendered to them.

The main features of the MAR scheme included registration for would‐be providers of immigration advice, a code of conduct for registered agents, procedures for investigating complaints against agents, processes for suspending and deregistering agents and criminal sanctions for unregistered practice. The scheme was originally established to operate for three years with a government commitment to evaluate its effectiveness after two years. It has since had a number of temporary extensions.

The scheme is administered by a board and the Secretary to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Each have distinct roles. The scheme has been reviewed twice in its short life. In 1995, in accordance with the minister's commitment at the commencement of the scheme, the Joint Standing Committee on Migration produced the results of its year‐long inquiry in a report entitled Protecting the vulnerable? The migration agents registration scheme. The current Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, was a member of the committee that produced a unanimous report containing 49 recommendations. The recommendations were aimed at improving the standard of conduct and quality of advice given in the migration advice industry and ensuring greater consumer protection for clients of agents.

The first recommendation in the Protecting the vulnerable? report was that the scheme continue for a further three years and then be further reviewed. This recommendation was accepted by the then minister, Senator Bolkus, in the government's response to the committee's report, which was tabled in the House of Representatives on 30 November 1995. It appears that the current minister and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs were not informed of or were unaware of this important event. Mr Ruddock said in the other place on 30 October 1997:

The further comment that was made, and I think it was picked up by other members who spoke, was the reference to the Joint Standing Committee on Migration report entitled Protecting the vulnerable? I was a party to that committee report, and I know what happened in relation to the deliberations on it. I know that the report was not one that had been responded to by the former government—notwithstanding that it was a committee report that they had had in their hands for some 12 months before the last election.

In fact, Minister Bolkus had responded and had done so within six months of the presentation of the report. In its response to a question on notice from the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, the department told the committee about the presentation of the report to the Senate President on 1 December 1995 but failed to record that the report had earlier been presented to the House of Representatives.

Minister Ruddock either ignored or forgot the report when he established a further review of the scheme in June last year. The review was conducted by a departmental task force which was guided by a six‐member reference group headed by Mr Ian Spicer, former Chief Executive Officer of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. The reference group also included two officers of the Migration Institute of Australia.

It is interesting to record the minister's boast made in his second reading speech that MARS was the first regulatory arrangement to be reviewed by the Commonwealth as a party to the competition principles agreement. That is what this legislation is about—deregulation and self‐regulation. It is not about strengthening consumer protection for those people in the community who are vulnerable to exploitation by unscrupulous or incompetent migration agents.

The minister proposes to delegate the administration of migration agents to the Migration Institute of Australia. The explanatory memorandum to the bills notes a key finding of the Spicer review in relation to the MIA:

The industry association, the Migration Institute of Australia has only limited coverage of the industry, having only 10 per cent of registered agents as members. The Association also lacks resources, with a membership of 250, an annual income sufficient only to meet the costs of one full‐time Secretary and with executive positions filled on an honorary basis.
The MIA was founded in 1992. Until recently the institute employed only one person. It operated its national headquarters from a post office box in Normanhurst, New South Wales.

The government's commitment to this organisation, however, is beyond question. It recently provided the MIA with a grant of $380,000 to assist with the development of the systems and infrastructure of the Migration Agents Registration Authority. The money has been paid, despite the fact that the bills to establish the authority have not yet been passed.

The opposition have grave concerns about possible conflicts of interest if the MIA is appointed as the administrator and regulator of the industry. Our concerns were compounded by the responses to questions from officials of the MIA at the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee public hearings on 5 November 1997. The interchange appears at pages 34, 35 and 36 of the committee's report, which was presented to the Senate on 18 November 1997.
It is worth while briefly quoting the comments of the national President and the national Vice‐President of the MIA from that public hearing. Mr Brown, the President said:
In terms of MARA—
that is the Migration Agents Registration Authority—

the point needs to be made—and I think it became apparent during this morning's proceedings—that it has not been understood that MARA will in fact be a separate body to the MIA. MARA is not MIA, so it will not be the MIA registering agents; it will be MARA. Conflict of interest issues will be removed by making that separation.
Mr Cope, the Vice President, went on to say:

Could I add to that? What Ray is saying is that the MIA is acting on a delegation from the minister, so the MIA membership is comprised through election processes to create a national executive, such as that which exists. The Migration Institute will continue to run in that fashion but, in addition to that, there will be a legislative overlay, so the institute itself will carry out the regulatory roles. Those regulatory roles will not be exercised by us, the national executive directors, but by employees paid through the registration levies of people who seek registration with MARA. MARA is the MIA in terms of exercising those legislative responsibilities.

I understand that Mark Sullivan, from the department, explained this morning that they are separate roles. They are separate, but additional, roles. People might be still writing a cheque for their registration fees. They will not be going to the MIA; they will be going to the registering authority, of which the MIA is nominally the name, but it is exercised by employees whom this body—the national executive of the MIA—employs.
Mr Cope later clarified by saying:
I was meaning to clarify that there is not another MARA. It is the MIA. If you wanted to make a complaint you would contact the institute's employees, through the MARA legislation.
I know that was an extensive quote, but I think it is very worth while to put it in at this early stage in the debate on these bills.

This legislation is a very direct, ideologically based attack on the community sector that provides immigration advice on a no‐cost basis. The fact that it is such an attack is proven in many ways. The community sector accounts for some 24 per cent of registered agents. It was not represented on the minister's reference group, but the MIA, then representative of only 10 per cent of the registered agents, had two senior officials on the six‐member reference group. It is no wonder that the review found:

that there is no basis for public funding of the regulation of the migration advice industry and that, in an environment of statutory‐based regulation, regulation should be funded on a cost‐recovery basis.
When the issue of registration fees is discussed, the ideological attack is crystal clear.

Under the current legislation, non‐fee charging registered agents do not pay a registration fee. The bill before the Senate will change that, and the change will be dramatic. Under regulations that will accompany this bill—if it is passed—if an individual, voluntary, non‐fee charging person seeks to register with the Migration Agents Registration Authority, MARA—for which, perhaps, read MIA—each will have to fork out a whopping $475 per annum.

To get this into perspective, the Senate should note that fee charging agents can and do charge up to five figure sums for migration advice. To register, these agents will have to pay $1,000 per annum. Those who charge nothing to service the most vulnerable may have to pay a half of what is to be levied on the commercial sector. I say, advisedly, that, in the event of the opposition's committee stage amendments failing and this bill passing, the opposition will consider whether to move to disallow the regulations that propose to levy the exorbitant and unrealistic registration fee on the voluntary non‐fee charging sector.

The opposition in its minority report to the Senate committee report condemned the government for its lack of consultation with the voluntary, non‐fee charging sector in deciding the fees issue. Labor members of the committee said that they considered making the same finding against the MIA but withdrew from this only because of the confusion about the MIA's role in the development of the bills. Did the MIA have some form of semi‐official, de jure, de facto consultative role in the process?

Both the department and the MIA strenuously denied that the MIA had at any time had an official appointment or delegation to act or negotiate on behalf of the minister or the department. MIA officers were known to admit that discussions on fees had occurred with sections of the voluntary sector. Under questioning, they admitted that they were not negotiating on behalf of the minister or the department.

The Labor opposition is disturbed and distressed by the following response to committee members' questions from Ms Bedlington, the First Assistant Secretary—Refugee and Humanitarian Division of the department at the Senate estimates committee on 13 November:

The issue of how fees were going to be set was one that was primarily led by the MIA. If the minister is going to delegate the authority for the registration of migration agents, the way in which that is going to be run and its overall cost would be under the direct control of the MIA. Therefore, the level of fees that would be required to meet that cost, it seems, would more appropriately be worked through with the MIA.

This type of conduct is disgusting and the voluntary non‐fee charging sector which has contributed so much over the years does not deserve to be treated in this way. The opposi tion is disappointed that the government, in suggesting the proposed fee regime, fails to recognise the significant role and contribution of the voluntary sector agents who are operating in an environment of increasing government cutbacks and competing demands. Both the Victorian Immigration Advice and Rights Centre and the Immigration Advice and Rights Centre of New South Wales told the committee that that proposed fee regime would undermine their capacity to provide service to the more disadvantaged sections of the community that seek immigration advice. All would agree that VIARC and IARC are representative of the community sector.

The minister and the department have not provided any plausible justification for the imposition of a fees regime on those least able to meet those exorbitant and outrageous charges. It should be noted that at the same time the bills propose to reduce the registration charges for more than 25 per cent of currently registered agents. I put it to the Senate that those who would benefit by the reductions are in fact the very agents who would be more able to afford a much higher fee. The minister clearly displayed his antipathy toward the voluntary sector during debate on the bills. He made an extraordinary statement about the 450 non‐fee charging agents when he said:
They did not have to meet the same standards as fee charging agents. You cannot tolerate a two‐tier system where the most vulnerable receive a lower standard of service.

The department was questioned about this statement during the Senate committee's inquiry, but officers could not produce any evidence to support or verify the minister's statement, other than to draw attention to the different admission standards.

One measure of standards and quality of performance might be the number of complaints made against the voluntary sector in comparison to other registered agents such as lawyers and fee charging registered agents. The Migration Agents Registration Board has received 1,248 complaints since the scheme commenced. Out of that total, only 18 were against persons registered in the voluntary sector. This is an astonishingly good figure considering this sector accounts for a quarter of the registered agents. No prosecutions have ever been launched against any registered agents from the voluntary sector.

The Queensland branch president of the MIA, Mr John Hodges, appeared before the Senate committee as an MIA national executive member. Mr Hodges offered an opinion on the performance of the voluntary sector. He made some highly critical reflections against the providers of migration advice at the South Brisbane Immigration and Community Legal Service. These allegations have since been vigorously and categorically rejected by the service in a five‐page response which was attached to the opposition members' minority report to the Senate committee report.

Mr Hodges, a member of the minister's reference group, said that he had not reported his allegations about poor service. He stated that he had not lodged any complaint. It is disturbing to note that, under the legislation that is now being debated in the Senate, Mr Hodges, who is an executive member of the MIA, would be an executive member of the Migration Agents Registration Authority. He, with his other MIA and MARA colleagues, would be in charge of the body which would administer the new scheme. It is proposed that this authority would govern standards and police behaviour and ethics of registered agents.

I have not heard yet if the MIA has publicly apologised to the South Brisbane Immigration and Community Legal Service for the comments that were made by one of their members during the public hearing. I have attempted to get a copy of the speech by the national president, at a conference in Melbourne last week, but so far I have been unable to get that. I hope that an apology was part of that speech. If not, I hope that a public apology is delivered very shortly.

The bills do not represent the unanimous views of the industry as some would have us believe. Remember, the Spicer review group did not include one representative from a major community based group. Indeed, the Spicer review group recognised in its report the major stakeholders to be only the MIA and the Law Council of Australia. The bill introduces a form of statutory self‐regulation and the minister will appoint the Migration Institute of Australia as the Migrant Agents Registration Authority. In his evidence to the Senate committee, a representative of the MIA said that the MIA, as MARA, will be exercising `a statutory power'—`a public power of a public authority in delegation'—`within a statutory framework'.

The Senate committee received advice from the Attorney‐General's Department confirming some of the legal and administrative arrangements proposed under the bill. The Office of General Counsel, whilst confirming that MARA would not be a statutory authority, said there may be avenues for parliamentary scrutiny of the MIA's actions when acting as MARA. These opportunities are going to be very limited, as explained in the following response:

The Institute is incorporated as a company limited by guarantee. As such it is not part of the Commonwealth, for example, part of DIMA. Nor is it a statutory authority established by the Commonwealth. Rather, it is a separate, private sector company proposed to be given Commonwealth statutory powers and functions and to be known for these purposes as MARA.

It follows from the preceding comments that MIA will be a separate body for the purposes of DIMA's annual reports. The operations of MIA will not be the operations of DIMA. Therefore, DIMA will not be in a position to report on the activities of MIA as though they were activities of DIMA. However, it could report on its dealings with MIA and for that purpose report on matters to which it has access concerning the exercise of functions and powers of MIA under the Act.

It may be possible for a Senate estimates committee to call MARA or the MIA as a recipient of Commonwealth funds to appear before that committee. This is an interesting exercise which we will be exploring perhaps at some time in the future.

The opposition had some concerns about the time for objections for the registration of agents. We note the government's amendments which will be moved in the second reading debate. We are very pleased that the government has seen fit to alter its proposal. We think this is sensible, as indeed we believe that there are some sensible propositions contained in the bills. However, we believe those sensible provisions could be implemented without the need to resort to self‐regulation or a move towards self‐regulation, which this bill is about. There will be an opposition committee stage amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of migration bills that the Senate is considering today is designed to do two main things: it is designed to move the migration advice industry towards a system of self‐regulation via an initial period of statutory self‐regulation and it is designed to establish a new system of fees for migration agents who seek registration. I think it is important to emphasise right at the start that the Democrats have a number of problems with these changes and the direction they are going in.

SPEECH.PARA: We have got particular problems with the proposal to move the migration industry towards self‐regulation, as well as the proposal to start charging fees for non‐fee charging agents working in the voluntary sector. That is certainly not to say that the Democrats do not understand and fully support the need for a system which offers the often very vulnerable clients of migration agents strong and effective protection—I think we would all agree on that—but we are not convinced that a system based on voluntary or even statutory self‐regulation is the best way that this can be achieved.

In his second reading speech in the other place, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) made it very clear that statutory self‐regulation for the migration advice industry is to be an interim measure for two years commencing in March next year and that this proposed scheme would be reviewed before March in the year 2000 to determine the extent to which the Migration Institute of Australia has developed the capacity and infrastructure to undertake the role of industry regulator in a fully self‐regulating environment. What is not really questioned here though is whether or not the move towards voluntary self‐regulation is actually a desirable one.

When considering this I do not think we can afford to ignore the comments made by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration in their 1995 report, Protecting the vulnerable? I understand the current minister was a member of that committee. That committee stated:
. . . self regulation is more effective where there are mature and concentrated markets or where there is a propensity for consumers to make repeat purchases.

When it comes to the migration advice industry, the Spicer review in March of this year—and I think the government itself—has acknowledged that, at least at this stage, we do not have a very mature market; that this is something which can change over time. It is something that the government obviously believes is moving in the right direction. However, what is not likely to change much is that the consumers of migration advice are rarely in a position to make repeat purchases and because so many clients are disadvantaged—many cannot speak English—they are often not in a position to complain or to even recognise that they have been given poor advice.

I think what we need to be asking here is a much broader question about the direction we are going in. That question is: is it possible that there are alternatives to voluntary self‐regulation which may in fact provide much more effective protection for consumers, but simply have not been considered because they fall outside the government's narrow ideological view of how things should operate in a market framework?

It is time that we start to broaden the debate on this issue and a whole range of areas across the board and move beyond the assumption that the hands‐off approach is always the best or economic and competition considerations should always be give priority. It is important to continue to emphasise that the impact on people should be given priority and the market should take second place to that, regardless of what the market is; and in this case we are talking about the migration advice market.

A number of questions have been raised and were outlined by Senator McKiernan in his speech about whether the Migration Institute of Australia, the MIA, is the appropriate body to act as the Migration Agents Registration Authority during this interim statutory regulation period. Witnesses at the recent committee hearings stated their concerns that the MIA was not the appropriate body to carry out these tasks. The Democrats share many of those doubts about the MIA's ability to act as the registration authority. Again, Senator Mckiernan has outlined a number of those, including: how representative the MIA actually is; whether they have the capacity to administer the scheme adequately; the very real concerns about the potential for conflicts of interest; and how they would be able to adequately handle complaints and disciplinary matters.

One witness to the recent committee hearing asked whether it was possible for a body which is not truly representative of the industry—being made up at this stage primarily of commercial agents—to carry out the tasks which will be required when it has virtually no experience in very important areas such as refugees and humanitarian visas. Often the people looking for advice in those areas are amongst the most vulnerable. A number of other witnesses also suggested that there was potential for a conflict of interest in the MIA, the industry body, also carrying out the regulatory role. As one witness put it:

. . . it is a rather odd situation that the government should be handing over disciplinary and complaints handling and consumer protection to a body which is also representing the interests of the actual people who are providing the service.

In the light of these issues and others raised by witnesses during the 1995 joint committee hearings, the Spicer review and the recent Senate committee hearings, the Democrats are of the view that the migration industry is not ready to move towards self‐regulation at this stage. Nor do we believe that the MIA is the appropriate body to act as a migration agents registration authority. For those reasons, the Democrats are supportive of the aim of the ALP's amendments, which would act to extend the system that currently operates by three years and ensure that there is a viable and workable system in place while allowing the government to give further thought and consideration to the direction it is taking in this area.

BREAK.PARA: Of course, the problem that the Senate faces in relation to this area is that this amendment of the ALP's will need the agreement of the government at the end of the day to enable the exiting system to continue. If that agreement is not forthcoming from the government then we will basically be left with a situation where, come March next year, there would be no protection in place at all for migrants. That is a situation which the Democrats would find totally unacceptable and I am sure all senators would be concerned about.

Whilst we would urge the government to consider agreeing to the ALP's amendment to extend the current system by three years, we do recognise, given the indications they have expressed to date, that they are not willing to pursue that option. That would leave us in a situation where we have no scheme in place at all come March next year, which is obviously not a good scenario.

The Democrats are pleased with the amendments that the government has circulated today. Those amendments extend the period during which a person may lodge an objection to the registration of a migration agent and introduce a requirement for the MIA to report to the minister and for the minister to report to the parliament on how the new scheme is going. We are happy with both those changes, particularly the extension of time allowing for objections.

I will ask the minister a couple of questions in the committee stage about the publication of notifications, et cetera. I will leave my comments on that until then. The other main area of the bill is the introduction of fees for non‐fee charging agents working in voluntary community organisations. The Democrats acknowledge the very important and high quality services that these organisations provide. Whilst we strongly support the requirement that volunteer bodies comply with continuing education requirements, we do not believe that it is desirable to have the impact of fees on the capacity of community groups to provide migration advice to those who are most disadvantaged.

I am please that the office of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, has been willing to consider the level of fees that are charged. It is the view of the Democrats that the community sector should not be charged any fees at all, because we believe that it will impact on a sector that is clearly extremely under‐resourced. Many of the organisations that provide voluntary advice have a number of people who provide that advice. The compounding effect of each of those people having to pay any sort of fee would add up pretty quickly for a severely under‐resourced voluntary organisation.

The Democrat view is that the appropriate way to go is to have no fees at all for those organisations. We have been having ongoing discussions with the office of the minister, Mr Ruddock, about this issue. I am pleased that he has been willing to consider amending the level of fees charged to the voluntary sector. When we get to the committee stage, I will ask the minister in this chamber, Senator Vanstone, some questions about the government's approach in relation to fees. I have certainly had some indications from Mr Ruddock's office that he is willing to reduce the fee levels for the voluntary sector fairly significantly. Whilst I restate the Democrats' view that we believe that no fees will be appropriate at this stage, obviously, the lower the fee, the better for the voluntary sector.

During the committee stage, and perhaps before we get to the ALP's amendments, I will also seek to ask the minister some questions about what approach the government is looking to take with the implementation of the legislation and the monitoring of how it operates, particularly on the voluntary sector, but also on the broader sector as a whole. I will leave any further comments on that until we get to the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997 deals with the issue of migration agents—the people who help the immigration system to ensure that those who are allowed to come into Australia do so as best they can and with as much expedition as possible, and to keep out those who should not come to Australia. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has two functions: one is a regulatory function, making sure that people comply with the immigration legislation; and the other is a facilitation function to ensure that those who come in do so with as much comfort and ease as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: For that to happen, there must be agents who give advice to those who are subject to the immigration laws. Lawyers do a lot of that work, and so do migration agents. It has been the policy of this government and the former government to make those who assist people with immigration problems subject to regulations.

The people who help those who are seeking advice about migration law should be as competent as possible. I am not sure that this legislation assures that. The most effective agents in this area are community agents. These people have been referred to by the last two speakers. The policy that is presently afoot seems to make it as hard as possible for those agents to operate.

As I say, they are the most effective agents. In my state, bodies like the Victorian Immigration Advice and Rights Centre and the Refugee Advice and Casework Service are staffed by very dedicated people who know the law in this area and can apply it. During the committee stage I will ask questions—which, perhaps, the department can answer—about what lawyers they have had looking at the standard of knowledge of the people who give advice on this law, what advice they have got about the amount of money that those people charge, and how they treat their clients.

If you were to look at those three issues, the Refugee Advice and Casework Service and the Victorian Immigration Advice and Rights Centre would score very highly. However, that does not seem to be the standard that is applied in deciding who are going to be the agents in this area. The standard applied is the issue of how much money will be available and where that money will go. There is a danger that money provided by the government in this area to ensure that people are properly looked after will go into law firms which do not have this as a primary aspect of their practice and which do not have cheap partners.

BREAK.PARA: As I understand it, for example, the Refugee Advice and Casework Service in Victoria has a lot of work at the moment. I am told they have 650 East Timorese to look to, and 130 other cases, and have been provided with $42,000 until next June to accomplish that service. It seems a very interesting approach for the department to be taking. Does the department want an efficient service that runs well? What I mean by an efficient service is a service where the department is able to present a case efficiently and where those against whom they present a case can also do so efficiently.

The Refugee Advice and Casework Service Victoria Ltd is talking with people who are amongst the most vulnerable in this society—indeed, in any society throughout the world. But as I understand it, apart from the problems that are associated with those seeking protection as refugees here, there are the general immigration problem people, if I can put it that way, whom the Victorian Immigration and Advice and Rights Centre look after. VIARC has been given $22,000 to do that work until June 1998. It just seems ridiculous—and if this is not to be accepted, then perhaps the minister can contradict it—that those two bodies which contain the most dedicated, most efficient and most learned group able to give advice to people with problems in migration, should be treated in that way. It is just a nonsense.

These organisations are not in the public sector; they are in the community sector. Take RACS, for example. Lots of people go there to give advice and work voluntarily, and for that, as I understand, those people have to pay a fee to register. I am subject to correction here, but I think they have to pay the full fee, $475, or a reduced fee, but it is substantial in any event. This is an issue that is to be seen in the context of legal aid generally.

Looking at the Victorian Bar News—which I am sure the department reads whenever it comes out; certainly, the minister would—for Spring 1997, on page 7 I see this heading, `Legal aid funding crisis continues to dominate bar council business'. The way the Refugee Advice and Casework Service Victoria and the Victorian Immigration Advice and Rights Centre Inc. are being treated will demonstrate just how correct it is for the Victorian Bar Council to be talking about legal aid and the way it dominates the bar's discussions.

There is another article in this magazine with a great heading which reads, `How to lose a contested matter without really trying'. A lot of people who act in this area would be great demonstrators of the truth of that headline. They show how to lose a contested matter without really trying, whereas bodies like RACS and VIARC show quite the opposite. They have the skills, the learning and the experience to make sure that people's rights are properly vindicated. It is not the purpose of those two bodies to keep people in Australia who should not be kept here. It is not their function, as it were, to try to get around the law. It is their function to see that the law is properly applied to their clients and to properly attend to their clients' position, as it is for any legal adviser, but it is getting very difficult to do that.

On one side you have the vast resources of the department filled with learning and people who know this area of the law backwards, who can give advice and draw on advice from the Attorney‐General, if the department needs it, and on the other side of the contest is a person who has very little in the way of resources and whose hope really is to be able to rely only on bodies like the Victorian Immigration Advice and Rights Centre Inc. and the Refugee Advice and Casework Service Victoria Inc.

There is no doubt that there are some very good solicitors in this area, whom I know—I do not know many agents who are not solicitors—but for people who do not know the country, the society and the community as well as those who were born here, it is very difficult to go to the right place for the best advice. Indeed, it is very hard for people who were born here to know who to go to for the right advice on the matters which they have to deal with.

Here you have two bodies which people can go to and be guaranteed of proper advice, yet they are being starved of funds to the point where they may have to close down. This system is put under awful pressure that may lead those bodies to close down. Then the system would be well and truly loaded against the people who want to see their way through a very complex act, and the minister would understand that. The act itself is complex, the regulations are complex and need skill and learning, and the very bodies which would enable people to get through that, so that we at least would have an approach to justice in the whole system, are going to be closed down. I would be interested to hear what the minister has to say about those issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Cooney made an extremely fine contribution to this debate on the migration bills, raising matters which need a response from the government. I listened carefully to what Senator Bartlett had to say, and I apologise that I did not hear what Senator McKiernan had to say because I was in another meeting, but certainly they raised matters that the government needs to respond to in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I come from the view that access to good information by those who often are without English and who are in very vulnerable situations is a right, not to be regarded just as a service subject to the demands of competition policy and user pays.

I must say that I have great difficulty with this particular legislation. My biggest concern is with regard to the impact of the legislation on voluntary community sectors. Only this morning I received a fax—and it is surprising I received it because thousands and thousands of faxes are pouring into my office on another unmentionable matter that is before the Senate—from the Migrant Resource Centre. This fax raises a number of matters to which Senator Cooney has referred. As Senator Cooney indicated, these dedicated and efficient organisations believe in the need for the most vulnerable—and for others, of course—to receive access to good information.

Amongst other things I will say that the provision of immigration advice by voluntary organisations such as RACS and the VIARC is of vital importance to those who cannot afford to pay. Unfortunately, some of those groups have seen their funding slashed. They function in continuing uncertainty. I personally know many dedicated individuals who are working in the area of refugee advice. Their work is of the highest quality and is delivered with great concern for the wellbeing of their clients. These groups already operate on very tight budgets.
In this fax that was sent to me, RACS says:
. . . RACS has eaten into a considerable amount of our savings and have enough money to continue for only about another four months at the most.
On 26 November 1997, RACS . . . were advised that we would receive $132,748 for Victoria and $133,029 for NSW, amounting to $265,777 nationally.
On 27 November 1997, we received a fax from the Department advising us that the figures . . . were a mistake and that the true level of funding is: Victoria $42,076—
not a bad drop from $132,000 to $42,000—
and NSW $54,257.
down from $133,000—
This represents just over one third of what we had previously been advised.

Surely there must be some explanation for this. In the committee stage, I—and no doubt Senator Bartlett, Senator Cooney and Senator McKiernan—will be asking a few questions which it is not appropriate for me to ask in this debate. As RACS points out:

If applicants are unable to adequately present their claims and applications, the whole integrity of the immigration program is threatened. When unrepresented and unassisted clients receive decisions they consider to be unjust, they move into the appeals.
That is something the minister constantly argues he is trying to reduce. If he is reducing the efficacy of these voluntary services, he will increase the costs of appeals.
Senator Cooney mentioned a very interesting point which is in the missive from RACS about the services that RACS and other voluntary organisations provide for advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say—
—May I, because it is here on page 4 of the document. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: RACs and VIARC both consider the MARS Bill as proposed to be extremely problematic. Even with the concessions you mentioned to me on the telephone . . . we continue to have grave reservations about whether the Bill should be passed.
Here is a most interesting point:

Even with a fee of $100 to register, our volunteer evening advice services would be annihilated. We would be unable to cover any registration fees given our dire funding situation. Fees would have to be covered by volunteers, many of whom are impecunious.

The point is that it is a $100 registration fee for each and every person who is involved in the service. These organisations may have 120 or 130 people who are providing the service and taking time to go out at night and give evening advice services. As they say here, those services will be junked—annihilated, to use their more civilised word. I really do need to know that the government will make a commitment not to erode the funding of groups in the voluntary sector—a commitment that will make that certain for them. I urge the government to demonstrate a commitment to the voluntary sector and to ensure adequate funding so that these groups can continue to provide the highest quality service to those who need it. How can they be expected to pay the registration fees if they can barely survive now?

I am in a difficult position on this matter. I have expressed my views on migration over the years. You know my views. I have entered into the debate over the years and argued with the previous government in respect of some of their legislation which I felt affected the most vulnerable. Of course, my position has to do with the sunset clause. I know and acknowledge that certain things have been done. I recognise that the minister has made a number of concessions. The fees to be paid by the voluntary sector have been reduced from $475 to $150 in the first year and $100 in the second year. The minister has also undertaken to extend from 10 days to 30 days the notification of intention to register, which would allow more time for lodgment of an objection. This increase from 10 days is certainly an improvement when you are considering issues of consumer protection.

But the fact is that I am in a difficult position, and Senator Bartlett has indicated similarly. The opposition has suggested that we amend the legislation to allow it to have a further period of three years. That would be fine except that we do have a sunset clause in the legislation at the moment. The minister has made it perfectly clear that, if the Labor Party amendment is adopted by the chamber, that would not be acceptable to the House of Representatives. That is a matter to which Senator Bartlett referred. People seeking migration advice do need protection. As I understand it, and I will ask the minister here, in the event of the House of Representatives not agreeing, the government does not intend to bring the legislation back here. I suppose it would not have the opportunity of doing so in time. And then we will be rushing across the precipice with no legislation.

While people do need advice and protection, there needs to be some regulation. Statutory self-regulation is a better option than no regulation at all, which is a situation we could face next year. I know there are people in the government who would not mind living with that situation. I do not believe that the minister is in that category. I suspect that Senator Vanstone, the minister representing the minister, would not be in that category either. But I must say that, in the end, I really would like, and I am sure the Senate would like, some questions answered that will be able to be put to the minister once we reach the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank senators for participating in the second reading debate. I will refer to a couple of points. I understand that Senator McKiernan, perhaps before I got here, made some remarks about the Spicer review reference group. I am advised that members were chosen for their skills and expertise, not for being representatives of any particular group. One of the six members, Ms Cheryl Webster, was with Careforce which is an Anglican Home Mission. She brought knowledge of the community sector. She had a very good understanding of the issues concerning vulnerable consumers. Senator, I was not here when you raised that point. I am not sure if it is directly on the point that you raised, but I am advised that it is.

BREAK.PARA: A number of speakers have made a number of comments in relation to RACS and VIARC. I think it is probably appropriate to respond to those comments. The government agrees that all have well qualified staff—arguably, one might say, the best in the voluntary sector. The department put services for immigration advice and assistance out to tender and these two organisations were the successful tenderers. Interim contracts were offered pending the resolution of final contracts.

I point out to Senator Harradine that while I am not able to be specific at the moment about funding, as negotiations are currently both organisations are likely to be funded at the same overall level this financial year as last financial year. The matter is not concluded, but I am advised that that is where it is in the negotiating stage at this point.

Some of the services will be different. VIARC successfully tendered for training for voluntary agents, which is a new service type. RACS Australia has successfully tendered, as you mentioned in your speech, Senator Harradine, not just for work in Victoria but for work in New South Wales as well. While they are likely to have therefore a lesser amount of work in Victoria, they will provide a significant level of services in New South Wales. I think those points are worth making with respect to those groups.

In addition to the remarks made by Senator Cooney, Senator Harradine specifically raised the issue of the misinformation to RACS with respect to the level of funding. As I am advised, the covering letter from the department was wrong although the contract was correct. The advice the following day, I think you indicated it was, was to correct the covering letter, not the contract.

The said amount excluded detention case work which is paid per case and referred by DIMA. The amount in the letter did include a planned amount for detention. They may or may not, I am advised, get that number of cases in funding, depending on the number of referrals for detention. The contract amount, which was attached, was minus the possible detention cases and that, in fact, was the correct amount. Detention work will be extra.

Senator Bartlett in his contribution made reference to monitoring the performance of the MIA as a registering authority. There is a formal agreement between the minister and MIA, including reporting requirements on a regular basis to the minister, which will probably be on a monthly basis and will be governed by legislation. If they are found not to be operating in the interests of consumers, the minister does have the power to withdraw the delegation.

There were a number of other points made in speeches in the second reading debate. I think the government's response to those is reflected in the amendments which we will be moving in the committee stage. There are a number of remarks I want to make about the fees that were proposed to be charged to community groups.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (MIGRATION AGENTS) BILL 1997
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill. The memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 1 December. I seek leave to move government amendments 1 and 2 together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 32, page 8 (line 21), omit "10 days", substitute "30 days".
(2) Schedule 1, item 32, page 8 (line 22), omit "10 days", substitute "30 days".

The government has noted concerns that were raised about this bill. We have been listening. There are concerns about the short length of time allowed for the making of objections to an agent's intention to register and about the lack of a formal reporting requirement to parliament for the proposed Migration Agents Registration Authority.

BREAK.PARA: The government has had discussions on these issues with a number of parties and has made amendments to the bill to meet these concerns. The first will extend the period of notification for intention to register as a migration agent from 10 to 30 days. That will provide a much longer period for objections to be lodged. The second will require the Migration Institute of Australia to lodge an annual report on the activities of the Migration Agents Registration Authority with the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs for tabling in parliament.

An additional concern has been the charging of registration fees for voluntary sector agents. The government appreciates the concern that has been raised by the Democrats and Senator Harradine just recently with respect to this matter. It was originally proposed that voluntary agents be charged $475 in the first year and $350 in later years. We have now agreed to reduce that amount to $150 in the first year and $100 in subsequent years.

That is a fairly dramatic concession or reduction—phrase it whichever way you will—in acknowledgment of the arguments that have been raised in favour of these voluntary groups. For the government to reduce the charge for the first year from the proposed $475 to $150 and the charge for subsequent years from $350 to $100 is a fairly clear indication that it has listened to these concerns and responded very substantially. I admit that the government has not gone as far as some would like. Some would like no fees to be charged, but nonetheless it is a very significant acknowledgment of the concerns that have raised.

To finance this reduction, full fee paying agents will be required to pay a fee of $800 in the second and subsequent years rather than $750. This fee structure will be reflected in the regulations to the bill. The government does not accept the proposition that agents who are employed by, or are volunteers with, community organisations should be totally free from paying a registration fee. Charging the voluntary sector agents a small registration fee—as I indicate, it is going from $475 down to $150 and from $350 down to $100—we believe is fair and reasonable.

It is appropriate to expect voluntary agents to be responsible for making a contribution to the running of a scheme which is self‐funding rather than being fully subsidised by the other full fee paying agents. By paying a fee, we believe agents are more likely to take responsibly the task of being a competent migration agent, and that gives a degree of status to the task. In any event, many of the organisations which provide free immigration advice receive funding from Commonwealth and state governments.

I am sure that all senators would agree that the migration advice industry needs regulation. Senator Harradine was making some remarks with respect to this matter. This bill provides for an enhanced new regulation scheme for the industry. As senators are aware, the existing scheme is subject to a sunset clause which will come into effect in March next year. I commend the bill to senators. I ask them to ensure that we do not put ourselves in a situation where the entire industry will be unregulated and there will be no specific consumer protection available to this very vulnerable client group.

It would be ideal if there were a longer period of time. I appreciate that. We might have all sorts of options, but we do not have that longer period of time. The sunset clause will operate in March. We are not coming back until some time in March—I am not quite sure of the date—or late February, and there will not be time to shift from the scheme that is operating now to a new scheme without creating some sort of mayhem.

I commend Senator Harradine's advice or comments—I do not know which it was—to other senators.
