Despite the fact there might be some differences of opinion, I ask senators to accept that the government has made a number of amendments responding to community concerns and has committed itself today to a very significant reduction in the charges that were proposed to be charged to community groups in an effort to acknowledge the concerns that have been raised; recognise the validity of the concerns that have been raised, in an effort to get this bill through; and ensure that we can move from here through to the sunset clause into a properly regulated system. Without doing that, we will not be providing the appropriate consumer protection to, as I say, one of the most vulnerable client groups.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition has one major concern, and it is better to put it on the table right from the beginning. At no time until Senator Harradine spoke during the second reading debate did we know that the government was considering reducing the fees that are going to apply to the non-fee charging voluntary sector. It is a breach of faith on behalf of the government to not at least inform the shadow minister of that fact. We had a briefing with the government and senior departmental figures as late as last week and we were told on that occasion that the fees were a matter for the regulation.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no mention of fees in our amendment. Neither Senator Harradine nor the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Senator Vanstone, were present during my speech at the second reading stage. I did refer to the issue of fees then, but I did indicate that we would be dealing with the matter of fees when the regulations came before this place. In fact, on behalf of the opposition, I warned this chamber that we might—we did not say we would—move to disallow the regulations and the fees that apply to the voluntary sector. That is a decision to be made by others in another place, but I had an authority to say that here.

The major movement in the fees question, whilst it might be welcome as an initial gesture, opens up somewhat of a pandora's box. During the Senate committee deliberations on the bill, the matter of fees, of course, was addressed. One of the reasons given for the levying of fees on the voluntary sector at the levels that were suggested—and remember we are talking about $475 in the first instance and then in subsequent years it would be $350 per person—was that it was the total amount needed to run the MARA when it was established.

BREAK.PARA: It raises the point that, if there are going to be these substantial reductions from $475 to $150 and from $350 to $100, there is going to be a subsequent loss of revenue for the MARA. Is that going to be made up by an increased levy on the other sectors of industry, the fee charging sector? Are the fees that apply to lawyers who register as a migration agent going to be increased in order to compensate? If there is going to be a shortfall, where is it going to come from? It does raise some questions. I will make some more general comments at this time and then sit down because there is no wish on this side of the chamber to delay proceedings at all.

Senator Harradine, in his very careful and very measured second reading contribution, raised the question of funding to the various organisations. In particular, like Senator Cooney, he referred to what has happened with the Refugee Advice and Casework Service in Victoria, and I understand the minister will come back to that in some more detail. The story told to us by both Senator Harradine and Senator Cooney is being replicated in organisations like RACS right around the country. Organisations such as that which are providing a very valuable and needed service to the community are strapped for cash and, in some instances, have just had to fold up. In fact, this has happened to people who were working with ethnic communities.

Senator Harradine mentioned the dilemma we are in because of the lateness of debate on the bill, and the minister referred to this herself. The opposition have a solution to this problem. It would have been perhaps more logical to deal with the opposition's amendment No. 771 which has been circulated and which calls for the extension of the sunset provision in the bill for a further two years. I suggest it would have been more logical to deal with that amendment in the first instance, rather than dealing with the minister's amendments because if our amendment and the government's amendments are carried by the chamber, it will create some difficulties as to how the bill will be implemented and how workable it will be.

We will be back here all too soon in early March and, if our amendment is carried now, there will be time in that intervening period for the minister, the department and the government to go back and revisit the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration and seek to implement the favourable provisions that were contained in that report. There was no need—and we reiterate it here again today—for a further review by Spicer. All the mechanisms were there—they were in place—and it could have been done if there was a will to do it. As I said in my speech during the second reading debate, these bills are not about protecting the vulnerable. They are about deregulation; they are about self-regulation.

There is a final point I want to make, and I am trying to keep things as brief and focused as possible. The minister responded to my comments about representation of the community sector on the Spicer review. I did note that Ms Cheryl Webster, a grant‐in‐aid worker for Careforce, the Anglican Home Mission, was indeed a member of the minister's reference group. I have had a long involvement in migration with the Senate—both on the joint standing committee and on the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee—and I might say that the Anglican Home Mission is not an organisation that comes to the fore when one is looking for a community viewpoint on immigration advice. It is not one of them.

Careforce may be in receipt of some government funding, because I note Ms Webster is a grant‐in‐aid worker with Careforce and I understand the very good work that Careforce does in a whole host of areas, including migration, not only in New South Wales but around Australia. I am not in any way seeking to denigrate it, but I would argue that the Anglican Home Mission is not an essential figure in community migration advice in Australia. There are a number of other organisations like VIARC, IARC, RACS and the Refugee Council of Australia that one would lead to, but one would not immediately think of the Anglican Home Mission when one was looking for advice on a measure of how the community was feeling on these matters. The precipice that Senator Harradine referred to is not there. We believe that we have put the barrier up across the top of the precipice with our amendment No. 771, which we will move at a later time in the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I apologise to the committee if I have acted inappropriately. I do not want to suggest that the government's response was merely a result of my raising questions, because as I understand it Senator Bartlett has been involved in discussions and negotiations. I am not sure whether the Labor Party had taken a view that this legislation should be rejected and that was it or what is the case. I do acknowledge that it no doubt was rather inappropriate of me to announce what ought to have been announced by the minister. So I hope the committee will accept that. It is not what I normally do and I did it because I thought everybody would probably know.
—We didn't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —On the issue of charging $150 to volunteers, I think that is an excessive amount because the number of volunteers who go into organisations like this or other community legal centres are numerous and they change, so if they have to pay even $100 for them, it quickly mounts up. They might have 15 a week and that is $1,500, and the 15 they have the following week might not be the same.

SPEECH.PARA: It is typical of people doing studies. They might go to university during the day, come home on Monday night and go down and do a couple of hours volunteering. On Tuesday night, they might have tennis or football training and then do some study. On Wednesday night, they might study, with football or tennis training on Thursday night. You know, Senator Vanstone, that Saturday is off to the football. You used to watch Fitzroy when they were in the league. Then there is the replay. There is church on Sunday morning perhaps, and away they go.

The picture I want to paint is that these volunteers do it out of a sense of social responsibility and do it in a context where their lives and studies have to go on. To charge $100 for each of those when they change over the years, when they come and go and when it is voluntary seems to me to be excessive and seems to put a dampener on the sort of thing we should be having amongst the young. I would like to sound old and very wise at this stage, but it does put a dampener on their social conscience at a time in their lives when it should be encouraged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, perhaps I can put your mind at rest as to whether you have inadvertently or otherwise done the wrong thing. I do not believe you have. As I am advised—and I was not involved in discussions on this bill—you showed a particular interest in this matter and the cost that would be charged to community groups, as did Senator Bartlett, and we were engaged in continuing negotiations in that respect.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McKiernan, I do not know who was doing the negotiations on your side but, as I am advised, after a briefing on the bill—during which the possibility of a reduction of the fees was canvassed—the briefing concluded with, `Is there any more that you feel ready to discuss with us?' I am advised that the response was, `No.' I am further advised that, within a couple of days of that, whoever was handling the negotiations on your side was rung back and asked again if you were ready to talk more about the bill and the answer was, `No.' The question was put, `Will you be voting against the bill?' and the answer was, `Of course we will.' So there was not any attempt to hide this matter from you, as I am advised. It was simply that Senator Harradine and the Democrats wanted to be engaged in ongoing discussions on it and, as I am advised, your party did not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bit disappointing from the minister and it is a bit disappointing from the department who are providing that advice to the minister. That is something that we will take on board for the future and see where we are going. I was not the person who was rung back by the officers so I cannot categorically say that there was no ring back. The only reason I mentioned Senator Harradine's name was because he was the person who told us about this proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Even if we had categorically formally and finally closed the door from our briefing on Tuesday of last week—and I do not believe that was the case from my perspective—it might have been courteous to at least inform those of us on this side of the chamber of this very important movement. I do not know yet if it will be enough because the movement is great.

Senator Cooney has clearly put you on notice that even $100 for a voluntary organisation is an enormous amount of money. The voluntary community sector does not charge fees for its services. It does not charge for its advice and it is caught up. If this sector were to raise some funds in order to pay for the fees, it would then have to pay the full fee, which at the moment we are told is $1,000. Has there been any change in that area?

Minister, what is the overall impact of this proposition by the government to reduce the proposed fees for the voluntary sector from $475 in the first year to $150, and in the subsequent years from $350 to $100? What is the overall economic impact on the MARA because of that proposition?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Senator McKiernan, I should have responded to you before. When I was referring to the reductions, I did indicate how they would be funded. I indicated that they would be funded by a $50 increase on full fee paying agents, who will shift to a fee of $800 instead of $750.
—Is there any movement in the initial registration in the first year?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Same for the first year; this increase will be in the second and subsequent years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to seek a couple more comments from Minister Vanstone. I do appreciate the willingness of the government to go some way towards reducing the burden on the voluntary sector, whilst I and the Democrats still believe, as I indicated previously, that any fee is going to have a significant impact on them for the reasons that Senator Cooney outlined.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the amendments that the government will move in relation to reporting requirements, obviously the big concern that many people have, including the Democrats, is the effect that this charging of fees will have on the voluntary sector. That certainly came out in the committee hearings on this that I have read the transcripts for.

Part of the rationale that the government is putting forward is that this change is promoting competition. Concerns have been expressed by people, such as FECCA, that it will restrict competition because it will have the potential to wipe out a big chunk of the industry if it severely impacts on the voluntary sector. Certainly there was a very strong undertone in some of the comments made during the hearings, particularly from Mr Hodges, that the wiping out of the voluntary sector would not be too bad a thing, given his views on the quality of advice that they would give.

So I would be seeking some assurance from the government that, in terms of the ongoing reports from the MIA about the operation of the scheme and the reports that will need to be given to the parliament under these amendments, the impact of the fees on the voluntary sector will be given close attention so that we are able to see what sort of impact it is having in the information that is provided to the parliament.

I would like to get some indication from the minister on behalf of the government that they in no way support the implication made by Mr Hodges in his evidence to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee which was very critical of the standard of advice provided by community sectors, particular the South Brisbane Immigration and Community Legal Service, which is a service in Brisbane that I have a fair bit of knowledge of over many years. It has got an extremely high reputation. In general, I believe it is important that the government not only reaffirms its commitment to services such as these but also expresses its belief—assuming it is its belief—that the quality of advice provided by these services is at a standard as good as the fee charging sector.

Firstly, the suggestion was made that the standard of advice provided by the voluntary sector was not up to that of the fee charging sector and, secondly, some sort of implication, as Senator McKiernan indicated in his speech during the second reading, was made that they are not required to meet as high a standard as the fee charging sector. Certainly my understanding of this set‐up as it exists now, as well as with the new set‐up, is that the standards that they have to meet are as high. They still have to do the same training.

Certainly, from my experience, the quality of advice given by the voluntary sector is very good. It is a matter of great concern to me to see such a very strong attack made upon that sector. It certainly did give me the impression that some sections of the industry would be quite pleased if the voluntary sector were wiped out by these changes. I would very much like a commitment from the government that that is not their intention.

Similarly, I think Senator Harradine indicated in his contribution earlier that parts of the government—and he excluded the minister from this, I think rightly—would not be too upset if the whole regulatory system did fall over come March next year and people were left with no protection in the migration industry. Again that is a situation which the Democrats would be very concerned about. Again we would be seeking a commitment of the government that they would seek to avoid that outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bartlett, I can indicate that the reporting to the government will give such information as is available on the impact on the community sector, should there be one, one way or the other. The purpose of the fee on the community sector is not to discourage that sort of work by the community sector at all but to try to put all agents on a similar level, as you indicated, in terms of the training they need to undertake.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not about the agents or the advisers themselves; it is about ensuring that the vulnerable group get the same quality of advice wherever they go. We have simply taken the view that it is not appropriate for the fee paying sector to completely subsidise the community groups because they will just pass that on to their customers. We have listened to what Senator Bartlett, Senator Harradine and the community groups have said—very substantially, as Senator McKiernan has said—and a very major reduction in the fees is an acknowledgment of that. We believe it is appropriate that the community sector pays a small portion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, you are saying that the professional people, people who give their services on a fee‐for‐service basis, have to pay $800 a year. If there were a very powerful partnership of three people, they would have to pay $2,400 for the year for giving advice. If you have a voluntary sector where you have 50 people of the sort I described before—people who come and go—each of whom will have to pay $100, that means that the community service will have to pay $5,000 to run that show, if I can use that expression, whereas the professionals have to pay only $2,400.

SPEECH.PARA: Taking up Senator Bartlett's point, a lot of people who charge fees on a professional basis do a good job, but lots of others do not. I think the most learned person in Melbourne in this area is Lidia Argondizzo, who works in my office and is quite brilliant. So I have some sort of a judge of the place that comes through. But it seems to me that the community sector, which does provide very good and very proper information, is going to have to pay $5,000 a year whereas these other people, some of whom may or may not be good, will have to pay only $2,400 for a partnership of three. That is less than half of what the community service will have to pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow on from that. The question arises: has the MIA, the Migration Institute of Australia, agreed to exempt legal aid from having to pay any registration fee? If so, why will that exemption not be extended to solicitors from voluntary groups such as RACS and VIARC? That follows on from the question that Senator Cooney asks: if it is good enough for solicitors appearing where there is legal aid paid, and they are exempted from the payment of registration fees, why is it not good enough for the voluntary organisations, who are actually paid out very considerably as a result of taxpayers' money? It seems to me that it is just Peter paying Paul.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of points worth noting. As I am advised, there are only a few organisations that would have a significant number of volunteers. The vast majority of these have one or possibly two. About half of the voluntary organisations are funded by DIMA in the first instance. I think that is probably worth noting.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine, I understand the answer to the question that you raised about legal aid is that government officials are not required to register. I am advised that it is not a case of someone having made a specific exemption for the legal aid group but that government officials are not required to register—and legal aid officers are considered to be government officials.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to follow up that point. I am surprised at what the minister said about the number of volunteers. Mr Hodges, who is the President of the MIA in Queensland, gave evidence to the committee. He indicated:

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment there are about 25 volunteers that work there every Monday and Wednesday night. Five of those 25 are MIA members . . .

I suspect that a lot more volunteers work in this sector than the minister has been told about. Let us face it, Mr Hodges is a pretty informed individual. He is President of the MIA in Queensland, and he was a former minister for immigration and was on the minister's reference group for this thing. If he can state publicly that, in the centre where he works with his wife to provide voluntary advice on a no‐fee charging basis, there are 25 volunteers working, one would think that those numbers are more likely to be replicated in other parts of Australia.

BREAK.PARA: To help the process along, I will state where the opposition is coming from in regard to the treatment of the amendments. We do have some questions we want to put on the record about what the government proposes to do in the area of training and education opportunities for people from the voluntary sector if the bill is passed. I understand, from the briefing we had last week, that the minister is going to ensure that some funds are going to be available for that. We do have some questions in that area, but I am not going to raise them now.

It is not our intention to divide on either of the government's two amendments but we will be pressing—and probably pressing to a division—our amendment for the extension of the sunset clause. I just put that on the record to help people know where we are coming from. Whilst we are not voting on the reduction in fees, because that is a matter for the regulation rather than for the legislation—although it is very useful to know that information now—we are not in opposition with the intent of what the government is proposing in these two amendments. Nonetheless, irrespective of the passage of the government's amendments, we will be pressing ahead with a division on our amendment to extend the sunset provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of small questions about the amendments specifically before us which increase the protection period from 10 days to 30 days, which certainly Democrats are very much in favour of. My first question relates to item 32 in the bill—the item that these amendments relate to—which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The individual must publish in the prescribed way a notice . . .
I would like the government to clarify whether that notice is likely to be in a national newspaper or in a paper in the person's home state or something like that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I am advised, the requirement will be for a national and metropolitan major newspaper advertisement.

—Not wanting to labour the point but just reflecting my concern about the impact of this on the voluntary sector and the comments that Mr Hodges made in the committee hearings on this bill, because I understand that Mr Hodges is going to be involved in an ongoing way with these sorts of things. If he has an attitude that is so negative towards the voluntary sector, then that is a source of concern. I would appreciate some statement from Minister Vanstone that the government does not have a similar view to Mr Hodges about the quality of legal advice that is provided by the community legal sector.

—While Minister Vanstone is consulting her advisers, I want to make it clear to the committee that the Greens support these amendments because they ameliorate but do not remove the concerns that we have about the government's legislation. We will be supporting the opposition's amendments to delay the sunset application of the existing legislation—in other words, to shelter the community group interest. We think that the community group interest is extremely important in this area of social justice. It is a good in the community which should be ongoing, and we do not think that fees should be put in the way of that. We do not support the government's thrust in this legislation. We will be supporting the opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to Senator Bartlett's remarks, I am not privy to the remarks that you referred to and I have not had the opportunity to consult with Mr Ruddock, but I can say this much: that community legal centres generally provide a high level of quality advice. But just as Senator Cooney indicated there might be some private operators who are not as good as others, so that would be the case in the community legal centres. The community legal centres would not be immune from having the odd person who was not as good as the bulk of people providing the service. But the general view is that the community legal centres provide a high level of quality advice.

—If this legislation goes through, then the Joint Standing Committee on Migration will be able to examine the legislation for its effectiveness or otherwise. There will need to be some benchmarks or some facts against which we could consider the effectiveness or otherwise of the undertakings given by the government. I certainly would at some stage like to be provided with details of the actual figures of funding that have been provided to the voluntary sector, organisation by organisation, over the last two years and also with the projected figures. If they are not available at this point, then I am absolutely certain that the joint committee will be looking for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine will understand that I do not have those figures available to me at the moment, but I can give an undertaking that we will get them—the figures would be available fairly promptly for the past years. As I indicated to you earlier in the committee stage, negotiations are not yet complete for the current financial year, but it is expected that the two groups we are referring to would get roughly the same amount of money as they did in the previous year. Until that is finalised, we will not be able to give you those current figures.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

I am not going to speak for very long to these amendments. I think my speech in the second reading debate was all directed towards the effect and impact that these amendments, if they were carried, would have. To explain briefly, what we are proposing to do here is to extend a sunset clause provision in the Migration Act which would mean that on 21 or 20 March next year—that is three days after St Patrick's Day—the protective provisions contained in the bill would fail to operate any more and would expire. That is what the sunset clause means. What we are proposing is that that sunset clause be extended for a further two years so that, if the government agrees to it and our amendments are carried, there will be some form of protective system in place to protect those in our community who need the protection. Practically the whole of my speech in the second reading debate was directed to that. I will not belabour the Senate further now to follow it through.

I will just refer back to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. This was a year‐long inquiry by that joint committee. The persons who served on the committee were, indeed, distinguished and knowledgeable. The deputy chair of the committee was the shadow minister for immigration. We had Mr Clyde Holding, a former minister for immigration, on the committee. Mr Phillip Ruddock, who was a member of the committee, is now the minister. We also had Mr Ian Sinclair, the longest‐serving member of this parliament, a member of the other House. Ms Kathy Sullivan, a member of the other place, was also a member of the committee. I had the privilege of chairing the committee.

After the long and detailed deliberations on the scheme, in response to what the then minister said when the scheme was established, we conducted this 12‐month review. It was not something quick, cheap and nasty that happened overnight in order to bring forward a prearranged viewpoint. It was a considered report that was presented. We deliberated long and hard before the committee unanimously agreed to 49 separate recommendations to improve and enhance the protective measures that were contained in the migration agents registration scheme. It was unanimous. The current minister for immigration, who was a member of the committee, agreed to each and every one of the recommendations going forward.

Equally important to the presentation of the report was the fact that the then government responded to the report in a relatively quick period of time, as I said in the second reading debate, within six months of its presentation. The then minister, Senator Bolkus, agreed to the majority of the recommendations. He did not agree to each and every one of them. Some he agreed to were consequential and others were suggestions to be accepted in part with modification. The first recommendation that we made was accepted in full: that the arrangements should continue. He also agreed that there should be a review. Nothing is in place forever and ever and we accept that. Even in the argument today we have not dismissed that in the long term this industry might be self‐regulatory. We have not dismissed that at all; as indeed the joint standing committee, after its year‐long deliberation, did not dismiss it either.

The door is still open on that, but what is happening now is premature. The organisation for the regulation, control and policing of this industry is not, in our opinion, ready to undertake that role. It can be assisted with government funding, as indeed it has been, in order to do it, but at the moment it has not demonstrated that it can do it. It is doing very good work in the education and training area; there is no question about that. Together with VIARC and IARC it is doing this excellent work in preparing people. That is where I want to lead to in the questions that I want to direct to the minister at this point in time.

One of the things that we do accept in the bill is that it is improving the qualifications of people who can register within the scheme. At our briefing on Tuesday of last week, less than a week ago, we were told by senior officials of the department that government funds are going to be made available to the community sector in order to assist them to meet the standards for registration to provide migration advice. If the minister is in a position now to put on the record some of those commitments by the government, we would be pleased if he could do that. There were certain sums of money talked about last week. We did not agree from this side of the chamber. We thought perhaps there might be more money. But, at this point in time, it would be worth while for the minister to put that on the record and explain, perhaps in some brief detail because time is pressing, what the qualifications for registration and reregistration would be under the new provisions.

I ask those questions and I have clearly stated now and earlier in the debate that we will be pressing our amendment to extend the sunset provisions for a further two years. Nonetheless, if we press that amendment and it either is carried or falls, there will not be time to respond to these very important questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of other questions for the minister about the operation of the legislation before we vote on this clause. Again, they go to the issue of sunset clauses. As I have indicated before, it is an impossible situation for the Senate to be in. I have indicated before that the Democrats are supportive of the aim of Labor's amendments to extend the current scheme because we believe that is the best way to go. If the government is giving a cast‐iron indication that they are not going to support the extension of the sunset clause and would be willing to see the whole system of protection collapse rather than support it, then certainly I would like to have a clear indication from the government that that is their firm position. I find it an undesirable situation to be in, but that is the way of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to ask some questions which link to the current bill. I note in the explanatory memorandum and, to some extent, in the minister's second reading speech that features of the amendments to the Migration Act in this bill include a sunset provision on the statutory self‐regulatory scheme that is being introduced. Could I get an indication to make it clear—because I am not 100 per cent clear—what happens when we get to the end of that sunset period, assuming the bill goes through? Will we again be faced with a situation where the government can come back with a scheme that we are not happy with and where the alternative is, `Take it or end up with nothing?' Will that be revisited on us under the sunset provision in this bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last point you raised, there is often a debate amongst law reformers about the goodness or otherwise of sunset clauses because they force a relook at any situation, but all they really do is force parliament to reconsider what it wants to proceed with. Parliament has the choice of debating in the two chambers what the appropriate replacement is. While that can create a level of uncertainty, some would argue that the provision of such clauses gives parliament an opportunity rather than forcing it into a situation. The numbers will have changed in parliament by the time these clauses come up and parliament as it is then configured will decide what to do. I think that is appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point in respect of the opposition's amendments that if this bill is not passed we will lose an opportunity to strengthen consumer protection for what I think we are all agreed is a very vulnerable group in the community. There is an extension to sponsors, there is a universal knowledge qualification—a law degree or an existing course and test—and there will be mandatory professional development qualifications for reregistration. Failure to live up to that will result in deregistration. As to funding for training to enable volunteers to meet the knowledge test, I understand about $116,000 a year is to be available in relation to completing a prescribed course and test.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe I am divulging any secrets, but at the briefing last week we were talking, I think, about a range somewhat higher but not massively higher than that figure. The point was made—if not publicly, then in the briefings—that the Migration Institute of Australia can receive something like $380,000 to set up and run the scheme for the government. There are 442 registered agents in the voluntary sector. The government is prepared to give less than $120,000 to assist those people in their continued self‐development. It is not just a one‐off thing, although possibly it is the case that $116,000 is one‐off funding. But it is a very small amount of money and it has to be compared with the $380,000 worth of taxpayers' money that has been ceded to the Migration Institute of Australia to set up the scheme and later on run the scheme on behalf of the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bartlett, I missed the earlier part of your contribution because I was getting some advice to answer something that I think Senator McKiernan asked. If this is the question that I missed, I can make it clear that the government will not be supporting what the opposition is now proposing. We will not be extending the sunset clause; that is not the government's intention.

—I have one or two other questions for the minister in terms of this scheme as it goes ahead. As I understand it, the appropriateness of the MIA to be the body to undertake the supervision of this scheme came up in the Senate committee hearings. It seemed fairly clear, to me at least, from the evidence that was given that the MIA at this stage is not particularly representative of the broader industry. Are there any mechanisms the government is pursing to ensure the MIA does become more representative?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that MIA membership is open to a wide range of people involved in the industry who want to join. Under our system, if they want to be involved in the regulatory authority, they will join, so those who want involvement can have it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —On the Democrat position in relation to the ALP amendment, as we have indicated a number of times, we are supportive of what it is trying to achieve but, given the minister's indication that the government will not countenance extending the current scheme under any circumstances—and I understand that that is what you said, Minister—that puts the Senate in an impossible situation. In relation to sunset clauses, the minister outlined before that one of the potential benefits is providing the parliament with the opportunity to reconsider what it wants to proceed with.

SPEECH.PARA: The trouble is that, in doing this, we are in a situation where, without wanting necessarily to speak for Senator Harradine's view, we potentially end up with something that is quite clearly not what the Senate wants to proceed with. We are going to get what the government wants to proceed with. That is a different thing.

Nonetheless, it does ends up with a situation where we have basically got a Reservoir Dogs type stand‐off: everybody has his gun loaded, cocked and pointed and ready to go. Unfortunately, on this occasion, instead of having our guns pointed at each other and threatening to fire first, we have a situation where basically the people who are going to potentially end up getting shot are the most vulnerable people—those who are seeking migration advice. That is the situation that it appears we would end up with if the Senate insisted on the ALP amendment.

It is for those reasons that, whilst the Democrats are very supportive of that path and recognise that that path is closed by the government's refusal to open that door, we wish to make it clear that that is totally a decision of the government. Whilst we are very grateful that it has made some changes to ameliorate the impact of this legislation, we are still very concerned about the impact it will have.

In normal circumstances we would insist on this and go through the process of having it sent back to the House of Representatives for the government to restate formally that it will not accept that. While that may be a partly symbolic step, it is still an important symbolic step. Given the current circumstances that we find ourselves in, with this being the last sitting week and the need to focus as much attention as possible on the extremely crucial Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , the Democrats will not insist on going through that procedure this time around.

The government has indicated quite firmly that it would send the bill back here in any case, or else allow the whole scheme to fall over without having the bill reconsidered. Whilst that might be a game of bluff, in that sort of stand‐off situation, the Democrats are not willing to risk those who are seeking migration advice having basically no protection whatsoever. In that circumstance, the Democrats, being in the unusual situation of supporting what the amendment aims to do but fearing the risk of what it might end up achieving—having the whole scheme collapse—will be abstaining on this amendment if it is pressed to a division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very disappointed to hear what the Australian Democrats are going to do. While I respect your decision, it is a decision that you are going to have trouble rationalising to the community. I think you have given in far too easily. Let me reinforce that point.

SPEECH.PARA: As late as Tuesday of last week, from our side of negotiations, a $475 fee was going to be imposed on every individual registered as a migration agent in the voluntary sector—that is, a person who provides migration advice for no fee. As late as last Tuesday the fee was going to move from no charge to $475. In that short period, there has been a dramatic reduction in those levels—from $475 to $150 in the first year of registration.

There may be a game of bluff and counterbluff here. From the opposition's point of view, we gave very deep consideration to the impact of the moving of our amendment, understanding where the government is coming from. The government has been quite categorical that, if the bill did not go through and the sunset clause arose on 21 March next year, the regulatory system that we have in place would collapse.

We have had experience of being in government and we understand that you can get claims and counterclaims and bluff and counterbluff. I do not accept the analogy of guns pointed at heads. We are certainly not in that position. We have not been trying to get in that position. We are very strong in our position that a regulatory system must be in place to protect individuals who need immigration advice. We are very strong on that.

We are putting forward our amendment in the position that a regulatory system will remain in place for at least two years. If the government chooses not to have a regulatory system in place from 21 March next year, that will be the government's decision. If it decides that a regulatory system is not going to be put place, that will be its problem and it will have to live with the consequences if no regulatory system is in place to at least attempt to protect the vulnerable. The government will be responsible and accountable for that. We are proposing that, with the carriage of this amendment, a regulatory system will be in place.

Finally—and I am not trying to delay this—a number of references have been made to Mr Hodges and the South Brisbane Immigration and Community Legal Centre. If our amendment is defeated and the bill goes on to pass, I will be making a very short third reading statement in regard to that matter because I do not believe that that matter should be allowed to rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what Senator McKiernan has said and make a plea to Senator Bartlett to reconsider. It is not a situation where the government should be taken on face value. There will remain a government responsibility for ensuring that the migration advisory service is adequate and is proper. The opposition is saying, let us extend the current regulatory service for another two years. The problem with not taking that course is that suddenly there is a fee impost on the voluntary service given to people wanting migration advice around the country. That is going to create a great deal of pressure on that voluntary service and it is certainly going to weigh things in favour of non‐voluntary service in the community. The Greens do not think that is a good thing.

SPEECH.PARA: The government ought to be tested on this. I know there are backstop positions, but they are not as strong and they are not in the interests of the non‐government sector of the community in the way that the opposition amendments are. I join with the opposition in saying we should think again about this. Think again about the impact on the community sector. On this side of the chamber, we are trying to protect that community sector and the excellent service that they provide in the field of migration advice and to stop them being clobbered by the sudden imposition of fees, which, notwithstanding the fact that they have been reduced somewhat by recent pressure on the government, are still there as an impediment to the delivery of services as we know them. I reiterate that the Greens will be supporting the Labor Party's amendment because we believe it is in the interests of the community service being provided by the voluntary sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —We are in an impossible situation, as Senator Bartlett has indicated. In discussions between the government, Senator Bartlett and myself, the government has responded—it is not a question of blackmail or otherwise—to the persuasive arguments that were put to them on their merits. I give credit to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) because he was prepared to listen very carefully and to deal with those arguments on their merits. I give credit to Senator Bartlett and his staff who spent an enormous amount of time and energy on obtaining these beneficial results.

SPEECH.PARA: We are in an untenable position at the present moment. I am sure that the minister is not bluffing. The government's position is very clear. What will happen if we vote for the opposition amendment is that there will be created huge uncertainty in the area where there should be some degree of certainty. That is the reason that I am not going to support the opposition amendment. I hear what Senator McKiernan says—that he is going to call a division. As I am not going to support the amendment, I hope he will not mind my leaving the chamber to attend an extremely important meeting at half past 12 on another matter of burning interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly while Senator Harradine is here, we completely endorse your remarks, Senator Harradine. We will not always agree across different sides of the chamber and amongst the Independents and Democrats, but there has been a concerted effort to try to understand each other's points of view. Senator Harradine is not entirely happy. We might be happier if the charges were as we had originally planned. Senator Harradine and Senator Bartlett have been prepared to engage in discussion and come to a compromise.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems with a compromise is that often nobody is 100 per cent happy, but I do want to draw a distinction, Senator Brown. I do not know whether this relates to your office or to yourself, but I am advised that you were offered a brief on this matter and rejected that brief. You have, therefore, not been a party to these discussions and to come in at the eleventh hour and claim that you are trying to be the saviour of a particular group, when the parliamentary process, as it now stands, has offered you opportunities you have declined, I find somewhat unsatisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, if you consulted with the voluntary sector of the community on this as much as we do, you would be doing a better job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to prolong this but, Senator Brown, perhaps you have not understood the point that is being made. You can consult all you like with the voluntary sector. But if you do not do your job and bring the knowledge that you want to bring to parliament into the proper negotiations, and want to waltz in at the last minute, you must expect not to get a look‐in, as you would if you did your job properly.

—I have consulted with community groups through my office on this matter. I am very firm about the position I have taken. If the minister does not like that, she has to lump it. I am standing here because I believe that the opposition amendments are in the interests of the voluntary sector and migration advice. I will not be persuaded from either not standing here on that situation or not voting on this matter because the minister does not like the way the consultations have proceeded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I should make a response to the comments made since I was asked to consider the matter. I obviously take on board seriously what people are saying. I certainly do not want to criticise anybody's approach to this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the aim of the opposition amendments, as I said before, but they will leave us with a situation where the government, as it has stated, will not accept them, so we will therefore be in a situation where we will have no scheme in place. In his contribution, Senator Harradine referred to the fact that there are people in government who would be quite happy to have that situation occur. That is why I am quite strongly of the view that the government is not bluffing on this matter. I am not necessarily saying this about the current Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock), or his representative in this chamber, Senator Vanstone, but I am very sure a number of people in the government would be very happy to have no detection or regulation over migration agents at all in place. That is the situation we are faced with.

As I have said a number of times, we are in a no‐win situation, but that is the worst outcome, as I see it, and that is why the Australian Democrats are trying to obtain the least worst outcome. That is why we are dealing with it now rather than sending it back to the other place so that it can come back here for us to go through again. In normal circumstances we would do that but, as I said, due to the importance of the native title legislation, we will not press for that on this occasion.

Personally, it gives me a great deal of pain to be giving even the limited support I am giving to what the government is doing—that is, to be providing some reluctant support for a situation where the community sector is to be charged fees. It is a sector I personally have had a lot of involvement with—not so much in the migration area but with lots of community legal centres, and I know the impact it will have. The government may say it will not impact, but I know it will. Yes, it is not a situation that I or the Democrats are happy with, but I would not have agreed to come into the Senate if I could not wear a bit of pain. The situation is that it is the least worst outcome rather than there being no protection at all for those who are the most vulnerable.

As Senator McKiernan said, it is a situation the government will have to live with if the whole scheme is pulled down. The impact on the voluntary sector is also something the government will have to live with. But, if we have no scheme at all in place, it will not be just the government who will have to live with it but migrants and people seeking migration advice—some of the most vulnerable people in our community. The Democrats will not support a situation that will have a very high risk of people having to live with that outcome.

As I said before, I do not think a large number of people within the government will worry terribly much about having to live with that outcome, just as I do not think they will have a great deal of trouble living with the outcome of slugging the community sector. Either way, the government will have to live with it. This outcome is the least worst outcome, and that is the reason the Democrats are taking the position they are taking with these amendments.

That the amendments (Senator McKiernan's ) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two very brief comments on the third reading. The first one is the extraordinary situation and circumstance with the Australian Democrats. Until the debate started, we understood that they were supportive of the position of the opposition. They changed their mind during the debate and then chose not to vote at all on the division for the second reading. I find that extraordinary. I will say nothing further on that at this point.

SPEECH.PARA: The main reason I am speaking on the third reading is to make a plea. With the passage of this bill, the MIA will be put in charge of the Migration Agents Registration Authority. There is a very great onus upon Mr Brown, the President of the MIA, to now publicly apologise for the comments one of his national executive members, Mr John Hodges, made during the Senate committee deliberations. I am not going to labour the point, but the comments that were made were quite untrue, as it appears from the five‐page letter that was given to the committee. That has been attached to the report so the comments are on the public record. Those comments should be refuted.

It would be a measure of Mr Brown as president of the organisation, a measure of the MIA as an organisation of integrity, if it were to rule and police the integrity of the agents operating in this field, and a measure of the new body, MARA, the Migration Agents Registration Authority, if that apology were put on the public record. It is something that I very strongly believe should be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator McKiernan's comments, I wish to say that, as was indicated in previous debate on this bill, Mr Hodges's comments were something that concerned me greatly as well. I certainly support the call Senator McKiernan has made for action from the MIA. In relation to his other comments about the Australian Democrats, I simply say again that we made fairly clear the reasons why we took the position we did in relation to that. We were faced with a no‐win situation. The Democrats were not willing to risk a situation where the end product of all the bluff and counterbluff would have been no protection at all for the most vulnerable in our society.

PARA.EMPHASIS: House of Representatives reasons for disagreeing to Senate amendment No. 7—

PROCTEXT.PARA: The amendment proposes the insertion of a new Part IIF into the Taxation (Interest on Overpayments and Early Payments) Act 1983 , to provide for the payment of interest on overpayments of surcharge which result from a person's failure to provide a tax file number. The House of Representatives does not accept this amendment which would result in inconsistent consequences for the failure to quote a tax file number. In other legislation administered by the Commissioner of Taxation, interest is not applied to amended assessments after the quotation of a tax file number. The legislation already imposes significant requirements on the Commissioner to identify members of superannuation funds before issuing a surcharge assessment on the basis of non-quotation of a tax file number. In addition, the legislation provides that certain superannuation accounts are to be assessed at a nil rate of surcharge where a tax file number has not been quoted.
Motion (by Senator Kemp) proposed:
That the committee does not insist on amendment No. 7 made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats believe that the Senate should insist on this amendment. The amendment moved by the Senate was entirely reasonable. What it said was that if a person subsequently provides a tax file number and it is discovered by the tax office that that person should not have paid that surcharge, then the tax office should pay interest as well as return that surcharge.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate has long campaigned for interest to be paid on overcharged and subsequently refunded tax payments. It has been a very reluctant tax office that has ever so slowly started to concede that point in recent times. That the coalition has dropped its longstanding principle in support of interest on overpayment and run what is essentially the bureaucrats' line on this issue, particularly given the strong stance of Senator Kemp and others in the opposition, we think is very disappointing. The government wants to place the blame of the financial cost of its collection mechanism for the surcharge on the shoulders of ordinary taxpayers and we do not think that is acceptable.

The collecting mechanism utilising tax file numbers was not the preferred collecting mechanism. The entire collection of tax file numbers would have been unnecessary if the government had agreed to collect the tax through PAYE tax certificates as recommended by the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. It and its tax office advisers chose this tax mechanism. Therefore, in our view, it is the tax office which should wear the cost of that.

In evidence to the committee, Jacques Martin reported that as of a couple of weeks ago, despite three requests from its members, only 23 per cent had provided tax file numbers. The tax office now says that it is up to 40 per cent and it is confident that it will get to 65 per cent. That is okay, but even if we get to 65 per cent that means that the number of people who are still paying the surcharge when they do not need to will be seven to eight times the number who should be paying it—so 2.8 million instead of 350,000. That means a windfall gain to the tax office of up to $4 billion. That is simply unacceptable and we must do everything we can to ensure that millions of Australians are not paying more tax than they should be and we should develop policy that ensures that such an outcome is avoided if at all possible. I do not think this can be compared with the interest withholding tax situation. The interest withholding tax is an anti-avoidance provision and there is no other fairer way of collecting that tax.

There were better alternatives to the surcharge. Indeed, if the government's assurances that the efficiency of its data matching and its advertising campaign are to be believed, then no high income earners should be able to avoid the tax and no low income earner should be paying the tax. It really is the government's problem. The tax office should not reap the fiscal benefit from collecting tax off low income earners who should otherwise not pay. This amendment will provide a significant incentive to the tax office to accelerate its data matching to avoid the contingent cost of the surcharge. It is good policy and, in our view, it was wrong for the House to disagree with it. The Democrats will be voting against this motion and will be calling upon the Senate to insist on our amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not support the government's motion to reject this amendment, and we do not do that for several reasons. Firstly, the need for this amendment highlights the absurdity of the government's superannuation surcharge tax collection method. As a general proposition, this is a tax on a third party, on a superannuation fund, resulting from the actions of a superannuation fund member. In the situation where the member does not provide their tax file number to the fund, the tax office will levy the full amount of the surcharge tax—that is, 15 per cent of surchargeable contributions on the fund. That means that low and middle income earners who do not provide their tax file numbers to their superannuation fund will pay the full 15 per cent of the surcharge tax. I have to say, that is a terrible situation.

SPEECH.PARA: If the situation that I have described does occur, the member can subsequently provide their tax file number and the tax office may reassess the tax liability on the superannuation fund. This amendment is designed to bring some justice to that type of situation by ensuring the payment of interest on the amount that was wrongly collected. In the eyes of the opposition, that is a fair and reasonable thing to do. The refund should include interest on that amount which the tax office was holding unnecessarily as a result of the government's complex collection method. The money would have been earning interest had it stayed in the member's superannuation fund account, of course. That is my first reason for opposing the motion of the government.

Secondly, it is puzzling as to why the government does not accept this amendment, given that it is so confident that low and middle income earners will not pay the surcharge tax for the reason this amendment addresses. Senator Kemp told us when these bills were debated last week that:
. . . collection rates of tax file numbers are currently in line with expectations at this stage of the process . . .

I am not sure what Senator Kemp's expectations are, but that is contrary to the advice which some superannuation funds are giving, which is that only a small number of people are providing their tax file numbers. Even if we ignore that advice from the superannuation funds and take the government at its word, which is, of course, a risk, there is still a problem with the collection of tax file numbers.

Reportedly, there are six million individual taxpayers in Australia who are covered by superannuation. If the collection rate for tax file numbers is as high as 65 per cent, which is the figure given by the tax office, that leaves over 2.1 million people unaccounted for. The tax office assures us that it can locate another two‐thirds of those people who do not provide their tax file number, which leaves some 700,000 people unknown. That means some 700,000 people will pay the full rate of 15 per cent of surcharge tax regardless of their income level. Giving these people the opportunity to earn interest on their wrongly collected moneys is a fair and reasonable amendment.

Thirdly, the government claims that this amendment will be inconsistent with other legislation which determines the action the Australian tax office must take if a tax file number is not quoted. The inconsistencies in the government's surcharge tax legislation are legendary. There is the 15 per cent cap applying to some funds but not to others. There is the inconsistent collection method depending on what type of fund you are in. There are the allocated surplus amounts inconsistencies. There are the inconsistencies between defined benefit funds and accumula tion funds. The surcharge tax is inconsistent with any sense of fairness or reasonableness that can be applied. At least this amendment seeks to redress those inconsistencies.

The government also claims that there may be an incentive for someone not to provide their tax file number in the hope of receiving a nil assessment from the tax commissioner. I assume that the government is arguing that the incentive applies to high income earners and not to low income earners. According to the government, low and middle income earners will not pay the tax anyway. If they do, they can give their tax file number and get their money back with interest if this amendment is insisted upon. If a high income earner does not provide their tax file number, the tax office will be able to charge them the full rate and they will not receive any refund if they subsequently provide their tax file number. Therefore, there is no reason for the ATO to pay interest. I am not sure where the incentive not to provide your tax file number comes from, providing the tax office is doing its job properly, which we all assume it will be doing.

In those circumstances, with 700,000 taxpayers possibly caught in this net, the only conclusion one can come to is that the reason why the government will not support this amendment that was previously made by the Senate is that it is aware that it can make a windfall out of inadvertence. People, particularly low and middle income earners, who are not aware of or who have not had impressed upon them the need to provide their tax file number to avoid paying the 15 per cent surcharge tax will get caught. The government does not mind if they get caught because it will not ensure that the value of their money is adequately maintained by the payment of interest on money wrongly collected. It does not mind because it makes a windfall gain itself.

This is an insidious, hidden form of taxation which, because of the government's recalcitrance on this point, has to be laid at its door. It will be able to secretly collect a tax without people being aware of how they can adequately protect themselves against it. When they do wake up, they will not have the value of their money adequately maintained because the government will not pay interest on tax wrongly collected.

This is a mean‐spirited, narrow-minded approach by the government. It does reflect what many commentators these days describe as the attitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to these things—that is, mean, narrow and shifting the burden on to the battlers, whom the government sometimes pretends that it represents. If the government does represent the battlers, it will drop off on this amendment. If it does not represent them, it will pursue it. The fact that the government is pursuing this amendment leads inexorably to the conclusion that it does not care, and it is prepared to push this matter right to the limit and threaten the Senate with the prospect of using this bill as a trigger. That is an outrageous proposition, and I look forward to hearing from the minister some sort of ameliorating explanation, which I am sure he cannot provide.
Debate interrupted.
Progress reported.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Minister, will you acknowledge that several Australian citizens, including a warrant officer, have been murdered by rascal gangs in Port Moresby in recent years? Has the government been able to ascertain whether the videotape that purports to show PNG Prime Minister Skate boasting about his intimate connections with rascal gangs is genuine? What inquiries has the Australian government made on this matter, and what proposed course of action will the government take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly acknowledge that the rascal gang issue has been a serious problem for some time in PNG. Certainly, there have been deaths, but I would need to have confirmed that an Australian warrant officer was murdered by such a gang. We are of course aware of the allegations that have been made in the video that has been shown on Australian television and recognise that these are very serious matters. We do however believe that they are primarily matters for the government, the parliament and the people of PNG. We do not think it is appropriate for the Australian government to comment at this time.

ANSWER.PARA: As a matter of interest, I notice that a similar view was expressed by Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, this morning when he said that it was something the Papua New Guineans were going to have to work out. We know of the events that have flowed therefrom within PNG politics in the last 24 hours but, beyond that, the Australian government has not got anything further to add at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I did not raise the question to ask you to comment on internal PNG politics, but in opposition you and many others made points about the protection of Australian citizens overseas, so I ask you to comment on the point that there are several families in Australia whose lives have been destroyed by these particular elements, in Port Moresby in particular. If any evidence flows that there is any connection between those gangs and those anarchistic groups in Port Moresby, I simply ask what action this government will take on behalf of those families who lost relatives due to the activities of these gangs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no dispute that criminal activity associated with violence has been a difficult problem for PNG in recent years and that injuries and deaths have resulted therefrom. That is what I have just said. There is nothing new in that, unfortunately. As Senator Ray knows, the Australian government has given advice to Australian citizens from time to time in PNG about ways in which they could reduce the risk of being injured or worse as a result of these gangs. In fact, the Australian government in relation to its own officials has taken quite considerable precautions as I recall it—in particular, by building a particularly secure compound. So this has been an ongoing issue.

ANSWER.PARA: I might say that I also recognise that another way in which we have sought to assist has been in the training of the police force. That is something that was undertaken by the previous government and continues to be undertaken by our government.

If Senator Ray is asking whether, as a result of the allegations that have been made in the last 24 hours, there is any further action Australia should take in relation to those injuries or deaths, then I think that is premature. I think the correct step at the moment is to allow the PNG people, the parliament and the processes to take the course of action that is appropriate and, in the case of Australian citizens, to see that they are properly advised and, where necessary, properly protected from injury that can result from the behaviour of such gangs. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer the Assistant Treasurer to recent economic figures showing high growth in investment expectations, strong rises in skilled vacancy levels and continuing low inflation in addition to record low interest rates and record high home affordability. Isn't this proof yet again that the government's economic strategy is producing positive results? How will the economic measures put in place by the Howard government assist Australia in withstanding the economic instability in Asia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coonan for that important question which I believe is of great interest to most Australians, probably with the exception of the Australian Labor Party. Today I received a copy of the National Survey of Business Expectations produced by the ACCI. I will quote from this survey, which I think will be of interest to senators. Under the heading `Australian economic performance', it says:

ANSWER.PARA: The results of ACCI's National Survey of Business Expectations for the December quarter 1997 show an unmistakable pick up in economic activity. There are positive results for general business conditions, sales revenue, exports, employment and investment in plant and equipment recorded for the quarter just past. These are clear signs that the economy is in the early stages of recovery.
The survey goes on to stress:

Importantly, both actual and expected investment continue to be positive. Moreover, and as on the last occasion, the strong investment performance is found in firms of every size although the data also show that the larger the firm, the more positive investment expectations are.

That is a recent survey which has been put out by the ACCI. The government is very pleased that the indicators continue to show strong growth in the economy. Many senators will be aware that the private new capital expenditure figures released last Thursday show that business expects very strong investment over the next year consistent with the budget forecast of eight per cent growth.

BREAK.PARA: The expectations for equipment investment for 1997-98 are over 12 per cent higher than the equivalent estimate for 1996-97. This is a very good sign of the extremely positive outlook for business investment in this country. As I said, it is very good news for Australia. There is a whole range of other figures which confirm this series of improving conditions in the economy. It is no wonder that we are starting to see a lift.

Inflation is very low so that people's savings are not being eaten away and workers do not need high wage increases to maintain their standard of living. The headline CPI fell 0.3 per cent over the year to September, reflecting the very big falls in home mortgage rates that this government has been able to achieve. The government's strategy is producing the goods. Home mortgage rates are the lowest since the late 1960s and rates available to small business are the lowest in possibly a quarter of a century. That is the positive proof that this government is delivering for families and delivering for business.

The responsible budgetary policies of this government in taking the pressure off interest rates allow the private sector to expand and create jobs and wealth. There is no doubt that, in putting the economy on a sound footing, the government has put Australia in a hugely better position to withstand the vagaries of global economic influences like the turmoil affecting economies of countries in Asia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Gibbs for the question. Yes, I did see that comment of Mr Marek and I have spoken to Mr Marek about it. Mr Marek explained to me the context in which those remarks were made and, as is usual, the comments were taken out of context.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not my place to reprimand anybody. I would take equal offence at Mr Noel Pearson's remark about people being racist scum. I ask you, Senator Gibbs, whether you support that statement by Mr Noel Pearson or, as in today's press, where Mr Noel Pearson said that the Prime Minister had the morality of a cockroach.
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—The point I was making is that it is a free country and people get reported out of context. I do not believe everything I read in the papers. Parliamentarians have the right to say what they do. Whether it is reported correctly or not is another matter.

ANSWER.PARA: I can assure Senator Gibbs that Mr Marek is a good representative for the area from which he comes. He is a very good National Party member for that area. He is still, I believe, a member of the trade union movement. He has worked his way up. He is very close to the issues within his own electorate. He is a very worthy representative for Capricornia.

Mr Marek comes from a different background from the union organisers over there who have never had a decent job in their lives, but who have been union representatives. He has got out and worked.
