—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. The government has a number of initiatives to address the high youth unemployment and the long‐term unemployment left by the former Labor government. Will the minister inform the Senate of the initiatives to assist up to 65,000 job seekers, to provide more individualised service to the individual job seeker and to involve the private sector? How will these changes improve assistance for job seekers and employers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for this most important question. Today marks one of the most significant reforms in 50 years in relation to improving services for job seekers. Commonwealth funding of $16.2 million has been contracted out to more than 300 private and community agencies to find jobs for up to 65,000 unemployed people. These agencies will compete with the CES, which today is being managed by the government owned employment placement enterprise. To mark this changeover and the new services for job seekers and employers, the government owned company was launched yesterday under its new name: Employment National Ltd. The new arrangements are part of a transition to the contracting out of $1.7 billion to private, community and public employment agencies from 1 May next year.

ANSWER.PARA: The improved services will provide significant benefits to job seekers, employers and taxpayers. Put simply, the new services will ensure more unemployed people get jobs. From today, private job placement agencies will be paid a fee when, and only when, an unemployed person is placed in a job. The focus on jobs will continue from 1 May next year, when providers will only be paid their full major fees after an unemployed person has been placed in a job for 26 weeks. Incentives will also be targeted to the most needy job seekers, with long‐term unemployed and other disadvantaged groups attracting the highest placement fees.

BREAK.PARA: These changes will be a welcome relief for taxpayers as they see government funds being used to place unemployed people in real jobs. Job seekers will no longer be put on short‐term training merry‐go‐rounds. Funds will not be wasted as they were under Labor, which threw away hundreds of millions of dollars on schemes that simply led nowhere. Job seekers and employers will benefit from a wider range, a wider choice, of expert employment agencies providing flexible assistance tailored to their individual placement needs. There will be an increased share of job vacancies open to unemployed people. This is because the new expert service providers will have greater access to job vacancies—many more than the 20 per cent of jobs currently available through the CES.

The changes mean that the government can now make a number of firm commitments to job seekers, employers and the community. Firstly, a commitment will be that unemployed people will get jobs. Secondly, job seekers will not be churned through short‐term training programs that simply lead nowhere. Thirdly, assistance will be tailored to job seekers' and employers' individual needs. Job seekers will no longer be forced into inflexible bureaucratic programs that do not help them get jobs. Finally, under this coalition government, taxpayer dollars will never again be wasted on schemes that can cost up to $143,000 per net job outcome.

These commitments should be measured against the commitment of the Labor Party. The only commitment they have offered is that they are going to return to Working Nation and that, as we know, is in sharp contrast to what we are offering today. We want unemployed people to get jobs, but the opposition want to bring back the $10 billion deficit and Working Nation, which simply did not work.

This government has vigorously pursued a comprehensive plan to tackle unemployment. It has done this by repairing Australia's fiscal position, which places it in a strong environment despite the current South‐East Asian situation. It has reformed Australia's education and training systems. It has reformed the delivery of labour market assistance. It is focused on removing restrictions on business growth and development, especially for smaller business. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. Minister, is it true that former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser has signed an open letter expressing concern that the government's handling of the native title debate has `a great potential to create division both within the Australian community and between Australia and our neighbours'?

QUESTION.PARA: Is it true that former Liberal Aboriginal affairs minister Ian Viner has stated, `This is a disaster for the nation, to have a government so deliberately prepared to divide the community on a racial issue'? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The only people who are scaremongering are the Labor Party. They are raising the racist attitude in this debate. Nobody else has, and none of those people that Senator Collins has mentioned have used that word. They have reported concerns, as they are entitled to do as private citizens. They are private citizens of this country and private citizens can report their concerns.

ANSWER.PARA: I think what is more important is what we are doing for Aboriginal people in this country in relation to health, housing, education and employment. They are the real issues. Senator Collins, one Aboriginal leader said to me, `We can't eat native title.' I think that is important to recognise. They are concerned about the day‐to‐day issues of how they get by living in this land.

Those people are extremely grateful, as we saw on the 7.30 Report the other night, Senator Collins. The people of Bulla and Oak Valley are particularly grateful for what is being done for them. Senator Bolkus interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bolkus, cease interjecting.

—Senator Collins of all people, because of his association with Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory, recognises the great defects. ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

—I apologise for getting upset about this but I do get upset when I go to these communities. TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I will have to have an education program on those critics so that I can bring them up to date on what is occurring at the moment.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. I note that last weekend's edition of the Australian Financial Review obtained an internal memo from the National Association of Forest Industries that labelled the government's national greenhouse response strategy as `mickey mouse'. I also note that the Australian Gas Association, in its comments on the government's national greenhouse strategy, stated that it `believes that the document fails to address the prerequisites for an effective Australian greenhouse response'. Doesn't the emerging unease or disinterest on behalf of business and the opposition in the community suggest that you will be attending Kyoto not as a representative of the Australian people but as a taxpayer funded lobbyist for the coal industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I did notice today's media release of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. I will just read a couple of paragraphs from it:

ANSWER.PARA: The package of policies announced by the Prime Minister confirms that Australia will be more than pulling its weight in abatement efforts relative to other countries.

The Prime Minister, in taking this argument to Kyoto, is defending all Australians against the unacceptable demands of other nations. He is arguing that the aim should be equality of economic sacrifice not equality in target emission reductions. It is a position that all Australians should support.

As a broad based representative of Australian industries, I think the ACCI puts the position fairly and well. We are putting a position in Kyoto that will enable Australia to more than pull its weight. Unlike most other parties in the negotiation, we will implement the commitments that were part of the Prime Minister's recently announced $180 million statement, come what may. We will do this because we believe they are good domestic policy and they will have a significant effect on reducing domestic greenhouse gases.

As I have said many times in this place before, we do want to be part of a good outcome in Kyoto where we pull our weight and we contribute to an ultimate stabilisation of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. Our complaint that Senator Lees has had trouble in understanding is that we can see no reason why Australia should take an unfair share of the burden, particularly when abatement costs in Australia are higher than those of practically any other party in this negotiation. In other words, the economic cost on a uniform reduction will be greater for Australia than for another party. Or, put yet another way, the cost in Australian jobs will be greater for Australia than for other parties in this negotiation.

The Australian government is interested in protecting Australian jobs. As a result of the recent statement, we have gone beyond no regrets for the first time. We are prepared to take economic sacrifice to contribute to a better global greenhouse outcome, but it has to be a fair share of the burden—or an equali ty of sacrifice, as has been said. We believe, on the best advice that we can get, that the initiatives that have been announced in the statement will mean that Australia is accepting an equality of sacrifice as compared with the United States and the European Union.

Therefore, the position we have put down is not only environmentally sound but also economically sound. If you can get a win-win situation of protecting Australian jobs whilst contributing to a better global environment, I would have thought that is something even Senator Lees ought to applaud.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it not correct that your stance is so weak, and perceived so by Australian business, to the point that 53 per cent of businesses in a recent survey said they had no plans to do anything about greenhouse gas emissions whatsoever? Are you aware that 67 per cent of coalition voters—your own voters—now say that you are not doing enough? Isn't it the case, as far as negotiations in Kyoto are concerned, that `they are looking pretty dicky at the moment'? They are your words, Minister, from the weekend Australian Financial Review .

—It is hard to get through, but the issue is that it costs Australia more. The abatement costs to Australia are higher. That is why it is easier for other parties in the negotiation than for Australia. In actual fact, the initiatives announced by the Prime Minister went beyond those of a number of other countries in terms of regulation, in terms of demanding new standards of emission for the car industry, new standards of emission for energy power authorities, new standards for building codes in relation to both domestic and commercial activity. I did not see these initiatives in President Clinton's statement. This government is going well beyond anything any Australian government has done in the past to ensure that we are providing a good environmental outcome; that we are contributing our fair share of the weight.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask about the multilateral agreement on investment currently being negotiated by OECD nations, including Australia, in Europe. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Brown, for the question. The OECD ministers have established a negotiating group, I understand, on the multilateral agreement on investment, the MAI, that you referred to, with a view to developing an international investment instrument which could provide a constitution for a global economy by encouraging further liberalisation of international capital flows. ANSWER.PARA: Senator Brown, in relation to the specific question you raised—the impact of the MAI on our foreign investment policy—Australia has flagged its concerns in its negotiations that any MAI must ensure that Australia can maintain its foreign investment review process and take account of the division established by Australia's constitution between the powers of the Commonwealth and the states. I think that covers the point that you were asking. I think you wanted a further briefing, did you, for the Senate or for yourself? —My question goes to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, are you aware that bike rallies right around Australia yesterday demonstrated dissatisfaction with the government's position on greenhouse? Are you aware that last week the Australian Local Government Association said that, with positive efforts by all levels of government, Australia can achieve a significant reduction in emissions by the year 2010, at least to 1990 levels and probably better? Minister, are you aware that the Waverley Council in New South Wales, for instance, has committed to sourcing 25 per cent of their electricity requirements from renewable energy? Are you aware that the ACT govern ment has committed to a 30 per cent decrease in 1990 levels by the year 2018? Minister, when other governments in Australia are taking greenhouse seriously, why is your government so insistent that we should actually increase emission levels by 18 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1992, the Australian government—a Labor government—signed up to stabilise Australian emission rates at 1990 levels by the year 2000. In the midst of the worst recession since the Great Depression, our emission levels continued to rise. That demonstrates how difficult it is to restrain emission growth in Australia. Even at times of major economic difficulty, major recession, emissions still rise.

ANSWER.PARA: Why do they continue to rise? Firstly, because of the growing population in Australia and secondly because the profile of our economy differs significantly from that of most others within the Kyoto negotiations. We are much more energy dependent in terms of our GNP, both in terms of energy production direct and energy intensive production. The combination of both of those—an examination of our economic profile and an examination of the population growth—demonstrates how difficult it is for us.

It may not interest the Australian Democrats but, between 1990 and the year 2020, our population is expected to grow by about 30 per cent, whereas the European Union population is expected to grow by 1.7 per cent. They have a stable population, ours will increase by 30 per cent, and yet the Australian Democrats say that we should be doing as well as the European Union in its pledge.

It is another way of saying the same thing. What they are arguing is that we should be accepting a much greater economic sacrifice than other parties. That is what we are not prepared to do; but we are prepared to make reasonable efforts to reduce our emissions. The package brought down by the Prime Minister in the week before last is evidence of that.

That package will significantly reduce emissions across a whole range of areas on both the sources and sink side. It will reduce emissions direct and it will increase the scope of sources to absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, thus having the same effect. It is the equivalent in sacrifice to that position put down by most of the other key negotiators.

It is easy for a particular local or state government to come out and say, `We will do better.' If they can, I welcome it. In fact, we are working with the Local Government Association to help local government contribute to a better national bottom line. As the Democrats may be aware, we were initiating a program—the cities for climate change in Australia—in which we were embracing some 30 councils to contribute better.

That will be done through an education program. They will have to keep a record of emissions, look for ways of abatement, and then keep a record of performance. We have now expanded that very significantly—some sixtyfold in expenditure—and we are putting in $13 million to build that number up to 300 councils Australia‐wide. In terms of their own emissions and their capacity to influence the behaviour of their ratepayers, local councils can play a significant role and help us contribute to a better national outcome. We will work with state and local governments that want to contribute to better outcomes and we will achieve that goal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank you for your answer, Minister, but the point of the question was to show that the federal government is out of step with both the community and other levels of government. I remind you that the federal government took money out of the better cities program and the ERDC programs, so the money which is going back in is not even going close to filling that gap. I bring you back to the question of local government. Are you aware that the Mayor of Waverley said that, even though the Prime Minister is out of touch on the problem of greenhouse emissions, the community has demonstrated that air quality is the No. 1 pollution concern. I ask you again, Minister: do you agree that your government is out of touch on this issue? Why is your government incapable of showing leadership when there is such strong support for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, even from 67 per cent of your own voters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The air quality survey is an entirely different issue but, be that as it may, I welcome the fact that some local governments are prepared to constructively work for better outcomes and to encourage those over which they have influence to work for better outcomes, because part of the message must be that everyone can make a difference. There is too much in this greenhouse debate of people blaming others when they can do something about contributing to better outcomes themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: The other thing that is important—and the Democrats have not adapted—is to get past the Rio days of thinking of a number and doubling it. There is no point standing up there and saying, `I will achieve a certain target,' unless you are prepared to implement policies and measures to achieve that outcome. The way we have approached this negotiation is more responsible. We have said what we believe can be achieved by demonstrating that we will take the policies and measures to achieve that outcome. If all the world did that, you would end up with a better figure rather than simply these loud statements of goals. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. With Australia's effort on HIV‐AIDS being commended by bodies such as the United Nations and the World Health Organisation, will the minister outline to the Senate the significance that today, World AIDS Day, has to the people of Australia and the work the government is doing in research, treatment and education programs which will ensure that the low rate of incidence of HIV‐AIDS in this country continues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Payne for the question. Yes, today is World AIDS Day. Australia has a very good record in relation to the containment of the epidemic that has afflicted the world. First and foremost, many people in Australia would want to commemorate and remember the loss of friends, relatives and loved ones to HIV‐AIDS. Many events happening across Australia in cities and in small country towns are allowing people to do this. AIDS Awareness Week and World AIDS Day involve a range of events including fetes, memorial services, information stalls, sale of red ribbons and other community activities.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Brendan Nelson, on behalf of Dr Wooldridge, today officially launched World AIDS Day in the Great Hall with the assistance of the Aboriginal dance group Heat Works. He will also launch a photographic display featuring photographs of prominent Australians and their messages about HIV‐AIDS.

The Australian response to the HIV‐AIDS epidemic is acknowledged as one of the best in the world and is often characterised by enlightened pragmatism. In Australia, we can take some pride in the success we have achieved in containing the HIV‐AIDS epidemic. Australia has recorded 20,706 HIV infections. We have moved from a peak infection rate of approximately 3,000 in 1983 to about 500 new infections annually. Deaths from AIDS have now dropped to an all‐time low since notification commenced. The cornerstone of Australia's response to HIV‐AIDS has been a partnership forged in the early days of the epidemic between the affected communities, government at all levels and medical, scientific and health care profession als. It was bipartisan. It is, however, important for HIV‐AIDS awareness to be maintained and improved in light of the absence of a vaccine or cure and continued discrimination.

A meeting of the parliamentary liaison group held only last week reaffirmed our non‐partisan approach to Australia's response to HIV‐AIDS. At the same time, we need to recognise that Australia is part of a world‐wide epidemic in which children are major casualties. That is why we have this year adopted the United Nations theme `Give children hope in a world with AIDS'. Every day, 1,000 children around the world become infected with HIV and 350,000 children died from AIDS in 1996. More than nine million have lost their mothers to AIDS, and that is particularly so on the continent of Africa.

Given the global nature of the epidemic and its impact on Australia, the government is committed to building on past successes and improving current responses. In order to sustain the low rate of incidence of HIV‐AIDS, the government, in partnership with the appropriate community and government agencies, is responding in a number of areas. Each year, over $2 million is spent at the federal level on national education initiatives for those at risk of or affected by HIV‐AIDS. This activity is complemented at state and territory level by locally targeted education activity. Our education activity focuses on those groups identified in the third national HIV‐AIDS strategy as being at increased risk of infection: homosexually active men, injecting drug users and the indigenous community, where there is also potential risk.

There have been many recent media reports of the possibility of a vaccine and cure for HIV‐AIDS. Initial media reports falsely implied that the advances in new combination therapies in the treatment of HIV‐AIDS may cure a person of the disease and end the epidemic. Combination therapies have been shown to increase the lifespan and improve the health status of people with HIV who are receptive to the therapies. However, to date there is no scientific evidence that HIV can be completely eradicated from the body through combination therapies. Therefore, at this point in time the aim of combination treatments is to offer a long‐term suppression of the HIV virus in an infected person. An indication of the success of combination therapies is a reduction in an individual's HIV viral load.

The minister has approved interim funding from 19 May 1997 of test kits for HIV viral load testing used in the management and care of people with HIV‐AIDS and the Department of Health and Family Services is currently developing ongoing arrangements for the funding of viral load testing to take effect early next year. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the minister's reference to the importance of the partnership between government and community emphasised in the third national strategy on HIV‐AIDS and also the importance of this year's theme for World AIDS Day, `Give children hope in a world with AIDS'. Can the minister advise the Senate of any further important steps taken by the government in combating the pandemic?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Payne for her supplementary question. Yes, one of the most important aspects is our research. Our national research centres cover social research, virology and epidemiology of HIV‐AIDS and are highly regarded internationally. In order to ensure that this high standard continues, the work and role of the national centres is currently being reviewed. I am expecting a report on that from the department in the near future.

ANSWER.PARA: For the 1998 calendar year, the government has committed $1.2 million to funding 11 new AIDS research projects, five new research fellowships and seven new research scholarships. Research topics include studies on HIV‐AIDS, sexually transmitted diseases, injecting drug users, hepatitis C, basic virology and cultural and behavioural studies.

In the seven years that Minister Wooldridge has been involved in indigenous health issues, the potential risk of HIV and developing effective strategies to contain it have been matters of concern to him as they have for every member of both chambers of the parliament because, as Senator Payne said, it is a pandemic that we cannot relax on despite the fact that there are only 500 cases per year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, my question without notice is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Minister, will you be honouring Dr Kemp's threat to withhold targeted assistance grants to public schools in states where the minister for education in that state does not agree with Dr Kemp's arbitrary literacy benchmarks? Do you acknowledge that the Victorian education minister, Mr Gude, has described Dr Kemp's benchmarks as being of questionable validity and reliability and as being half‐baked, imprecise and flawed? What action will you take if states' ministers do not sign off on Dr Kemp's contentious benchmarks at the 11 December education ministers' meeting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam President, and I thank Senator Carr for that question. As everyone knows, this is a matter of great importance to this government. Of course, the opposition adopted that policy when it put it in its own policy on education and said that literacy was most important for children in their early years. It took it straight from the government. In relation to that question, Senator Carr, I am not aware of any threat by Minister Kemp in relation to withholding any funding as you mentioned and, as you well know, he answered that question in the other place just a few moments ago.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to literacy, we have agreed with all states and territories on a national literacy and numeracy plan, and that was back in March this year. There has been a great deal of progress since then with state and territory governments, and we plan to progress that further at the ministerial council next week. We look forward to advancing that so that we will have national benchmarks in place for children at the end of years three and five.

I can tell you, Senator Carr, through the chair, that officials from both the Commonwealth government and state and territory governments have been working towards an agreement on this. In relation to your comments regarding Minister Gude, I am aware of his reaffirmation of support for a national literacy benchmark and implementing the goals of a national benchmark accordingly. As to his comments in relation to the implementation or validation of that, that is something we will work out next week when we progress this further.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I ask a supplementary question. The Melbourne Age of Saturday 29 November reiterates Dr Kemp's threat to withdraw funding from states which do not sign off on these benchmarks on 11 December. Are you not aware of that report? Are you not aware of the letter sent on 27 November 1997 to yourself from Mr Gude which indicates that Victoria will not be signing off on those benchmarks? What action will you be taking with states that refuse to sign off on your arbitrary benchmarks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was more the Age that was making the threat than anyone else, Senator Carr. I think you do not want to believe everything you read in the newspaper. Can I say that Minister Gude has raised a number of concerns with me which we will be looking at closely over ensuing days, and we hope to come to a resolution at the ministerial council next week. If you recall, you predicted all sorts of failure and mayhem for the ANTA ministerial council, but we resolved matters at that one and I am sure we will do the same again.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, on 24 November Senator Cook asked me a question concerning Australia's participation in the IMF assistance packages for Indonesia and Thailand. I seek to have the response incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows—

In the case of Indonesia, Australia has agreed to provide up to $US 1 billion in the form of `supplemental financing' which would remain conditional on adherence to the IMF program. Australia's assistance would only be drawn down after recourse to IMF financing and would be repaid once the program ended. There have been no drawdowns of this amount.

Under the agreement with Thailand, Australia's assistance is firmly linked to the IMF program and disbursements under the Reserve Bank swap are conditional upon the Thai authorities meeting the IMF's conditions.

The first tranche of Australia's assistance ($US 414 million), was provided in September 1997. A second tranche is expected to be provided shortly, in parallel with the next payment by the IMF, subject to approval by the IMF's Executive Board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), to questions without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to nursing homes.

What we have, I think, through the media exposure of Minister Smith's letter to Mr Howard is a unique insight into how the Howard government does business. It really again demonstrates the hopeless mire that this government has managed to immerse itself in in nursing home policy.

It is a letter from a very desperate minister to an incompetent Prime Minister. It really does show, quite clearly, that there has been another secret increase in the annual nursing home up-front fee. Until he was exposed in the media today by three press articles, Mr Warwick Smith had absolutely no intention of making his ministerial statement on the government's plans for elderly Australians—none whatsoever. It is just another example of this government's failure to honour due process and its total inability to accept the forms and conventions of good government.

On 5 November we had the Prime Minister appear on national television to announce the government's nursing home policy—a wholesale backflip, as senators would recall. He stated at that time that the annual payment for nursing home fees would be $4,000. This was announced on television without the benefit of any cabinet consideration and without the benefit of a cabinet committee looking at the proposal. There was no departmental submission or involvement in Mr Howard's proposals and no adherence to the watered down 10-day rule, the five-day rule of the Howard government. It was just pandemonium and panic.

On 7 November Mr Smith indicated at a doorstop that the fee would be $4,380, as I mentioned in question time today. On 13 November the same minister said he would make a ministerial statement in parliament on 17 November, the same day, as we now know, as cabinet met to overturn his announced position that the fee would be $4,380 per annum. Now we have a leaked letter outlining that cabinet decision that was made on 17 November and which set the annual fee at $5,500. That is a rise of about $1,500 in 12 days. I think that is a pretty substantial amount for any elderly Australian.

We know that on 17 November the matter was dealt with below the line. Again, we know that there was no formal cabinet submission and that there was no benefit of departmental advice on this matter. Again, the five‐day rule was not adhered to. In fact, the whole thing smacks of a cover‐up. Today we know that Mr Smith has written to Mr Howard. He made it absolutely clear. He said, `Let's not get this out in the public arena. We'll settle the remaining issues progressively without reopening the issue in the media.' He said he wanted to avoid making a ministerial statement in the House, but, unfortunately for Mr Smith, he has been forced into it today because he has been exposed in the media. He has been exposed. He has no choice but to come into the parliament and make a statement—or we think it is going to be in the parliament even though it is not on the order of business for the House of Representatives. It is just another panic move, just another example of decision making on the run and just another example of poor cabinet process from this government.

Again, today Mr Smith wrote a letter saying, `Oh, Prime Minister, please waive the five‐day rule of cabinet accordingly and deal with this matter,' in order to try to cover up the aged care shemozzle that the Howard government has been responsible for. What can Minister Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, do in this place? All he can do is blame the public servants for leaking the letter. What we have exposed again today is extraordinarily poor process, another cover‐up and another example of the Howard government not honouring commitments they made to elderly Australians. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that the Labor Party is back to its old tricks of stirring up fear and creating confusion and worry in the minds of the elderly people of this country over the nursing home issue. I think it is fascinating that Senator Faulkner, who sits over there as the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, seems to think he has access to confidential cabinet information and comes in here and quotes it as though it was a fact, having apparently read today in the Melbourne Age a suggestion that a letter might have been written.

SPEECH.PARA: I would not believe anything very much that is written in the papers. We all know that the journalists sitting up there have to earn a living. They are not even interested in this debate because they know that the Labor Party is raising red herrings and that there is absolutely no substance whatsoever in this issue that the Labor Party is raising today. For Senator Faulkner to put his credibility on the line by believing something which was reported in the Melbourne Age as a possibility is a pretty sad state of affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Financial Review and the Sydney Morning Herald .

—Even if it was in the Sydney Morning Herald , these journalists really are scratching to come up with a story like that. The fact is that we all have to come back to the realities of the situation. The realities of the situation are that, in Australia, we have an ageing population. In the next 25 years the number of people over 65 is going to increase by some 48 per cent. That is a huge problem that we have to deal with.

SPEECH.PARA: The other reality we have to deal with is the fact that nursing homes in Australia are of very poor quality. They are of very poor quality because the Labor Party in 13 years of government let them degenerate into the appalling state that they are in today. Something like 40 per cent of the residents of nursing homes share a bedroom with four or more people, 13 per cent of nursing homes do not meet fire regulations and 11 per cent of nursing homes do not meet health regulations. These are realities which the Labor Party government did not deal with but the present federal government is determined to deal with.

We have introduced a program—copied, I might say, from the Labor Party—to improve the standard of nursing homes. The original proposal was that accommodation bonds be paid. Because that seemed to be causing a certain amount of problem in the community, that policy has been changed. The fact remains that, to achieve improvements in nursing homes, a certain amount of money has to be generated. The government has come up with a very reasonable proposal, which perhaps needs a bit of finetuning, but that is occurring. The purpose of this is to improve the standard of nursing homes.

We have to look at Labor's record in nursing homes. The reality is that Labor cut funding for capital expenditure for nursing homes in a very substantial way. In 1992‐93, $45 billion was available to nursing homes for capital purposes. Under the Keating government, by 1995-96 this had dropped to $10.7 million—a 75 per cent reduction in the amount of capital available for improvement in nursing homes. Even though the Labor Party was very much aware, we must understand, of the appalling conditions in the nursing homes of Australia they actually cut funding by 75 per cent. The then Minister for Finance, who was ultimately responsible for that decision, was none other than Kim Beazley, the great and glorious leader of the Labor Party today who, one must presume, is behind all the stirring up that has been going on and the fear and scaremongering which the Labor Party is seeking to engender in the elderly people of Australia.

The Labor Party left the community without enough funding for nursing homes and this government has come up with some very reasonable policies to ensure that there is adequate funding for nursing homes. I think that that exposes, as nothing else could, the hypocrisy of the claims made by the Labor Party today. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it little wonder that Senator Eggleston can give no credence to the authen ticity of a document that the Minister for Family Services, Mr Smith, wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). I believe Senator Eggleston because who would want to believe what is in this letter and the sneaky, opportunistic way in which it is written.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have is a government professing transparency and honesty in every set of public platitudes they issue, but behind the scenes they write letters like this saying, `We're going to cover up. We're not going to tell the truth. We're going to try to sleaze our way through what has been a very difficult political issue for us.'

I think the first breakdown in this government occurred when they abolished the 10‐day rule for cabinet submissions, which was always there so all cabinet ministers would have notice of the issues coming up and be able to give them due consideration. This government cut that rule from 10 days to five.

What do we have in this instance? The five‐day rule has not been applied. The matter was bought under the line in cabinet—that is, without a formal circulation of a submission and without the considered views of the Department of Health and Family Services. You can ambush the rest of the ministers and send a letter around, which was copied by the way, to only the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), the Treasurer (Mr Costello), the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott). When the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, blames public servants for leaking this particular Smith letter to the Prime Minister maybe they should put the Federal Police onto those four ministers first just to make sure that they were not the ones who leaked the letter.

What we are seeing here is an absolute replica of what happened a month ago. When the Prime Minister went on A Current Affair to announce enormous nursing home changes, what were all the officials of the Department of Health and Family Services doing at 6.30 at night? They were sitting in front of their televisions with their notebooks and pens out seeking guidance on the new policy because this was the very first time they had heard anything about this change in policy.

Not only has this government got rid of the five‐day rule by going under the line, they have completely revamped the way cabinet submissions are put in. I will tell you why. Cabinet submissions have been traditional over the years. They are meant to be concise. They are meant to have restrictions as to their wordiness, but the full explanation as to what is behind a cabinet submission is put in the attachments. Sometimes you might get attachment C through to J. I am certain Senator Bob Collins has seen them through to attachment R. All the things at the back of the submission explain the details of the submission and contain views of other departments.

What has this government done? It has scrapped that. They still exist, but they do not circulate them. They are paranoid about leaking but even more concerned about the complexity that will stress ministers like Senator Herron who do not have the competence to go through them. What they do with all those attachments is lodge them in the cabinet office. That is the office that got expelled from Prime Minister and Cabinet over a turf war because they would not pay rent. They are now down in this building.

If you want to access those particular attachments you go and read them down there, which is, I suppose, fair enough. Guess who has the loneliest job in the world? It is the guardian of the attachments. He sits down there day after day expecting some forlorn minister to come down and actually read these detailed cabinet submissions. No appearance your honour. No‐one in this intellectual government, no‐one in this government that wants to consider policy in detail, goes down there. Next they will have comics and pictures in their cabinet submissions. They are not interested in looking at the detail.

Hence Mr Smith raises these issues under the line. Hence Mr Smith says that it will be vital to avoid re‐ignition of the issue in the media. What they intended to do was to sneak their policy through today, issue the odd departmental guidance, issue no press release or ministerial statement and have no transparency and let it slide through. When they got sprung in this morning's press they suddenly panicked at the cabinet meeting and they decided to have a ministerial statement later today. I do not mind that, but Senator Herron claimed that this was always planned. It was not on their Notice Paper. It is something they are going to put in additionally.

This is a government of Nixonian proportions absolutely determined to cover up these issues, to dampen down public debate and to deceive the public. Why did they not announce their $5,500 or whatever cap instead of the $4,380 cap? They thought they could sneak it through without debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —It is bit pathetic—is it not?—when you have a former cabinet minister trying to relive the past glories of how cabinet acted under his regime. Of course, he tells us, we now know how it operates.
—We know how it operates now—kindergarten level.

—Let me simply say this: it ill behoves Senator Ray, and anybody else who was in the previous discredited government, to try to make comments about Nixonian cover-ups because every Australian knows that the biggest cover‐up in Australian history was the $10.3 billion budget deficit that you left us. If you did not know about it, you were ignorant. You could not have even read the papers, let alone the attachments. You must have known. If you did not know, you were in dereliction of your duty. You have only two options on that one, Senator Ray, and the people of Australia will continue to judge you on that basis. It was a $10.3 billion deficit that you knew nothing about, and you have the audacity to come in here and try to lecture us on cover-ups. You are a fraud and a joke if you expect us and the Australian people to accept that.
—Order! Senator Abetz, would you like to withdraw your reflection upon Senator Ray?

—Madam Deputy President, as I understand it, I said, `You are a fraud and a joke if you expect the Australian people to accept that.' If he expects the Australian people to accept that, and I think he does, in that case I did say he was a fraud. On that basis, I withdraw.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality remains that the previous government also went to the Australian people saying they would not sell more than 49 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank. Remember that beauty? What did they do then? As soon as they were re-elected, they sold the rest of it. With all the integrity of that record, they come in here, hand on heart, claiming that they have somehow a monopoly on decency and integrity when it comes to government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you still crawling?

—We still have Senator Faulkner interjecting. Let us have a look at his ministerial record. Senator Faulkner, do you remember these sorts of comments being written about you in the media—disappointment, politically incompetent, discredited, ineptly handled, Faulkner takes a roasting at summit, looking inept abroad? Do you know what Senator Faulkner said? He said, `I am a man without a dream.' He is also a man without a brain.

SPEECH.PARA: What did former Senator Loosley say about you, Senator Faulkner? Do you know what he suggested to you, Senator Faulkner? He said that you should retire and grow onions at your comfortable Glebe terrace. Stephen Loosley may well have summed you up very well, Senator Faulkner. With that sort of a record, it ill behoves you to come into this place to try to say that you know how government ought to run, that somehow the way Labor did things was a shining example of the way parliament ought be behaving.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the aged care cover‐up.
—Indeed, Senator Faulkner is still shouting loudly, so I will remind him of another one. My fellow Tasmanians, Labor members Sylvia Smith and Dick Adams—
—You are so gutless.
—Senator Faulkner, would you please withdraw that comment?
—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Vanstone can shout that 25 times into the microphone and not be asked to withdraw. That particular one has never been unparliamentary.
—I withdraw.
—Thank you. Senator Abetz, I advise you to be relevant to the issue, please. You have ranged very widely.

—I would have thought the whole credibility question was at stake and was raised by both Senator Faulkner and Senator Ray. I think it is only appropriate to remind this Senate and the people of Australia exactly what their record was as individual ministers in the government that left Australia with a $10.3 billion deficit when they said during the campaign that, if anything, the budget was in surplus. Everybody knows that was to be untrue, absolutely and utterly untrue.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, on 30 June 1994, two Tasmanian federal members, as they were then, Sylvia Smith and Dick Adams, said that they wished to assure the Tasmanian public that the statements of Senator Faulkner were not government policy, had not been to cabinet or to caucus. So there they were having to dissociate themselves from Senator Faulkner. He is hardly the sort of person that you would put up as an opposition front line to try to attack the government because there is no credibility left in these former failed ministers trying to make attacks of this nature on the government.
You can hypothesise as much as you like. Wait until the policy is announced. When the policy is announced, we will have a debate about the actual issues, not about the hypotheticals. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen George

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to take note of Senator Herron's answers. In another debate in which I participated in this chamber last week, I accused this government of being a government of division and distortion. I think we ought to add another medal to what they have and accuse them of being a government of deception. Australians need to ask themselves whether or not they have a Prime Minister they can trust, whether or not they have a government they can trust and whether or not any aged Australians today would believe anything that this government have to say. Why would any Australian believe anything they have to say?

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard speakers from the government say to us today that you should not believe everything you read in the newspaper. I say to Australians today: you should not listen to everything you hear on a television set, particularly when it comes out of the mouth of the Prime Minister of this government, Mr Howard. The Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) put out a press release on 13 November. It reads:

"I have listened carefully and have acted to ensure certainty and clarity for consumers who enter nursing homes. I'll be taking action to ensure that we now communicate this clearly to older people, their families and others in the aged care sector", Mr Smith said.
From 6 November, residents entering nursing homes may pay up to $12 per day as an accommodation charge . . .
Now what did Mr Smith say in his letter to the Prime Minister? He said:

The key issue is the cap on the daily accommodation charge which replaces the accommodation bond for nursing home level residents. Cabinet discussed this issue and agreed on a cap of $5500 on 17 November.
That was just four days after the minister put out his press release. What is more outrageous is that the Prime Minister got up in the House on the same day, 17 November, and said:

. . . the Australian public will know that it has a government that has a detailed, comprehensive, long‐term nursing home policy that will give security and comfort to the elderly, will give them comfort and dignity but will, at the same time, ensure that there are proper capital contributions to the nursing home stock of this country.

What he did not say to them was that they had in mind changing what they had publicly said their policy was just four days beforehand. I also indicate that on 24 November in an answer in the House the minister again said:
There is a $12 a day arrangement, payable in advance, which in total would amount to $4,380 . . .

Again, on Friday there was a major meeting, that I arranged, to discuss these matters further with the industry and the consumer sector. All were in agreement that the arrangements that I have in place are appropriate.
If you go to Minister Smith's letter to the Prime Minister, what does it say on the second page? It says:
Industry groups initially wanted a review of capital needs that would report in time for next year's Budget—
so they were not satisfied with what the government had put in place—
however, indications are that they will agree to a longer‐term process.

A `longer‐term process' is simply code for they will wait until after the next election for any increases that may come their way. How much pressure was put on those industry players in order to ensure that they were prepared to commit to that statement? It is quite clear that this government have fumbled and bumbled the issue of home care for aged Australians. They do not have a policy. They have entered into nothing but a process of distortion and deception of aged Australians right throughout the whole of this process and have been prepared to continue the process, as was indicated in the letter of 17 November from Minister Smith to the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Synon, Sen Karen

TALK.START.PARA: —You would not know from listening to the frivolous discussion and debate here this afternoon that we have an aged care sector in crisis. All the ALP is interested in is where the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) is going to make an announcement. Isn't that an informed contribution to the debate! There is a funding crisis in the aged care sector. You have left that sector and the nursing homes in a perilous state.

SPEECH.PARA: We sincerely value the contribution of older people to our society and that is indicated in the Conference for Older Australians which has been established by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in conjunction with the Minister for Family Services. The conference has many roles—to coordinate the government's involvement in the International Year of Older Persons in 1999, to develop strategies to promote a positive image of older people and to help advise the government on strategies for dealing with an older population. In addition to that, we are currently developing a national strategy on ageing Australia—a coordinated strategy across all policy areas.

The ALP is once again demonstrating gross hypocrisy—saying one thing and doing another. You neglected this critical area and that is why we must act. You turned your backs on the very people who have given so much to this society. Your disgusting neglect was left to us to clean up. Just like the deficit, we are doing the job.

Let us revisit the ALP's record on this area. The ALP government reduced capital funding to nursing homes by 75 per cent between 1992‐93 and 1995-96. A cut of 75 per cent and you have the audacity to stand here and criticise our policy. You deliberately ran down the nursing home sector. Bob Gregory warned the then government—you—in 1985 that $125 million was needed to upgrade nursing homes. At the last election, the ALP—your government—had 200 words on your aged care policy, less than a page. Two hundred words signified your commitment to older Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did they find you?
—You should be ashamed. Rather than interjecting, you should be off writing your policy now.
—Order! Senator Synon, I would appreciate it if you would actually address the chair and not the interjections.

—My apologies, Madam Deputy President. As Senator Eggleston rightly said, in our current nursing homes, 11 per cent do not meet fire standards, 15 per cent do not meet health standards and, in more than 40 per cent, four or more people share a room. You obviously do not care for the dignity and living standards of older Australians. Clearly, the ALP's record is appalling and the fear that you continue to peddle is appalling.

SPEECH.PARA: You neglect, for instance, to say that under our policy 27 per cent of beds will be guaran teed for people on low incomes. This year we will spend $3.7 billion on aged care, on supporting our older people—not including pensions. We are about setting standards. We are about taking the tough decisions. Our older people need dignity and respect and decisions that look after their long-term interests. We will tackle these issues head-on. The gallery have disappeared. They are obviously not interested in anything the ALP has to say. You were a discredited government offering gratuitous advice on a sector that you let decay and fester. Not only this, you come here and advise us on cabinet and government processes.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Brown, Sen Bob; Lees, Sen Meg
PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old-growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old-growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed-species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non-toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily-available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal-waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter-grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively-managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Brown(from 400 citizens)and Senator Lees(from 1,000 citizens)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to notice of intention to withdraw certain disallowance notices given on 27 November 1997 and earlier today, on behalf of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee I now withdraw business of the Senate notice of motion No. 1 standing in my name for four sitting days after today and business of the Senate notice of motion No. 1 standing in my name for today. I seek leave to make a short statement about the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —These regulations are part of an important national cooperative legislative scheme involving the Commonwealth, the states and the territories which includes a number of related but different principal regulations made under the various road transport reform acts. I have reported to the Senate on our scrutiny of these regulations which has previously resulted in undertakings to amend three of these separate principal regulations. Along with my colleague Senator Cooney of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, I have also reported to the Senate on the special considerations which apply to the scrutiny of national scheme legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee was concerned about a number of aspects of particular regulations and wrote to the minister. These concerns included a possible breach of parliamentary propriety in that a Commonwealth-state agreement provided for regulations to be made as a matter of priority that were not made for five years, 68 strict liability of fences, inadequate notification of rights and a lack of review of discretions.

The committee received a reply from the minister, which met not all of its concerns, and wrote back for further advice. The second reply from the minister met more of our concerns, but again there were some difficulties. I then had two meetings with the minister and the committee subsequently received a third reply which undertook to amend certain provisions and which met our concerns.

Because the regulations were part of a national legislative scheme, I will write to our colleagues in the state and territory legislative scrutiny committees and to the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills describing our actions in detail. I will also present a full report to the Senate.

The committee is most grateful to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the Hon. Mark Vaile MP, for his helpful and courteous personal attention to ensure that the regulations comply with high standards of parliamentary propriety and personal rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, I present the committee's 12th report entitled Australia‐Indonesia maritime delimitation treaty , together with submissions, transcripts of evidence and minutes of proceedings. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report, to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard and to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
Madame President, I wish to comment on the twelfth report tabled today by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties entitled the Australia‐Indonesia Maritime Delimitation Treaty.
The Treaty is an important one as it further establishes the seabed and water column boundaries between the two countries after more than two decades of deliberation.
Australia and Indonesia have conducted a series of maritime boundary delimitation negotiations since the late 1960's that have resulted in three treaties being concluded.

It is important to note that the treaties negotiated to date have treated the seabed differently from the water column. Primarily, this is because recognition of continental shelf jurisdiction in international law predated the recognition of the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) jurisdiction. That is to say, the concept of the EEZ was not known to international law at the time of the negotiation of the 1971 and 1972 seabed treaties.

Furthermore, the principle of natural prolongation that suggested using features such as the Timor Trough in maritime boundary delimitation had been progressively eroded and ultimately rejected in a series of International Court of Justice cases.
The Australia‐Indonesia Maritime Delamination Treaty finalises maritime boundaries between Australia and Indonesia in those areas which were not covered by existing treaties.
The three boundaries finalised by the Treaty are:
1. The exclusive economic zone (EEZ) and seabed boundary between Christmas Island and Java;
2. The western extension of the seabed boundary between continental Australia and Indonesia;
3. The EEZ boundary between continental Australia and Indonesia.

The boundaries delimited by the Treaty stretch over approximately 3,000 kms. The treaty provides Australia with security of jurisdiction over the relevant offshore resources south of these boundaries.
The main recommendations made by the Joint Standing Committee are as follows:
1. The government review the 1974 traditional fisher Memorandum of Understanding with Indonesia in light of the changes to the EEZ boundary in the vicinity of the Ashmore Islands;
2. The Government review the issue of ongoing Indonesian traditional fisher access to Australian waters and its impact on the sustained management of Australian fish resources.

3. The Government review existing or established reciprocal maritime scientific research arrangements with Indonesia to facilitate cross‐border access for Australian researchers in the vicinity of Christmas Island. This co‐operative approach benefits both countries with respect to ecological issues arising out of activities such as fishing and exploration (pp. 47‐49).

The treaty highlights good working relations between neighbours. It exemplifies the manner in which the two countries are able to work together to resolve issues of common concern and achieve productive outcomes.
The Treaty represents a good outcome for Australia and has been welcomed by the resources industry and by the relevant State and Territory Governments.

The inquiry raised a number of complex resource management issues including fisheries matters, natural resource exploration and exploitation issues, and boundary enforcement. It also has ramifications for the local fishing industry, illegal immigration and environmental management as well as the need for adequate consultation with the local communities on Christmas Island.

A specific recommendation of the Committee was that the Commonwealth departmental officials conduct a thorough consultation process on Christmas Island with officials and the local community prior to ratification in order to explain the provisions of the Maritime Delimitation Treaty.
Given the significance of the issues, and the number of specific questions yet to be resolved, it is imperative that the Committee continue its ongoing deliberations and discussions in this regard.
The Committee has come to the view that the Delimitation Treaty represents a satisfactory outcome for Australia and makes a useful contribution to Australian‐Indonesian bilateral relations.

The treaty does establish separate water column and seabed boundaries that result in areas of overlapping jurisdiction. Based on historical precedent, any solution to the maritime boundaries between the two countries would have involved separate boundaries.
This situation represents a fair and equitable outcome which will be maintained through mutual cooperation and management.

It is important to make mention of the fact that the local community on Christmas Island sought an equidistant boundary with Indonesia. However, the Committee believes that had that option gone to international arbitration, Australia may not have received as good an outcome.

The issue of Indonesian traditional fisher access to the area prescribed by the 1974 memorandum of understanding was also raised as a matter requiring clarification. The Committee agreed that, while moving the boundary a further 12 nm to the north of the Ashmore Islands represents a significant gain for Australia, it does nethertheless create an anomaly with the current memorandum of understanding boundary which has an impact on boundary enforcement. In light of this change, the Committee has recommended further review of the MOU.

The Committee has no doubt that this treaty will create certainty for resource exploration and exploitation, particularly in relation to potential oil and gas fields. With respect to shared resources, such as fish stocks, we have recommended that the Government review existing agreements with Indonesia to ensure that suitable management controls are in place.

During our public hearing on Christmas Island a number of important environmental and immigration issues were raised by the local community. However an issue of concern was the apparent lack of consultation with the community on Christmas Island. The Committee had received some conflicting statements from Western Australian and Northern Territory Departments over the level and adequacy of consultation throughout the process.

It was in response to these issues that the committee made the recommendation that the Government establish cooperative marine scientific research provisions with Indonesia, and that it review the issues of illegal immigration and marine pollution.

The Committee believes that, at the very least, this remote island community should have been given the opportunity to put forward its views in preparing the National Interest Analysis. In turn, the Committee has recommended that departmental officials go to Christmas Island and conduct a thorough briefing with officials and the local community prior to ratification of the treaty.

Madame President, this inquiry was an interesting and challenging task, dealing with a bi‐lateral relationship of fundamental importance to Australia. The treaty serves as a model of bilateral cooperation in the region. This would not have been possible without the productive dialogue between our Minister for Foreign Affairs the Hon. Alexander Downer and the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Ali Alatas.

By any measure, the treaty is of significance to Australia because it settles the issue of seabed jurisdiction and provides a firm basis for the exploration and exploitation of the natural resources of the seabed in a climate of confidence. The treaty is a boost to the broader bilateral relationship between Australia and Indonesia and contributes to the strengthening of security for the broader region,.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to speak to this report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that this report will remain on the Notice Paper . When this Australia‐Indonesia maritime delimitation treaty was originally agreed to, there was a meeting in Perth. I managed to go to a briefing which was given to the media in which a spin was given that nothing had changed, everything was fine and it was a win‐win situation. At the time I also commented that it is amazing that they found it surprising that an agreement was reached so quickly with the government of Indonesia over this treaty.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no surprise at all that the agreement was reached so quickly. Australia's negotiators may well have been naive in their expectations. I obviously have not had a chance to read the 12th report of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties but I will be looking at it carefully, as will be a number of my constituents who have shown a particular interest in this issue. There has been a lot of interest in this treaty from the points of view of such things as security, greenhouse studies in the future; most importantly, marine resources and the ecosystem between Australia and Indonesia; the implications for the Timor Gap treaty; and many other issues. In particular, I have been advised of areas around Christmas Island where we have reduced the size of Australia's boundaries, which has implications for safety and rescue. There is a lot of interest in this area from the fishing industry, marine conservationists, scientists and people interested in the way treaties are made between two countries. As I say, I will be looking carefully at the report that this committee has presented.
