SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —When we suspended the sitting for lunch, I was concluding my remarks on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, the opposition, and saying why we do not support the government's motion. I do not wish to unduly prolong the proceedings of the chamber but I think it is worth while bringing my remarks to conclusion by making the following two points: first of all, the point I was summarising when we suspended for lunch was that the government has made great play in this nation that it is a government for the battlers; yet this measure it is insisting on will penalise the very people it claims to support—namely, the battlers.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment the government is insisting on is that if the Australian Taxation Office collects unfairly a payment on behalf of a worker contributor to a superannuation scheme and the tax office has use of that contributor's funds and it is later found that the funds were unfairly collected, then the funds are returned to the individual. So far, so good. The normal circumstances are though that, where the tax office returns funds that have been unfairly collected, an interest payment is made so that the value of the money—while it was retained by the tax office—does not deteriorate to the disadvantage of the individual.

This amendment means that the government proposes not to pay that interest so that if the funds are unfairly collected, then the value of the money will deteriorate to the disadvantage of the individual and the improper collection of the funds will not be something that the government wants to address. I want to cite two reasons why that is a reprehensible situation. Last week I read in the Australian Financial Review of a survey of the superannuation industry conducted by the superannuation firm Jacques Martin.

There were two significant findings in that survey. One was that 70 per cent of the respondents—bear in mind these are the companies that deal with superannuation in Australia—believed that the government's push for so‐called choice of fund is a good thing, and 69 per cent of those surveyed—bearing in mind that this is the industry that manages superannuation—believed that superannuation beneficiaries would lose money because of the government's insistence on choice of fund.

I cite those two figures because the reason is quite obvious. The superannuation fund managers operate as intermediaries managing the funds on behalf of the beneficiaries, that is, the contributors, or, in this case, the workers of Australia. The bigger the choice, the more the bureaucratic responsibility taken on by the funds and the more money the funds managers earn. The people who pay for that are the beneficiaries—the workers who make the contributions and ultimately stand to gain. What we have is a survey which pinpoints that the superannuation industry will make a bigger profit at the expense of the beneficiaries because of this government measure. That simply promotes the industry. The real people that we should be concerned about here are the beneficiaries. It is their money that is being managed; it is their retirement nest egg that is being eroded.

On top of that, we now have another measure where people are required to contribute their tax file number voluntarily. If they do not do so, and their tax file number cannot be identified, they automatically have a 15 per cent tax imposed on them—laughingly called by this government a surcharge—even if their income is below $70,000 a year, which is the cut‐off point by the government. When later their tax file number becomes known the funds are repaid but not the interest on the money.

Added to that situation, there is in today's Melbourne Age an article, which appears in the business pages on page 6, headed `Tax file numbers don't add up'. The author is someone called Beth Quinlivan. She cites a fund by way of an example, and I propose to draw the Senate's attention to this by quoting from the article. She cites a Mr Michael Lillicrap, chief executive of the 700,000‐strong Retail Employees Fund. He said that:
. . . about 10 per cent of its members had provided TFNs. That was after spending $250,000 on direct member mail‐outs and providing workplace information.
If I can interpolate, 10 per cent of 700,000 members had provided the necessary tax file numbers. The Age story goes on:

He said they were not disappointed at the response rate. It was about the level they would expect based on previous experience and probably better than that of some other industry funds. By targeting the mail‐out, they had managed to gather the TFNs of more than half of those categorised as high risk, basically people who were receiving more than $2000 a year in super and therefore would not qualify for the exemption.
This left about 28,000 people who would probably end up paying the tax unnecessarily.
So, we have the chief executive of a 700,000‐strong fund saying that 28,000 members of that fund would probably end up paying the tax unnecessarily. The Age article continues:
The experience of the large funds and large superannuation administrators is at ods with recent ATO statements, that 65 per cent of super fund members had provided their TFNs.

The tax office believes that 65 per cent of superannuation fund members had provided their tax file numbers. Here is, printed today, a report of a 700,000‐strong fund saying only 10 per cent have. What do you conclude from this? You can conclude that there is a wide variation between what the optimists at the tax office say will be the outcome and what the practical managers in the field say is the empirical evidence of an outcome. The only conclusion from both those points that has been now established is that a large number of Australians will be unnecessarily taxed. Yet the government wants to persist with this amendment which will punish them.

There can be no argument: that is unfair. That is totally unfair. It is for those reasons that the opposition will stand up and protect the right of those people not to be unfairly punished. We will insist that this amendment stand, and that the Senate returns it to the House and tells the government to actually do what it tells Australian battlers it is supposed to do for them—stand up for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, let me underline the point that the government has accepted all of the Senate's amendments, with the sole exception of the amendment relating to the payment of interest on re‐assessment where a tax file number was not initially provided. Despite what Senator Cook has said, as I have indicated in this chamber on a number of occasions, no low or middle income earner need be subject to the surcharge—all they have to do is supply their tax file number.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of glaring omissions in Senator Cook's rhetoric. First of all, no surcharge is imposed on accounts that existed before 7 May 1997 unless the surchargeable contributions exceed the contributor's threshold of $2,000—a very important amendment put through by the Senate, accepted, and not mentioned once in the remarks by Senator Cook. Further, the commissioner must write to the member twice, advising him or her of the consequences of failing to quote a tax file number, before the surcharge can be imposed—not mentioned once by Senator Cook. It is interesting that the Labor Party seeks to pretend to protect the battlers. The reality is what they sought to do all through this debate is to stop the payment of a surcharge by high income earners. The Labor Party got itself into that difficult position and now tries to pretend that it is protecting the battlers.

In all the remarks that you made, Senator Cook, you forgot two rather essential points, and I bring those to the Senate's attention. In relation to the amendment—I have been asked to keep this very brief as I understand agreements have been reached—it is simply not appropriate to provide an incentive to people who do not provide their tax file number. In all other instances where the ATO has assessed an individual, interest will be applied. However, where the overassessment arises from a deliberate decision on the part of a fund member not to quote their tax file number, interest should not be given. The amendment would result in inconsistent consequences for the failure to quote a tax file number.

In other legislation administered by the Commissioner of Taxation interest is not applied to amended assessments after the quotation of a TFN. For example, failure to quote a TFN results in tax being withheld at the top marginal rate on salary and wages paid by an employer, payments under the prescribed payments system and reportable payment system and bank accounts. Subsequent quotation of a TFN in these circumstances will allow the taxpayer to claim a credit for the tax withheld but no interest is payable. Therefore, what we are doing is perfectly consistent with what I believe was done by the previous government. We therefore urge the Senate to ensure that this bill is consistent with other cases where the tax file number is not supplied.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to speak to the government's amendments, given that I presume we are debating all amendments in one debate. For the benefit of the Senate, I will detail the government's amendments.

Amendment No. 58 ensures that the limitation period for claims for compensation runs from the time at which the act giving rise to the compensation is notified. In other words, the six‐year limit on compensation claims will run from the time of notice, and that notice must go to registered native title bodies corporate, registered native title claimants and representative bodies for the area affected by the compensable act.

Amendment No. 61 is a government amendment which flows from the report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. We believe that the word `unduly' should be added, in order that the cultural and customary concerns may be taken into account by the Federal Court, but not where to do so would `unduly prejudice' the other parties. We think that this relaxation is important.

In general, the issue of the rules for the Federal Court, from the government's point of view, should be based on giving the court discretion and the relevant flexibility in handling these matters. We certainly agree that the court should be able to take account of cultural and customary concerns. We provide accordingly. We have accepted that our previous proposition that they should not do so where it would prejudice the other parties was too tight. We think adding the word `unduly' is appropriate.

We have to remember we are now talking about a different situation from that which prevailed in 1993. We are now clearly dealing with the situation where native title claims can and will involve a range of other parties—other title holders, other permit holders, et cetera—whereas that was not contemplated to anything like the degree which will now be the case given that pastoral leases may not extinguish native title. Therefore, the Federal Court, in hearing these matters, needs to take account of the fact that there could well be many other parties to the proceedings. While we do agree that the court should be able to take account of cultural and customary concerns, we think that should not result in undue prejudice to other parties; but our amendment, I would have thought, would be welcomed by other parties in the Senate.

Amendment 62 merely applies the same amendment—that is, to add the word `unduly'—in relation to the operation of the National Native Title Tribunal, and is a consequential amendment again really flowing from the parliamentary committee report.

Amendment 63 relates to the proposition which has come before the parliament a number of times now, that is, the qualifications for a presidential member of the tribunal. We agreed with the former Keating government that the president of the tribunal need not necessarily be a Federal Court judge. Obviously, when the tribunal was first created it was given quasi‐judicial functions that appeared appropriate, but I think the former Labor government, in response to the Brandy decision when it brought in its own amendments to provide that the tribunal would no longer act judicially, made the sensible decision that there should be more flexibility therefore in relation to governments being able to appoint presidential members. I think our amendment 63 picks up entirely what was the previous government's proposition, that is:
A person who is, and has been for at least 5 years, enrolled as a legal practitioner of the High Court, of another federal court or of the Supreme Court of a State or Territory—

is eligible for appointment as a presidential member. Given that the tribunal can no longer act judicially, it seems eminently sensible for our government or any future government to have greater flexibility in relation to the appointment of a president. Given the enormous pressures now on the Federal Court restricting the availability of people who can act as presidents in the way that is currently the case and in the way the previous government tried to change, we think this change is eminently sensible and we ask the Senate, once again, to give this serious consideration.

Amendment 64 is again a relatively technical amendment. It simply provides that a mediation conference, which would ordinarily be held in private, may not necessarily be held in private if none of the parties object. It is simply giving some flexibility to enable a mediation conference to be opened if none of the parties object to it. It is simply giving the presiding member of the tribunal that discretion. Again, that amendment has come from parties involved in mediation who suggest that that sort of discretion should be available.

Amendment 65 is again a technical amendment—very technical—in relation to the power of the tribunal to dismiss an application at any stage of the inquiry relating to the application. It is technical and has come from those dealing with these matters. It is not something inspired by the government, but is a response to a suggestion made to us by those closely associated with the conduct of these matters.

Amendment 66 clarifies that the Registrar of the Federal Court must advise the native title registrar whenever an application is withdrawn, even if that application has not actually been registered. Again, it is a very technical amendment and is simply designed to ensure the effective maintenance of the register.

Government amendment 71 is designed to make it clear that there can be more than one group of native title holders for one area of land. There is perhaps some misunderstanding of the government's intentions here. It is generally the government's policy framework to ensure, when native title determinations are being heard, that all claims are brought in together. So you could have one Federal Court hearing and one determination of all relevant claims in relation to one area. That is the policy which is eminently sensible. Otherwise, it means that you have an endless stream of native title claims being able to be made. You make one determination in relation to an area, then somebody else comes along and makes another claim and the process just continues for ever, in theory. Given that claims can now be made over land on which there is another title, it seems only fair, just and sensible to provide a framework which enables the process to deal with all native title claims over one area at one time.

This amendment simply makes it clear that of course there can be more than one group of native title holders for one area of land. It is the job of the court to determine which claimants have what title. The amendments will ensure that determinations clearly identify whom the holders are and how, in terms of group composition, they hold the title.

Amendment 72 simply adds a note to explain that, when making a determination of native title that deals with other interests in the area, the determination can refer to particular kinds of non‐native title interests rather than dealing with each non‐native title interest or even each category of interest. An example of what we mean here: the determination could be that fishing licences exist in the area and that native title rights are subject to those licences. We are simply seeking to ensure, now that we know that native title can be claimed where there are other titles, that the determination seeks to ensure, as much as possible, clarity in relation to the interrelation ship between all the rights, having found that native title exists, to provide in the determination the relationship between the various rights, native title and non‐native title.

Those are the government's amendments. They are largely technical, with the exception of the question of the qualifications for the president of the tribunal. We are disappointed that the ALP seems to have changed its position on this question compared with its attitude while in government. As I say, I think, given that the tribunal is not now a judicial body, it seems appropriate that our government or a future Labor government should have the discretion to be able to have a wider field of candidates from which to choose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, first of all I will talk to the government's proposed amendments and then discuss what the issues are in relation to the amendments of the Australian Democrats, the Greens (WA) and, in large part also, the ALP.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed government amendment No. 58 amends the sunset clause. We do not accept that at all, so we will not be voting for that sunset clause amendment.

Proposed amendment 61 relates to page 162 of the bill and proposed amendment 62 relates to page 176 of the bill. The amendments make changes to the Federal Court's way of operating. We do not support any of these grossly unfair changes. The amendments may improve the situation slightly, but it is like putting a bandaid on an amputation.

We have a sense of deja vu with regard to proposed government amendment 63 because we are dealing with a repeat of the native title tribunal appointments bill, which was defeated. I will speak to that in more detail later.

Proposed government amendment 64 is one of the few amendments that I believe I could support. It allows some flexibility for hearings to be open, but only if all parties agree. So, when it comes to voting on the government's proposed amendments, I certainly will be asking that No. 64 be excised so that it can be voted on separately.

BREAK.PARA: Proposed government amendment 65 is way too broad. It allows for the dismissal of an application at any stage. We will not be supporting that. Proposed government amendment 70 amends provisions relating to state and territory bodies to which we are opposed, and proposed amendments 71 and 72 amend provisions relating to the determination of native title which we will also be opposing.

I will speak in a little more detail on proposed government amendment 63 by which the government is trying to bring in what was rejected under the native title tribunal appointments bill. Currently only current or former Federal Court judges from any jurisdiction can be appointed as presidential members after recommendations cross Mr Howard's desk. This amendment seeks to change this requirement so that a person who has been a legal practitioner for at least five years can be appointed as a presidential member. It inserts a new subsection in the table contained in section 110.

Currently there are five presidential members, including the President, Justice French, and 13 ordinary members of the tribunal. Two of the current full‐time ordinary members are Aboriginal. Ordinary members are only required to have been legal practitioners for at least five years. The main difference between ordinary and presidential members is the power to direct.

The principle of non‐judges being appointed to presidential positions may appear on the surface to be perfectly reasonable. For example, many experienced practitioners may have more knowledge of Aboriginal issues than most Federal Court judges or ex‐judges. Judges are nearly all ruling class, middle‐aged, white men, and this is a paradigm which should be broken down. To select from such a select pool of people could be considered as inappropriate for the National Native Title Tribunal. To this end, there are no Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander judges or ex‐judges in Australia. A further argument that could be used is that currently the government is finding it difficult to find presidential members. We mentioned this when the bill was debated.

Justice French is on record as supporting the proposed changes, and he said as much in his submission on the proposed amendments in 1995. In his submission on section 110 in August 1996, Justice French said:

The section as it presently stands sets out the categories of membership of the tribunal and the qualifications for appointment to those categories. The amendment extends the qualification of presidential members to include persons who have been legal practitioners for five years or more. If the amendment is supported, I will provide greater flexibility in the appointment of members to the tribunal.

However, Aboriginal people to whom I and people in my office have spoken, such as Mick Dodson, Social Justice Commissioner, and others from Aboriginal corporations, believe that the requirement that presidential members come from the judiciary should remain because, firstly, they believe the government is wanting to open up the field, not to appoint presidential members who are more appropriate but, on the contrary, to appoint members who will do the government's bidding. Secondly, they believe it will lower the stature of the Native Title Tribunal, which has come under considerable attack in recent times, and this will become just another area where Aboriginal peoples' forums are downgraded.

Thirdly, judges are less likely to be influenced by the government which has appointed them than a lawyer. Judges have the experience of working in an environment with a clear separation of powers. I know this is something the government quite frequently forgets, but it is important. That respects the need to remain independent. Mick Dodson in particular has much more trust and respect for the judiciary, it seems, than the government. In a conversation last Friday, he said that it was the judiciary which gave Aboriginal people native title and the government which is attempting to extinguish it. I think that is a reasonable indication.
In his 1995‐96 Native Title Act report, Commissioner Dodson wrote:

This proposal may undermine the standing of the NNTT in the establishment and consolidation phase of a body. With the significant and unusual functions of the NNTT, it is vital that it be perceived as credible and impartial. This perception would be undermined if the president and deputy president of the NNTT were not required to have judicial experience. I therefore believe that the proposed amendment is inappropriate.

The importance of Aboriginal people having faith in the independence and standing of the NNTT is absolutely crucial. Given the current attacks on Aboriginal people by this government, it would undermine the whole native title process if Aboriginal people felt the tribunal was stacked out by government lackeys.

Why shouldn't we look at any changes the government makes with regard to the native title process with extreme scepticism? After all, it is this government which, in the words of the Deputy Prime Minister, is seeking to enact `bucketloads of extinguishment'; it is this government which is seeking to destroy the right to negotiate process; it is this government which is proposing to change the rules of evidence, so why should we believe this government when it says that it only wishes to remove the requirement for the president to be from the judiciary in order to open the field?

The government has created a climate of mistrust with regard to Aboriginal affairs which has not existed since the dark times when indigenous people were considered non‐citizens. It cannot expect us now to take it on good faith that this change is being enacted to enable the appointment of a more appropriate president. The fear is real and apparent that in fact this government is more likely to use this amendment to appoint someone far less appropriate.

I now move to the ability to strike out native title applications covered in section 84C. Native title applicants should not face having their application being struck out in a Federal Court proceedings simply because they have made a mistake or circumstances have changed so as to make the information required for making applications under section 62 incomplete. There is a lot of information required under section 62(2), much of it very detailed. It includes examples covered from page 148 of the bill, but I would imagine that even the most dedicated lawyer could trip up in complying with this section.

There is already a provision in section 190C(2) for the registrar to be satisfied that the application complies with sections 61 and 62. This is the appropriate stage for an application to come under this sort of scrutiny and be amended if necessary. I know that the ALP agrees with the National Indigenous Working Group's compromised amendments to allow the Federal Court more flexibility in considering such applications, but this does not eliminate the cost and anxiety that will be experienced by native title claimants when dragged through this process.

Importantly, this provision allows any party to the proceedings to apply for the claim to be struck out on the basis that it does not comply with section 62. What is likely to happen is that wealthy non-native title parties are going to have lawyers scrutinising every aspect of native title applications. If any mistakes are made in the very detailed requirements of section 62, they will drag the native title claimants into the Federal Court. In addition, section 85A requires that each party must bear their own costs in such proceedings. This will clearly favour miners and developers and any other affected persons allowed to bring such actions by virtue of section 84(3).

Non-compliance with section 61 is maintained as a trigger for strike‐out provisions under section 84C under the National Indigenous Working Group's proposals. That should be all, yet here is another example of the National Indigenous Working Group adopting a compromised position in allowing for other parties to seek that claims be struck out but simply asking that it be done on a fair and workable basis. That is not too much to ask.

Section 61A, as the ALP agree by virtue of their amendments, should not be a requirement simply because section 61A should not exist at all. Senator Harradine requested earlier that consideration of that section under amendment No. 229 be deferred. It relates to applications which must not be made because they cover lands and waters over which native title is proposed to be extinguished via the government's evil section 23, confirmation of extinguishment provisions. That includes crown to crown community purpose leases, Defence lands, et cetera, et cetera—`bucketloads of extinguishment'.

I ask the ALP to seriously consider supporting the National Indigenous Working Group's compromise to prevent what could well be a very unjust provision, especially if other ameliorating amendments of theirs do not gain support from Senator Harradine. I also signal to the ALP that there is no reason for us to support their amendment because their position on this clause is the same as the government's, except for the part referring to section 61A. If section 61A has any effect at the end of this amendment process, we are heading for so many years division and injustice that this strike‐out provision will be largely irrelevant.

I know that Senator Bolkus will want to comment on this section. I indicate that it is my understanding that, although theoretically in conflict with Greens (WA) and Democrat amendment No. 214, opposition amendment No. 247 is virtually identical in its intent as Green and Democrat amendment No. 214. It should not matter which of those gets support, and I hope they do get support. I indicate that there is a conflict and a difference in the treatment of Greens (WA) and Democrat amendment No. 217 and opposition amendment No. 250. I indicate that, at this stage, I am unable to support ALP amendment No. 250.

TALK.START.PARA: —On my running sheet I have the claims process and sunset clause as the first item. I do not know why we did not deal with that first of all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with all the different aspects of claims process and sunset clause. There are eight important areas here where the opposition disagrees with the government. One of them is a sunset clause. What Senator Margetts has been talking to has been some of those other areas that are within the umbrella of the claims process. You may have wanted to do the sunset clause first, but I do indicate at this stage that, from our perspective, we see process as being quite critical.

SPEECH.PARA: There are eight important areas at least where we disagree with the government on this. There is more than one way to skin a cat. What Senator Minchin is doing here he is doing in the most tortuous way, but it is going to be effective if it gets through. Senator Harradine, the short answer is that, under that umbrella, we are in fact talking about the claims process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously we have been talking about the other matters. Senator Minchin has moved his amendments and Senator Margetts has been speaking to those, including the ones relating to the appointments, et cetera. I thought that, because the sunset clause might be the easy one to get over, we should have dealt with it first, but it does not worry me.
—Senator Harradine, that might be correct, but we are in the hands of the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, there are eight important areas where we differ from the government. I will make two points at the start. One is that the process is quite critical to the outcome. We need to acknowledge that in respect of the normal and general application of law making in this place. We really ought to acknowledge it in respect of this specific legislation. The other thing is, as has been evidenced in the last few minutes, that there is a difference between the opposition and some of the minor parties in respect of some of these provisions. It stems from the fact that we have actually tried to steer a course which, in some instances, we believe would be a bit more balanced, but that course would get us into trouble with the minor parties. This is one of those areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I will turn to the areas of distinction between us and the government and the minor parties and the government. We have to recognise that one of those areas is in respect of determinations. The government's bill we believe quite strongly is quite inflexible when it comes to a one‐only determination of native title for an area of land. If one were to have a full and comprehensive understanding of Aboriginal customary law, one would realise that there can be coexistence of interests on a particular area of land.

BREAK.PARA: What we say in that respect is that there should be flexibility to allow for that coexistence. Our amendments do that. At the same time, we recognise that amendments later down the track will ensure that overlapping can be handled. Our amendments further down the track in respect of overlapping are a bit more comprehensive and effective than the government's, we would maintain.

To force all different native title groups into one process at one particular time and not sufficiently recognise the capacity for coexistence of rights we think is quite inflexible. For instance, if you are really looking at it from the point that we are talking here about a right that a particular group would have, you cannot stop that claim at common law regardless of what the government is trying to seek here by ensuring a one‐only determination of native title. That will not be effective because groups that are not part of that process will still have a claim at common law—a claim that is either able to be compensated for or that goes to the validity of what the government is trying to do here. They are trying to rush an outcome when people's rights cannot be forced into one particular funnel. I think we need to look at that quite seriously.

The government is, out of a real lack of understanding of the process or maybe a deliberate lack of understanding of the process, seeking to have a sunset clause. You cannot take away people's rights to claim. The government acknowledges that. It is basically a smokescreen that they are putting up in respect of the sunset clause. Quite honestly, we do not think you were ever serious about pursuing this particular proposal.

What this Native Title Act amendment process is all about is getting certainty of outcome and certainty of processes. If you terminate the operation of the Native Title Act after six years, who is going to miss out? Indigenous Australians can still pursue common law claims. Those in the industry, particularly miners, who want certain time lines and certain outcomes will not be able to have them because of your suspension of the act. Basically, it may be populist politics, but it does not give the certainty that is needed.

Another important area, and one that has not really been focused on, is the evidentiary provisions. I think it is a quite insidious area of this legislation. What we have here is a deliberate intention to proceed to pare back the capacity of native title claimants to be successful in court. Were we to do this to any other group of Australians, there would be screams and so on. In this particular area, let us have a look at what we are doing. Let us have a look at what the government is proposing.

The government is proposing a strict regime of evidentiary provisions. It is proposing a loosening of the compulsion to take into account cultural practices and so on. You might think that is a reasonable thing to do but, in essence, it is not. If you look at the history domestically and the history internationally, what has been shown, particularly in respect of the law affecting indigenous communities and indigenous people, is that there needs to be a degree of flexibility. The Canadian experience is that there needs to be a degree of flexibility. The Australian domestic experience is the same. What the government is trying to do now is terminate the development of the common law principles at an embryonic stage.

Let us face it: those principles are there to ensure that people have a capacity to put their case to the court and to do so despite rigid requirements emanating from things like laws of hearsay and so on. As I say, internationally the development of law has been along the lines of allowing flexibility in respect of rules of evidence. The government, by its amendment, now wants to ensure that the court is bound by them.

In respect of cultural and customary concerns, presently the court must take those concerns into account. One would have thought, in dealing with indigenous rights, that that would be something one would expect and should expect to happen. For some reason, the government wants to—and it has nothing to do with the Wik legislation; it is overreaching the bounds of the Wik legislation—loosen that compulsion on the court to take those cultural practices into account. You can in no way drive this particular provision back to the Wik legislation.

In respect of experience internationally and experience domestically, if one were to look at, for instance, the 20 years of experience of the Northern Territory Lands Rights Act, one would see that the best evidence has been able to be adduced via the non‐adversarial process. That is something that is important when it comes to people who are so alien to the court process that the rest of us are aware of. We have to get the balance right. We have to acknowledge that this does not emanate from Wik. In getting the balance right, let us give the courts and the tribunals the flexibilities that are necessary.

Point 4 in dispute with the government is the government's provisions in respect of parties. If you really wanted to work out a motivation here—and be quite fair in that assessment—why would you reckon the government would want to leave the whole process open to anyone who might want to become a party to the proceedings? Why would you unless you thought there was some intention to do, with any other claim in the future, what has happened with the Yorta Yorta claim over recent years.

If you want to sabotage a process, if you want to delay it, if you want to drag it out, you have this sort of provision. This is something that the Senate ought to be aware of. It is not fair for those with limited resources to be pitted against anyone who might want to participate in the process. I ask the Senate to consider this seriously. With respect to who should be involved, we think, and we say, that anyone who has an interest should be involved. With respect to general public rights, let there be one public representative and let that person act as an agent on behalf of all those with a general interest in the proceedings. This Senate really has to consider here whether it wants the Yorta Yorta type of experience to keep going on.

In respect of strike‐out provisions, Senator Margetts handled those quite well. In respect of the Native Title Tribunal's way of operating with respect to evidence and so on, as I said earlier, I think the cases there are quite compelling. Were we to adopt the govern ment's provisions, we would be running contrary not just to developed practice in this country and elsewhere but also to research, advice and inquiries by such bodies as the Australian Law Reform Commission.

With respect to the president of the tribunal and whether that person should be a Federal Court judge, once again Senator Margetts covered that, but we just discussed that by way of legislation in this place only in the last few weeks. We made it very clear then that we thought that, given the growing importance of this area and the tribunal, there needed to be a judge appointed. We made it clear that was the developed position of the opposition.

There is another government provision which I think is quite insidious. It has sneaked in only in the last few days. It is amendment No. 65. If you really want to get a fix on what this process is about, have a look at No. 65. This amendment would empower the tribunal to dismiss applications without any criteria being established. This is a new proposal, never before raised by the government. The present sections 147 and 149 in the act impose the usual discretionary criteria applicable to dismiss applications, but what do we have here? We want to give the tribunal a blank cheque to dismiss on no established, written down, defined criteria at all. That also is too much of an ask.

I will go back to the point I made at the start. There are some eight areas, and those who have a passing interest in this particular debate might think, `These aren't as important as other factors in the debate. Maybe we should let these go through. The government, after all, wants to be able to manage its process, its affairs and whatever.' But, when you are talking about the rights of individuals, you cannot adequately protect those rights unless you give them a fair process under which to pursue them. This is about eight slices of the salami which would deprive indigenous Australians time and time again of an effective resolution of their problems in the courts.

With respect to some of them, they will go back to the common law or the High Court. But, if we really wanted certainty, if we were really dinkum about wanting certainty in this debate, we would allow the common law to develop and we would reject the sorts of proposals the government is putting up here. It is quite critical. These may not be as glamorous as some of the other areas, but we do have here a recipe which I think has as its main objective—and I deserve to be listened to here as much as anyone else because we made an analysis of these provisions—the intention of cutting back on claimants' capacity to pursue successfully their rights.

It is almost as though this government got together a whole group of lawyers who have acted against native title claimants over the last three or four years, put them in a room and said, `Just think of extra hurdles we could put in the way of successful native title claims. Just think of them.' All these lawyers who, admittedly, have lost their cases over recent years—they have not been able to win those cases against native title claimants under ordinary laws, under the laws that have been developed for indigenous claims throughout the world—have come up with a recipe and this government has shunted it up. It really will reflect badly on us if we accept them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just respond briefly to the ALP propositions. I indicated at the outset that, in relation to parties, the Yorta Yorta experience happened under the current Native Title Act, which was designed by the Labor Party. It is not our fault, so do not blame us for Yorta Yorta. In the spirit of goodwill, I indicate that we are prepared to accept ALP amendments Nos 247, 242, 248 and 249, which deal with the question of parties. We think a sensible case has been made for those amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to determinations, I do appeal to the ALP in the spirit of seeking certainty in relation to native title to consider supporting what we are trying to do here. It is essential that we approach this whole issue of native title from the point of view now that we are talking about trying to get as rapid a determination of coexisting title as is possible through the legal process—and that was very much, I thought, the intent of the Keating Labor government when it designed the Native Title Act. I think it was originally designed on the presumption that before too long there would be a clear determination around the country of who held what native title and what it consisted of.

Our provisions are simply designed to encourage the capacity of the court to ensure that, in relation to particular areas of land over which there may be other titles, the native title issues relating to that land are dealt with at once. It does not in any way, as suggested by Senator Bolkus, prevent coexistence of rights as among ordinary titleholders or other leaseholders and native title holders.

There is no restriction at all on the number of native title claimants who can be involved in the process. It simply says that, in relation to one area of land, you will deal with all the claims that are made and have the determination made; otherwise you will have the extraordinary uncertainty that is produced by the possibility of consequential claims going on forever, where the court goes through a process of making a determination that may involve three or four claimants, makes the determination and, if it is a pastoral lease, the pastoral lessee then knows whom he has to deal with, but then you find another claim is made.

It is true of course that, as a matter of common law, subsequent claims can be made through the normal common law process, but clearly there is a great incentive to make claims through the Native Title Act and in the Federal Court. All we are seeking to do is encourage those claims to be made at the time the hearing is occurring so that all claims in relation to an area can be dealt with at once. Everybody would then know who has got what rights and how they interrelate with each other so life can go on. If you are serious about certainty, you will support these amendments.

I know the sunset clause has aroused a lot of emotion, but it is important to stress that we are not placing a sunset on native title claims per se. That is not the government's intention nor is that the effect of what we have before us. Native title claims as a matter of common law under our bill can go on being made forever. However, we do believe that, in terms of good public policy, it is not unreasonable to be encouraging native title claimants to lodge their claims through the Native Title Act and in the Federal Court within six years of this bill being passed.

We do have a situation where, some four years after the Native Title Act came into effect, nearly 670 claims have already been made. Nearly 50 per cent of the country is under claim. Based on our current understanding of the extent of native title, only about a third of the total area is left to be claimed. In other words, two-thirds has been claimed in four years and we know that at least another third can be claimed. We are saying that, under this proposal, there should be another six years in which claims can be lodged. That means you have until five years and 364 days down the track to put your claim in—to simply lodge it.

Of course that claim will then be dealt with through the system for however long it takes. The processes do not terminate and they can run-on so that all claims lodged within that time are dealt with under the processes of the bill. It is simply that after that six years—or 10 years after the act was first passed and 11½ years after the original Mabo decision—claims that are proposed to be made under the auspices of this bill should be lodged, without in any way derogating from the common law right to make the claim at any time in the future. We do not think as a matter of public policy that is unreasonable, particularly as I say we are now dealing with an entirely different situation to that which the parliament thought it faced in 1993, when it thought it was dealing with claims over vacant crown land and Aboriginal land. We are now dealing with a whole new set of circumstances where claims can be made over the 42 per cent of Australia that is held by pastoral lessees.

So there are other interests at stake and they deserve to be heard and considered in the parliament's resolution of this very complex issue. It is not unreasonable or unfair to take account of those other title holders and their interest in knowing who is making claims on the land they lease and what rights they are seeking, and they can have those claims dealt with.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a double jeopardy otherwise.

—That is right. In terms of the rules of evidence, what we are simply proposing here is to recognise that we are dealing with a proper court—a proper court that is determining the people's rights. The practical fact is that there is a big difference for any current lessee as to whether a native title claim succeeds or not, and it is not unreasonable or unfair that common law claims should be dealt with as ordinary common law claims, although we do keep some proper exceptions in relation to native title.

SPEECH.PARA: All our amendments say is that the Federal Court is bound by the rules of evidence—like in any normal civil matter—except to the extent that the court otherwise orders, so we give full flexibility to the court to determine that it wishes to adopt another procedure. The prima facie proposition is there that the rules of evidence should apply, but the full discretion is given to the court to do otherwise in our proposals. We make it quite clear that, in conducting its proceedings, the court can take account of the cultural and customary concerns of Aboriginal people, but there is a quite reasonable rider that, because we are now dealing with claims affecting other title holders, the court should not unduly prejudice the other parties to the proceedings, and of course there are other parties whose rights are also at stake and affected by these claims. So we think we have struck the right balance. It does pay proper regard to the particular cultural and customary concerns of Aboriginal people, but it gives the flexibility and the proper authority to the court to conduct the proceedings accordingly.

I cannot say any more about the President of the tribunal. That matter has been fully debated. In relation to the accusation made against the government about amendment 65, I need to say that this suggestion was not one that came from within the government; it came from the Native Title Tribunal. I say that because ill‐motive has been attributed to the government in this matter, and I have to reject that and I do so by stating the origin of the proposition. You can throw it out—that is the Senate's prerogative—but I would ask you to consider the origin of the proposition. The tribunal does believe that this would considerably assist it in its proper functions of mediation, et cetera. So I do ask you to consider it in that light and not based on what you regard as the improper motives of the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to repeat what Senator Margetts and Senator Bolkus have said but I do want to make a couple of comments and this is the appropriate place to do it. We are dealing with the claims process and the sunset clause. The claims process sets up the machinery in which the Native Title Act facilitates the claiming and later the determination of native title. It could rightly be called the gatekeeper provisions of native title. The government amendments in part put in place what has come to be called the Brandy amendments. However, the amendments go too far.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the view of the Australian Democrats that the inclusion of a sunset clause underlines exactly what this government really thinks about native title. It really is an astounding statement to say to indigenous people that, after 209 years of dispossession, they should now effectively get their house in order because we consider them to be an annoyance and it would be good if we could just get rid of them.

After we threw them out of their houses, forcefully took their children from them and burned their spiritual beliefs to the ground, it became a case of out of sight and out of mind. A cartoon in the Australian today summed it up by showing the Prime Minister with a bunch of British troopers saying, `Shoot them all and take the land.' But the Prime Minister intervenes and says, `Let's be reasonable. Just take the land.'

The sunset clause represents a turning back of the clock. Few senators would remember that it was the pictures of the abstract poverty of indigenous people that shocked much of middle Australia and brought forth their support for the 1967 referendum. Because we became conscious or shocked about the living conditions of our indigenous Australians, we voted that way overwhelmingly in the mid-1960s. Black Australia became visible in the life of the nation. To a large extent that has been the hallmark of indigenous and non-indigenous Australians—a form of forced visibility.

The Mabo decision in legal terms, at least, made Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people visible to our law. That is what getting rid of terra nullius was about. After only five years in the sun, the Australian Democrats will not allow indigenous people to be sunsetted, enforceable by this government. We expect that the Labor Party will help us keep a light on the hill for native title. I am pleased to see Senator Harradine has moved an identical amendment to the other amendments. I commend this amendment as a blow for justice to the Senate.

Government amendments Nos 63 to 65, which are about the members of the tribunal, seek to have another bite of the cherry with regard to amendments dealing with persons who may be appointed as presidential members of the National Native Title Tribunal. During the debate on the Native Title Amendment (Tribunal Appointments) Bill 1997 , as recently as 29 October, only five weeks ago, I said:

It seems to me that, if this is an indication of the government's attitude, then one must put some weight on the fact that the government wants to water down again the stature of the president of the tribunal and therefore to reduce its effectiveness.
The Democrats did not support this provision five weeks ago and we will not be supporting the government's attempt to bury it in this legislation. The Democrats oppose these amendments.

I have a couple of other comments on some of the Democrat-Greens (WA) amendments which the ALP supports, particularly amendments Nos 193, 195 and 208. These amendments deal with working out cross claims. It is important to note here that it is possible for native title rights to be overlapping. For example, some native title rights may include the right to conduct ceremony and others may include the right to fish or camp. This em powers the Federal Court to assist in making determinations that will facilitate the necessary flexibility to ensure that justice can be affected. The Democrats, of course, will support these amendments.

Another amendment is No. 212, which the ALP supports. This amendment deals with expanding the flexibility of the court to deal with overlapping claims. It deals with the complexity of overlapping claims which in part have been caused by catastrophic events such as the stolen generations. In Queensland, the transportation of people for generations from one part of the state to another caused an incredibly complex mix of people, as did the forcing of people into communities. Most communities have an incredible complexity of ancestry.
Professor Marcia Langton, who gave evidence before the Joint Committee on Native Title in Darwin this year, said:

One finds in preparing land claims that a group of people who have been separated from all of that part of the customary group by enforced government removals will have been brought up over a number of generations to believe that they are the descendants of a certain person and that person only, while this group over here believes that they are the descendant of another person and that person only. They may come to find out later, from an anthropologist, say in a land claim—and this happens—that those two . . . ancestors were siblings. They were half siblings or full siblings.

Let us say that this group makes a claim and this group makes a claim before they find out about this historical fact of their ancestry from two siblings. It would be called an overlapping claim, in the present jargon used to describe these matters. But, because the Native Title Act does not permit the amendment of a claim before the Native Title Tribunal, it is not now possible to have a negotiation amongst claimant groups and to point out to them that they might in fact be related.

It is very, very likely that, if groups are claiming in the one area and the claims overlap to some extent . . . they are related through some kind of ancestral connection. They may not know of their connection, and it might be a part of their present social identification of themselves as a particular named group to distinguish themselves from other people. This kind of differentiation on the basis of cultural history is very typically a part both of Aboriginal tradition and of the colonial impact. But it is possible to amalgamate claims on the basis of such anthropological or historical information, or even that people might agree as claimants to conduct a unified claim on the basis of shared traditions.
The customary constitution of the group is a matter for the group, and it must always be. One cannot define culture. Thousands of anthropologists have tried to, unsuccessfully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to enter this debate on every issue, but this sunset clause is a major issue. It is an issue that I want to take up. It is one that has been promised to the rural community by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

SPEECH.PARA: It might be hard for people who do not understand native title to imagine the impact of it, but in the rural community a number of people have two or three or more claims on their property. Three years ago they were told there would be no native title claims on their property. Now they have been told there may be native title claims on their property. It is a nightmare for them because they do not know how they are going to get around it. At the end of every nightmare you wake up, and the nightmare goes away.

If we do not have a sunset clause in this, we are putting these people into uncertainty forever. They do not know when the next claim will come up or whether there will be another claim. If there are claims on their property, it is very difficult for them to borrow money. It is hard to diversify if you cannot borrow money. You cannot upgrade your property and you cannot move anywhere. So you are locked into a position forever with no certainty at all. You cannot plan anything and you cannot move anywhere if you do not have some sort of certainty. It is not as though we are saying that you cannot make a claim under common law or we are retracting that. That is not the case at all. Surely six years is long enough for the Aboriginal community to get their claims together and process them.

I understand where Senator Woodley is coming from, and he is looking into the past. I accept the injustices that were caused a long time ago—I think everyone does—but we cannot dwell on the past forever. We have to move forward. If we live in the spiritual world, we are going to confine investment and the competitive environment beyond our borders.

I know that every senator in this place wants to see young people get a job. They want to see people who spend six or seven years at university come out and be able to get a job. If we freeze mining and we freeze our rural industries and we freeze our primary industries, if we put such a handicap on them that they cannot move anywhere, the next process is that it is going to go down the line. This will be felt not only in the bush—they will have to live with it, and they will be affected worst of all—but right throughout Australia. Someone in my own family was trying to get a job, and I know how hard it was for him. I just want to warn the Senate and all of those senators who are voting that yes, there were things that did happen to the Aboriginals that none of us can be proud of, but if we try to live in the past we have no future.

So I say to the Senate that six years is a reasonable time. Do not condemn these people in rural Australia to uncertainty for the rest of their lives. If you do not put a sunset clause on it, they will never be able to say, `We're out of this nightmare.' You will confine them to this terrible position where they cannot move forward, they cannot borrow money on their property and they cannot upgrade their property because there is a native title claim on it. That will be there forever. Very few would have the mental fortitude to stay out there and cop it. So six years is a reasonable time. I am not certain of this, but I understand that when South Africa brought their land rights legislation in it was less than that. So let us give some sort of certainty to our job producing industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take up the issue of the sunset clause. We have been told by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that over 75 per cent of Australia may be available—
—Seventy-nine.

—Thank you. Seventy-nine per cent of Australia may be available for native title claim. If there is a six-year limitation period on that, wouldn't it be incumbent upon those giving legal advice to urge native people to issue a claim? Otherwise the legal advisers themselves may face an action for negligence. It is the same sort of thing that happens in Victoria when there is an abolition of common law. As soon as there is a threat to a particular right of action, everybody has to take a right of action early. That is the history of these things. If we put a six-year period on native title claims, there is encouragement for there to be a lot more claims made than otherwise would be, because people just do not have the time and the ability to search this thing through.

SPEECH.PARA: So I say to Senator Boswell that, far from getting a clarification in six years, what you are going to get is a claim made to ensure that nobody overlooks native title that may be there. So everybody who may have a title has to claim. That is going to cause a lot of time to be taken up and a lot of expense to be incurred. If you doubt that, you can look at the history of where you take away a right of action after a particular period of time.
While I am on my feet, can I ask the minister how the rules of evidence in proposed section 82 fit in with proposed section 86? Proposed section 82(1) states:
The Federal Court is bound by the rules of evidence, except to the extent that the Court otherwise orders.

Then proposed section 86 states that, subject to subsection 82(1), the Federal Court may receive a whole body of evidence which would otherwise not be acceptable. Those two sections need to be married together in a tidier fashion than they presently are.

Could I then ask about the strike-out application that must be heard before anything else is taken. Doesn't this enable strike-out applications to be made in a manner that is quite different from the way strike-out applications are normally made in court? In saying that strike‐out application must be made before anything else happens, you are treating these sorts of claims differently from other claims that you might treat because you give priority to an application to strike out. Proposed section 84C states, `If an application does not comply with section 61, 61A or 62'—that would be the basis of your claim—then:

BREAK.PARA: The Court must, before any other proceeding takes place in relation to the main application, consider the application made under subsection (1).

So the court must hear the strike‐out application, no matter what the evidence and no matter what the situation. The final point is the issue of costs, where each side has to pay its own costs. Doesn't that clearly make the whole proceedings under this legislation much more available to those with deep pockets? I would be grateful if you could give me answers on those three points.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a couple of points, partly in response to Senator Cooney's remarks. I understand Senator Cooney's point of view in relation to the sunset clause, which we have heard quite a few times, but it is important for us to have a bit of commonsense here. The Native Title Act has already been in operation for some four years. We are going to add another six years in which claims can be made, making a total of 10 years. If you cannot get a claim to the stage where you lodge it within a period of 10 years, why should we assume that, at some date 40 years down the track, a person is going to be better able to prove the claim, especially when much of the evidence relies upon people who are in their 50s and 60s? So these people will not be around in 40 years time and it will be even harder to make a claim.

SPEECH.PARA: But the more important point is this: without a sunset clause on claims under the Native Title Act, we have a double jeopardy. What happens is that you subject a person to multiple claims. The law abhors double jeopardy. The sunset clause is in the existing legislation because it was intended that double jeopardy would work only against the Commonwealth; in other words, the only people who would be prejudicially affected would be the Commonwealth.

What has happened now is that we subject private individuals to double jeopardy because claims are being made against pastoral leases. That is unfair and unreasonable. It is contrary to the good principles of law in this country. So to vote against the sunset clause is to vote for double jeopardy. Claims under the act, as opposed to claims under common law, attract particular advantages, such as the right to negotiate. It would be unreasonable to subject people to double jeopardy with a double right to negotiate.

I understand the point about competing and overlapping claims that Senator Woodley has made, but Senator Woodley forgets the fact that, as soon as one applicant has made a claim in relation to an area, other potential applicants are required to make their claims under the provisions of the act as it already stands. Importantly, efforts also have to be made to ascertain whether there are other potential claimants at that point in time. Although I understand Senator Woodley's argument, it is not an argument against the sunset clause over claims under this act. That is the important point we have to bear in mind.

Finally, while we understand all the points that have been made in relation to evidence, you also have to understand one other thing, which is that under the act as it currently stands the rules of evidence do not really apply. For example, the court would be forced to take uncorroborated hearsay evidence, and that again is not fair when private individuals are subjected to those rules. It is all right for the Crown to say, `We are happy to entertain these things'—and that is what was done under the previous government—but it is not all right to say that private individuals who fund their own defence, as opposed to claimants who are principally funded through land councils and hence from the government, should be made subject to uncorroborated hearsay evidence and some of the other problems that we get. That is why the amendments that the government has in this bill are necessary. That is why these sections of the bill should stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to comment on some of the statements made by Senator Boswell. He talked about the nightmare. I am hearing from various indigenous people who have been writing to me, ringing my office and visiting my office that the nightmare is theirs: the nightmare of the prospect of what might happen as a result of this legislation going through—even though it is not going anywhere except to the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no necessity for there to be a nightmare for the operation of pastoral leases. There is no need for the existence of the Wik High Court decision to influence the ability of pastoralists to borrow money. Banking representatives have stated quite clearly that the viability of pastoral leases is the main—and often the only—criterion which is necessary for banks to decide in determining whether or not to lend money to pastoral leaseholders. Many people are aware of the fact that when this excuse is gone—the government's excuse that the problems with the viability of pastoral leases is a problem of native title—by way of shovelling the bucket loads of extinguishment through this legislation, they will then have to explain to those remaining pastoralists why they are still unviable. They will not have the excuse any more of blaming indigenous Australians.

The nightmare, I contend, is not a nightmare of coexistence. The nightmare has been created by whipping up the fears and prejudice of people in Australia as a result of the way this bill has been written and presented to the Australian public. The nightmare must exist for those people in indigenous Australia who know that they may well only be in the process of setting up or trying to establish a corporation to deal with their land claims. We know that there are negotiations in the way if such land claims work in relation to rep bodies. There are models being worked out as to how these can work better within the rep body situation.

We know that many of the problems associated with the working out of claims are associated with the severe lack of resources that exist within rep bodies. If you listened to the minister, you would think there was lots of money available for rep bodies to run their cases. If you listened you would think there were resources rolling out of the doors in relation to rep bodies being able to represent the clans and the groups who want to be represented. Quite clearly, Senator Cooney is right: if you were to succeed in putting a sunset clause in this bill you would force many people who are not in a position to best put their case to put an ill‐prepared case forward to the court.

That is not a very wise way for anyone to go, especially if what you are seeing in this group of amendments is the government trying to pick off and strike out those people who may have made an error in putting together their case. It is a bit like Senator Newman boasting how many thousands of people she has knocked off social security this week for technical faults in their applications and so on—boasting that that is a great thing to do. It is not the right way to go about things.

There is, in fact, more than one sunset clause dealt with in this section—section 2(3) is one where there is a level of agreement. But I would also call your attention to the fact that the sunset clause is also mentioned in Democrats' and Greens (WA) amendment 192 as well. That involves the removal of the sunset clause on applications for compensation, so we are not going to be just dealing with one sunset clause in this group of amendments. It appears the majority of the Senate will move to remove the sunset clause on applications for a determination, but I do still urge that the majority of the Senate support either opposition amendment 225 or Democrats/Greens amendment 192 in relation to the sunset clause on applications for compensation as well, because the same kinds of issues relate also to sunset clauses for those issues.

There are many issues which will come up in relation to the debate on so‐called uncorroborated hearsay evidence that Senator O'Chee referred to. I think it is an indictment of the understanding of members of the opposition of how people speak for the land to say that there is a necessity for corroboration in relation to people's knowledge and spiritual understanding of the land for which they speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Though not handling the bill for the Democrats, I do wish to make a couple of comments on what Senator Boswell said, because it comes to the heart of the government's problem with uncertainty and the continuing claim that this bill is to deal with the issue of uncertainty.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw Senator Boswell's attention to the Wik decision, which said that if there was conflict between what the pastoralist wanted to do under his or her lease and the native title claim, then the pastoral lease prevails. But it is not quite that simple because some pastoral leases apparently, particularly in Queensland, are not that clear. Indeed, my information is that in some of the early native title claims there were not even maps available when the claimants went to various departments looking for the lease map. People had to go back to square one and start looking. That was one of the major hold‐ups for some of the early claims.

What I would like to suggest to Senator Boswell is that he takes out some of this angst on state governments, particularly the Queensland government, and that state governments make it clear to their pastoralists exactly what their leases involve and allow them to do, because the amount of fear and concern whipped up, particularly in Queensland, over what can and cannot be done, can often be tracked back to what their entitlement actually is under their pastoral lease. It is much simpler in South Australia, so our people do not have so many worries but, certainly in Queensland, some of the whole sensitivity and hype over uncertainty goes back to administrative problems within departments. I would like to recommend to Senator Boswell that he looks a little bit more closely at what some of the problems are, particularly in his home state.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I respond to Senator Cooney's queries of a relatively technical nature in relation to the rules of evidence and the interrelationship between sections 82 and 86. It is as it states. The fact is that the court may take account of all this other evidence listed in 86 if it otherwise complies with the rules of evidence, but, of course, there remains the discretion to order otherwise in relation to the rules of evidence. We are simply saying that all those items can be considered if they comply with the normal rules of evidence, but residual discretion remains upon the court, so the relationship is clear.

SPEECH.PARA: The strike‐out provision: yes, it is government policy that, in relation to the question of someone seeking to exercise their right to ask the court to strike out a claim, then the court has got to hear that strike‐out. We do think that is essential so that, if any party believes a claim is not a valid or fair claim, they can bring their action and that should be heard. Once that is heard, then the claim can proceed. It is simply saying that we think it is appropriate that, where a party affected by a claim believes that the claim does not comply with the rules relating to claims, then that matter should be heard first before the claim proceeds. Once that is dealt with, then, of course, the claim can proceed. So it is a matter of clear government policy which we think is quite appropriate.

In relation to costs, I am not quite sure of the tenor of the question, but basically our proposition is that each party shall bear their own costs. But, of course, again we leave the discretion with the court. The court can otherwise order. What we are on about here is giving discretion to the Federal Court to determine how it best should conduct these sorts of proceedings, taking proper account of their unique nature. We lay down some prima facie positions, but at the end of the day it is for the courts to decide—and we do give the courts the requisite discretion. Again, we think that appropriate.

I indicate to the committee that we could not agree with Democrat amendment 214. For reasons that we do not quite understand, it seeks to prevent local government bodies automatically being able to be parties to a claims process. I think if you have spent any time on the ground around Australia talking to communities affected by native title claims, you will very quickly realise how important local government is in this process—how it is affected, most particularly, by native title claims and why there is every reason local government should have the automatic right to be a party to a claims process if they so choose.

BREAK.PARA: We do not really understand why there would be any attempt to make it harder for local government to be involved if they so desire. I applaud what the Local Government Association is doing in relation to native title: they are taking native title quite seriously and they are doing a lot to educate their own communities about native title to dispel the fears about native title on both sides. I congratulate the local government bodies around the country for their very constructive role in helping educate the community on this issue and their constructive role in native title issues and in mediations. So I think that amendment 214 ought not to be supported and the government's proposal should stand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to be helpful here, I indicate that, as I mentioned in my comments earlier, the Greens accept opposition amendment 247 as it covers most of what we want to achieve from that section, so there is probably no need to put the Greens (WA) and Democrat amendment 214.

—Thank you, Minister, for the answers to those questions. The point that I raised, and that Senator Margetts explained, was the point about the sunset clause. Hopefully the court will sort out a lot of the issues about evidence and striking out, but the court cannot sort out the sunset provisions. If you look at issues such as the removal of common law rights, the history is that once you put limitations on, taking away a right of action, you are going to have people issuing proceedings to make sure that they have got it covered, in any event, to protect themselves from negligence claims. If 79 per cent of Australia—according to the Prime Minister and Senator Boswell—may be subject to native title claims, isn't this a recipe to ensure that you are going to get claims made simply to protect the claimant's position and to protect the solicitor from copping—if I can use that word—a negligence action?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, I stress that there is no negation or termination of common law rights involved in this process. I think that has been acknowledged by the ALP. We are not, in any way, preventing common law claims for native title being brought ad infinitum to the end of history. But we do believe, as a public policy, it is appropriate that, 10 years after the Native Title Act came into effect, we set a deadline on the lodgment of claims made under the auspices of the Native Title Act per se. So there is no negation of the common law right; it is simply saying, effectively, administratively, that if you want to bring your claim under the auspices of this Commonwealth act then you should do so, and that you should effectively lodge that claim within 10 years after the act originally came into effect.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, if you look at what has happened in the four years since the act came into effect, 45 per cent of Australia is under claim. I think 667 is the latest number of claims—a huge number of claims individually. So two‐thirds of what we understand to be the area claimable has already been claimed in this four years. We are saying, `In another six years we would encourage you to bring your claims so that everybody knows what is being claimed, where and when.' The quite huge infrastructure that the nation has established to deal with these claims can then deal with them, for however long that takes. We are spending $40 million a year on representative bodies to bring claims and $20 million a year on the tribunal.
