I do not know how much money the Federal Court is going to spend on native title claims every year, but obviously that will be substantial. So there is a huge national investment in this process.

It is not unreasonable, having set up that infrastructure and devoted those sorts of resources, that by the end of six years from the commencement of this act we know what claims are proposed under the auspices of this act. I think there is undue criticism of the government on this score because it is not in any way a termination of common law rights. As I say, people can go on bringing common law claims for native title for ever, but obviously there is an incentive to do so under the act and we wish to provide an incentive to do so within that six‐year period.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Those in the chamber understand the situation about native title rights being common law rights and negotiation rights being statutory rights, but we also know that native title is not much good to anyone without the right to negotiate.

SPEECH.PARA: In this legislation, we are trying to make that statutorily certain and to make the procedures as economic and efficient as possible. If you kept the sunset clause, you could have claimants under common law after that date. Claimants could go to the High Court. Is it not a fact that the High Court could not only decide the issue, but it could also decide what flows from the issue—including how to determine the rights and interests of particular groups, how they should be balanced and what processes should be used?

I point out to Senator Boswell that we are trying to deal with the matter with as much certainty as possible. One of the major purposes of the native title regime, which was established under the Native Title Act of 1993, was to facilitate agreements about claims and about future acts and procedures. The alternative would have been a reliance on the common law, with a significant amount of cases ultimately put before the courts and a huge amount of litigation concerning future acts.

Ending the ability of native title holders to access a regime under the act would deny them certain statutory rights, including the right to negotiate concerning future acts. Despite the fact that under the government's proposed amendments the statutory right to negotiate will be diminished, it will remain a significant right where applicable. It recognises the special attachment of indigenous people to their country. As I said at the beginning, native title rights are worth very little without negotiation rights.

The government's proposed sunset clause of six years for native title applications is both unnecessary and beyond the pale. It is unnecessary because, as Senator Minchin suggested in evidence to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title, most, if not all, native title claims may have been lodged by the date of expiry of the sunset provision. He indicated to the committee that most of them may well have been lodged by that date. Senator Minchin has emphasised to the committee here today that a very large number of claims have been lodged, covering substantial areas of Australia.

That being the case, this proposal would achieve very little, even were the option of resort to the common law unavailable. As Senator Cooney has indicated, resort to the common law will always be available, including for future acts. Senator Minchin confirmed that in evidence to the joint committee at page 201. In those circumstances, all parties to native title applications, including pastoralists and farmers, are inconvenienced.

No good purpose is served by the sunset clause proposal that is currently before us. Not only would the sunset proposal achieve the undesirable goal of propelling new claims into the court processes, but it would offend native title holders. After more than 200 years of dispossession, we would in effect be saying to indigenous people that no provision will be made to allow claims to be submitted for mediation after an arbitrary date. In the name of reconciliation, I believe that is unjustifiable. The sunset clause, as far as I am concerned, will be opposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the opposition will be opposing government amendments Nos 61, 62, 63 and 65, but will not be opposing the others in this block. Amendments Nos 61 and 62 are essentially minor amendments which go to adding the word `unduly'. Amendment No. 63, which I raised concerns about earlier, is about giving a strike‐out capacity on no criteria at all. Amendment No. 65 is about a presidential member having to be a judge. I suggest that we deal with those amendments individually and separately, and deal with the rest of the government amendments together, unless other honourable senators wish otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Concerning amendment 63, I have a bit of a problem with the proposal. The amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: A person who is, and has been for at least 5 years, enrolled as a legal practitioner of the High Court, of another federal court or of the Supreme Court of a State or Territory.

I heard what Senator Margetts said. We are all interested in the procedures being expedited with fairness, with efficiency and with a just outcome. We are also interested in the question of not making the procedures daunting, particularly to those who may not be used to going into a court. On that basis, I thought that the government's proposition might assist those people and assist that informal process. I would like to hear the minister's response to what Senator Margetts said in her opposition to amendment 63.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —This proposition was adopted by the previous Keating government in response to the fact that, contrary to the formulation originally proposed in the Native Title Act that the tribunal would be a determining body, Brandy made that impossible. In fact, that part of the Native Title Act was effectively unconstitutional—the tribunal could not make determinations. As agreed by the previous government and as set in place by our bill—and I think these parts are generally agreed—the tribunal is effectively a mediation service for native title claims and, with its ultimate arbitration role on the right to negotiate aspect, determinations are made by the court. So it is not a court; it is no longer a court.

SPEECH.PARA: Justice French has publicly advocated the proposition before the Senate that it is much more appropriate, given the new role of the tribunal as essentially a mediation service, that governments should have more flexibility in appointing the presidential member. Indeed, there is an internal contradiction in what is being put to us. There is an argument for maximum informality, relaxation of rules and all that sort of thing, both in the court and in the tribunal but, on the other hand, there is an insistence that a Federal Court judge be the president of the tribunal.

Our point is that the most appropriate person to run the tribunal—which now has this very significant role in the mediation of claims; that is its primary purpose—may well not be a judge. There is the practical issue of the enormous pressure on the Federal Court in terms of finding a judge, taking a judge out of the system. In many respects, this job may well be better performed by someone who is not a judge and has much greater administrative experience—running the tribunal is a huge administrative task, if you have visited the tribunal and seen what is involved—and also much greater experience in mediation in the more informal way in which it is advocated and supported by other parties.

We do not think that doing this in any way lessens the status of the tribunal. Under the new arrangements, the Federal Court is responsible for determinations and supervises and oversees every claim. The tribunal works to the court as a mediation service and it is only sensible to provide any government with flexibility to ensure that it can get the best possible person for that job. The tribunal would still be a key part of the process and its status is in no way diminished by this.

We rejected the proposition put from a range of sources that it ought be called the `Native Title Mediation Service'. We thought it would be more appropriate to keep the name `tribunal' to maintain that level of status. There are plenty of quite important bodies in the community which perform similar functions of equal importance where there is no requirement to have a judge at their head.

We did think that this is an important provision and we are disappointed that that sort of ill‐motive is again being attributed to us in relation to it. There are some very fine people in Australia who would be able to serve well—and I would have thought would be supported by all parties—in doing this job who are not currently Federal Court judges. It seems crazy not to be able to consider them for appointment to this position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition has some views on this and it is important to put them on the record. If you are looking for the consistency that Senator Minchin talks about, I do not think you will find it in this debate. Whereas you could quite validly say of us that we want informality, we could say of you that you want maximum formality in your rules, but you do not want to have a judge at the top.
—We are talking about the Federal Court.

—A Federal Court judge at the top. This particular issue is one where there are a whole range of divergent views which are important to it. You have to look at the nature of the job which—let's face it—is the hottest issue in town at the moment. It has been for some time and will continue to be into the future. Because of that, we have reconsidered the status of the position and who should be at the top of the tree in the tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, look at the most recent debate we had in the last week or so on whether native title can be claimed on someone's backyard. It was, amongst other things, the voice of reason of Justice French, together with the fact that he is a judge, which had a very telling effect on the public debate on that particular issue. Issues like that will continue to evolve as we go along. To have someone of that status—because of which they will be listened to in the community—is going to be extremely important.

Not the least of reasons why we have changed our position here is that the climate has changed. It has heated up enormously in the last two years and that is one of the reasons why we think someone at the top with the status of a judge would engender the sort of respect that will be needed for this important job, both in terms of certainty to the players and in terms of public education.

In terms of the flexibility, that is important. I am glad you mentioned that, Senator Minchin. If you want to help the people involved in this debate, then you reject the government's rules on rules of evidence and the question about cultural evidence being a prerequisite. I think those two things are important. Let us also keep in mind that, while you have the person at the top, others in the tribunal are not judges. They are the people who, more often than not, do much of the work in the day‐to‐day operation of the tribunal.

BREAK.PARA: I think it is important to maintain a mixture, a blend. To ensure continued respect in the public debate as well as for the tribunal, we need to appoint a Federal Court judge. Much of the position that the opposition has taken is by no small means due to the work that has been done by Justice French and the leadership role that he has played over recent years, but particularly over recent weeks, in a very hot public debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Without doubt one of the most important groups of opinions that should be taken into consideration in relation to this issue is that of the people who are most affected by the outcome of the Native Title Tribunal—the indigenous people. The views of indigenous Australians and Commissioner Mick Dodson are very important. If flexibility is about assisting claimants to proceed, and if there were confidence that the changes that the government is planning to make would in fact move to that flexibility, and to that issue only, I guess there may be support for it.

SPEECH.PARA: I would disagree with Senator Minchin that there is no cause for doubt that the government would actually move to politicise the issue or to, potentially, remove the ability for indigenous Australians to have trust in the Native Title Tribunal. Remember that we have only recently—that is, on Friday—dealt with a situation in relation to the indigenous land use agreements, which were on a consensus basis, where the government said they could not allow a consensus agreement. So we already have a situation where we have voted to make it so that a company, a corporation, with quite a lot of resources, can pick off people in an agreement process, one by one.

Is there any doubt why indigenous Australians do not have trust in the motives of the government in relation to so‐called flexibility in these arrangements? If indigenous Australians are saying they want to have a person in that position who they believe cannot be influenced by the government in this very important process of decisions in relation to native title, then I believe we are obliged to listen to their concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the opinions on this subject, I guess the person who would know best the role, obligations and duties of the tribunal would be the incumbent president, Justice French. He is the strongest advocate of this change. He is the one who has certainly persuaded the government that it is a sensible change to make.

SPEECH.PARA: In case there is any misunderstanding in relation to the operation of the tribunal, can I make it clear that we are not changing the current arrangements for the tribunal itself in relation to its rules. We are leaving current 109(3) which says:
The Tribunal, in conducting an inquiry, is not bound by technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence.
That informality will continue with the tribunal itself in all its activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one question. I understand that Justice French has spoken to you about it but, if you look at the purposes of mediation set out in section 86A, all those issues upon which there is to be mediation are fairly technical issues. You would certainly need someone who knows his law, and who has the attributes of a judge, to guide people through them. It is mediation about who holds or held the native title and the nature and extent of any other interest in relation to the area. All those areas are technical ones, and you would have thought that the person who is helping with the mediation should have an appreciation of that. It is a bit like someone mediating in a building case—they at least need to know the building law before they help people with mediation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response, the tribunal has a whole host of people who deal with mediation. Justice French does not handle every mediation. The part‐time tribunal members, and others who handle these mediations, are not judges. Mediation goes on in the community in a whole range of fields of endeavour—commercial mediation and other things—by non‐judicial people. By definition, you are not adjudicating when you mediate. To suggest either that Justice French conducts every mediation or that the president is going to conduct every mediation and therefore he has to be a judge, does not accord with the reality. Nor does it accord with what goes on in the wider community in what is obviously a growing field of endeavour—that is, mediation. It is not necessarily best conducted by someone who is used to adjudicating.

—I am not saying that. What I am saying is that the government's bill has asked people to mediate not to necessarily get a particular result but to reach conclusions about matters which are very technical. To mediate in this area—I understand you have mediation elsewhere, say, in the Family Court and what have you—you would need to have someone who has an appreciation of the issues involved. How otherwise could they talk with the parties? It is a different matter if you were trying to mediate a civil assault case, but that is not what you are doing here. You have specifically set out in your legislation the purposes of mediation and they are all very technical things. I am trying to think in what other areas mediators are instructed to the extent that they are here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that government amendment No. 65 be voted upon separately. I am not inclined to support that amendment, as bald as it is before us. In respect of the other amendments, I think Senator Minchin's rolling up former Prime Minister Paul Keating and the current head of the tribunal, Mr Justice French, in support of them is a bit too much for me. I will be supporting those amendments.
—The question is that government amendments Nos 61, 62 and 63 be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 65 not agreed to.
Amendment No. 64 agreed to.
Amendments Nos 58, 71 and 72 agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that schedule 2, item 3, stand as printed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what we now have are the leftover opposition amendments. Apart from amendments Nos 247, 242, 248 and 249, which the government have said they would support, I suggest we put the rest of them together, unless of course Senator Harradine, Senator Margetts or Senator Woodley want to extract any. I think there is some indication from Senator Woodley, Senator Margetts and Senator Harradine that they may want to extract some of the opposition amendments out and treat them separately.

—It might be helpful if I suggest that opposition amendment 250 is in conflict with Greens and Democrat amendment 217. I would ask that consideration of ALP amendment 250 be put separately as I intend to vote against it. That is the only one that I need to separate out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the bill in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (296) Schedule 2, item 79, page 208 (line 2) to page 209 (line 6), omit the item.
(225) Schedule 2, item 9, page 141 (lines 7 to 15), TO BE OPPOSED .
(255) Schedule 2, item 25, page 176 (lines 8 to 14), TO BE OPPOSED .
(358) Schedule 5, items 18 and 19, page 339 (lines 14 to 21), TO BE OPPOSED .

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that schedule 2, items 9, 25 and 79 and, in schedule 5, items 18 and 19 stand as printed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Amendments (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:
(226) Schedule 2, page 141 (after line 18), after item 10, insert:

TAB.TAB: Add:

PARA.TAB: (2) If there are different native title groups holding native title in relation to an area of land or waters, the Court may make a single determination of native title or it may make separate determinations, as it thinks fit.

(3) If the Court proposes to make an approved determination of native title in favour of a particular native title group and there is already an approved determination of native title in relation to part or all of the area of land or waters concerned, the Court may, as it thinks fit:

TAB.TAB: (a) vary the existing determination; or
(b) make a further determination.

PARA.TAB: (4) If the Court varies a determination, makes a further determination or makes more than one determination in relation to a particular application, the Court must, if native title rights and interests exist in more than one native title group in relation to an area of land or waters:

TAB.TAB: (a) identify separately each group that holds the native title; and
(b) if the native title rights and interests are held jointly or concurrently by more than one group—include a statement to that effect; and
(c) if the native title rights and interests are held separately by 2 or more groups—identify which rights and interests are held by each group.

INTERJECT.PARA: (228) Schedule 2, item 19, page 145 (line 25), omit "A native title", substitute "Subject to section 55, a native title".
(241) Schedule 2, item 19, page 154, (line 11), omit "can", substitute "will generally".
(245) Schedule 2, item 19, page 157 (after line 3), at the end of section 68, add:

PARA.TAB: (2) An application may be made to vary a determination of native title so as to include a separate native title group.

(3) Despite subsection (1), if there are 2 or more groups entitled to a determination of native title in relation to areas that are not co‐extensive with one another, separate determinations may be made which may overlap in part.
(1) A person who seeks to enter and remain on land or waters and have access to any place on the land or waters for these purposes:

TAB.TAB: (a) to conduct any investigation or identify any place or thing on the land or waters for the purpose of considering or making a native title application; or
(b) to carry out anthropological or other research for the purposes of preparing a native title application or evidence in support of a native title application;
may apply to the NNTT for an authorisation under this section.

PARA.TAB: (2) Despite any law to the contrary, the NNTT may grant an authorisation to a person to enter and remain on the land or waters and have access to any place on the land or waters for those purposes if it is satisfied that:

TAB.TAB: (a) the person is seeking the authorisation in good faith for those purposes; and

(b) there is reason to believe that the person would not be allowed to enter and remain on the land or waters or have access to a place on the land or waters for those purposes without an authorisation under this section; and
(c) reasonable notice of the application has been given to a person who is apparently an occupier or owner of the land, or the land adjoining or surrounding the waters; and
(d) entry to the land or waters and access to a place on the land or waters is reasonably necessary for one or more of the purposes mentioned in subsection (1).

PARA.TAB: (3) An authorisation under this section must:

TAB.TAB: (a) identify with reasonable particularity:

(ii) the place or places to which the person is authorised to have access; and
(b) specify the purpose or purposes for which the authorisation is given; and

PARA.TAB: (4) If, for the purpose of considering an application or exercising any function under this Act, it is necessary for a court, tribunal or officer of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory to enter and remain on land or waters and have access to any place on the land or waters, either alone or with other persons, the court, tribunal or officer is, upon giving reasonable notice in writing, with such persons as are considered appropriate, to enter and remain on and have access to places on the land or waters.

(5) If any law requires that the custodian of a significant site or place, or any person having an association with the site by traditional law or custom, must give consent before another person has access to that site or place, this section does not permit such access unless the requirements of the law are complied with.

(6) Any person entitled to have access to land or waters under this section must, to the extent that it is possible without impeding the bona fide execution of the purposes for which access was obtained, comply with the reasonable requests of the occupier or owner of the land, or of the land adjoining or surrounding the waters, in relation to the means of access, the parts of the land or waters visited and the duration of the visit or visits.

INTERJECT.PARA: (246) Schedule 2, item 20, page 162 (lines 1 to 9), omit section 82, substitute:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Federal Court must pursue the objective of providing a mechanism of determination that is fair, just, economical, informal and prompt.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Concerns of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders

PARA.TAB: (2) The Court, in conducting proceedings, must take account of the cultural and customary concerns of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Court not bound by technicalities etc.

PARA.TAB: (3) The Court, in conducting proceedings, is not bound by technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence.

INTERJECT.PARA: (251) Schedule 2, item 20, page 166 (lines 1 to 5), omit subsection (2), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (2) An application may also be made to the Federal Court by:

TAB.TAB: (a) a Government party; or
(b) a person (other than a native title holder) who has an interest in the land or waters concerned;

to strike out an application (also the main application ) or part of it to the extent that it seeks a determination of native title in relation to land or waters over which native title rights and interests have been extinguished.

PARA.TAB: (2A) The Federal Court may make such orders as it thinks appropriate after considering an application under subsection (1), including:

TAB.TAB: (a) an order dismissing the application; and

PARA.TAB: (2B) The Federal Court may make such orders as it thinks appropriate after considering an application under subsection (2), including:

TAB.TAB: (a) an order striking out so much of the main application as seeks a determination of native title in relation to land or waters over which native title rights and interests have been extinguished; and
(b) an order permitting an amendment to the main application to exclude particular land or waters from a claim for determination of native title; and
(c) an order permitting an amendment to the main application to include a claim for compensation in relation to land or waters of that kind.

INTERJECT.PARA: (252) Schedule 2, item 20, page 166 (line 28), omit "Subject to subsection 82(1), the Federal Court may", substitute "The Federal Court may, in its discretion".
(253) Schedule 2, item 20, page 168 (lines 1 to 3), omit "to the extent that the area is not covered by a non-exclusive agricultural lease or a non-exclusive pastoral lease—".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned somewhat that what Senator Bolkus has said may be the result of this amendment 246 failing. The amendment is to omit section 82 from the government's bill and substitute, `82 Federal Court's way of operating', and of course it is the same heading. The opposition indicates that:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Federal Court must pursue the objective of providing a mechanism of determination that is fair, just, economical, informal and prompt.
They are very desirable objectives, and that:
(2) The Court, in conducting proceedings, must take account of the cultural and customary concerns of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders.
(3) The Court, in conducting proceedings, is not bound by technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence.
The government's provision in the bill states:

(2) In conducting its proceedings, the Court may take account of the cultural and customary concerns of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders, but not so as to prejudice any other party to the proceedings.

Is there any real difference between the two? I assume that the court will clearly have to have regard to certain things under the opposition's proposal, but it could not have regard to those factors to the prejudice of any other party to the proceedings, surely. Isn't that really a rule of justice? I would like to hear something on that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just make it clear that the Senate has now amended 82(2) to include the word `unduly'. So it is `not to prejudice unduly any other party', which is, in a sense, a softening. That is now in that section.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason why we moved these amendments is that there is a regime already there, and I have talked about that at length. That regime allows a certain degree of discretion in respect of the rules of evidence, particularly the hearsay rule. That is in recognition of the fact that cultural practices are passed on from mouth to mouth over centuries and become part of the spirit and traditions of the groups. As a consequence, not only in Australia but also internationally, there has been a recognition that the rules of court need to be flexible, particularly in respect of the hearsay rule but also in respect of other rules.

SPEECH.PARA: There is the other point that Senator Harradine mentioned earlier. When you are talking about the sorts of people we are talking about here, the court process would be a particularly alien one to them and it is important to maintain flexibility for that. Tied in with that is the situation now where the court has been instructed by the parliament to take into account cultural practices. Though there might be an amendment in loose terms, if we were to move away from the current position in this debate, we would be sending a message to the court to say, `The parliament has had a rethink and you ought to be a bit more cautious. Drag it back in terms of how you apply the rules of evidence. Be a little bit more rigid is the message coming from the parliament.' In respect of the customary practices, we would be saying, `The compulsion that the parliament felt that it was important to place there before we do not now feel is as important.' Basically, through this legislation we are sending a message to the courts and the tribunals, and that is something we have to take into account.

In terms of whether it affects the rights of others, the point here is that you have to get the balance right. To the extent that the voice, rights and practices of indigenous people cannot be heard under an inflexible regime, it is they who are missing out. The court and the tribunal will always balance a just result, but the impediment is the hurdles, and the way the indigenous Australians have their voice heard will be difficult to surmount if the changes take place.

Let us take into account the Northern Territory situation. With this native title regime, over years they have developed fair and comprehensive rules of practice which are quite flexible but really do accommodate indigenous Australians. They take into account the rights of others who are not the claimants. Senator Harradine, we would be sending the wrong message if we were to wind back this legislation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 7.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time we broke for dinner, I was rising to speak about the potential for problems if you have a situation where only some people are authorised to speak for their land on a certain issue, and it might be very difficult to corroborate the evidence in that instance where there really are only certain people authorised to speak for land. I just wanted to express that note of caution. If we are making this process more difficult, are we not going to have a problem with the process es by which land can be protected and looked after and the definition of those people who can speak for land? If it is not the case that the court accepts certain sorts of evidence that require otherwise corroboration, are we going to have a problem where we are denying the existence of traditional law?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just add to that. I was making the point before the dinner break that it really is important to allow a degree of flexibility. One concern that the opposition does have is that this particular proposal of the government's has been around for some time but it is based on a real misunderstanding of how stories are passed down and how song lines are passed through communities, generations and so on. Any rigid rule or any message from the parliament that would impinge on that would very much impinge on the capacity to maintain the customs and traditions.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that this is based on a misconception, and the misconception was founded three or four years ago when the current Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin, attacked the particular provision in the Native Title Act. At the time, on 15 December, he said:

. . . the bill instructs the Federal Court to take account of the cultural and customary concerns of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders and `is not bound by technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence'.
He went on to say:

What an unbelievable instruction from the parliament to the judiciary. It is a most reprehensible undermining of a superior court of this country, and really is, at its essence, contrary to the whole principle of the separation of the executive, legislature and judiciary. As I say, it confirms that this bill is fundamentally based on race.

My point is that I think the minister got it totally wrong in 1993—totally wrong as to his assessment of the provision, totally wrong as to the importance of it and totally wrong when he said it was a provision based on race. The provision in the act recognises the importance for the message to be given to the court. My concern is that, by taking any further step today, we would be unwinding that message and impinging heavily on the capacity for song lines as a basis of custom ary law, practice and tradition and consequently impinging, in the way Senator Margetts said, on a capacity to base the native title claim in some circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad my speech of four years ago is such a rich load of capital for the ALP. I never thought my words would live on in the way they have. Can I just say that the debate seems to be conducted on the basis that we are somehow ruling out the capacity of the court to consider the cultural and customary concerns of Aboriginal people, which is not what we are about. We are not about the application of some rigid rule, as Senator Bolkus suggested; we are about genuinely ensuring a proper discretion for the Federal Court in the hearing of native title claims, which you must remember now will, by definition as a result of the Wik decision, involve other title holders. These claims are being brought on land on which there are other title holders with their own interests that they wish to preserve, protect and defend in law, and the way in which these hearings are conducted must reflect that new fact.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not seeking to direct the court in the way in which the original act was drawn up—which may well have been appropriate, given that it was only ever contemplated that, effectively, claims would be brought on vacant crown land or Aboriginal land. We now have an entirely different situation. Our response to that is to give the court the discretion that it ought to have in the way it handles these matters and in the way it develops the law to appropriately accommodate the whole range of interests which will come before the court and which we are seeing in these hearings. Obviously, people will need to and want to come to court to defend what they see as their rights; also those native title claimants will come to court to proclaim their rights.
Our proposed section 82, which is what we appear to be debating, does say that the court has that discretion. It states:

BREAK.PARA: (1) The Federal Court is bound by the rule of evidence, except to the extent that the Court otherwise orders.
There is a complete discretion to the court. And:
(2) In conducting its proceedings, the Court may take account of the cultural and customary concerns of Aboriginal peoples—

So it has a complete discretion in the matter and the only limitation on that discretion is that it should not do so in a way which would unduly prejudice any other party to the proceedings. I cannot conceive how you could regard such a proposition as unreasonable or unfair. We have a whole range of interests which need to be taken into account. What we are doing is giving the court the appropriate discretion to balance all those interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —To just import what was in the previous 1993 act is, as Senator Minchin has said, really to fail to know that we are in a different ball game at present. It was obvious that in 1993 the government had a view about what Mabo did. That view clearly was not that native title could coexist, as I hear it. As Senator Minchin said, the government's legislation now gives the court power to deal with these situations as they arise and to do so, obviously, with respect and consideration to the culture of the persons who are making the claim—that is, the indigenous persons.

SPEECH.PARA: Yes, I acknowledge that I voted for the word `unduly' to go into the provision. I think it is only fair that that word should have been incorporated. With that word I think, under the circumstances, I will be voting against the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I must admit that I have a bit of trouble understanding the position there. Senator Harradine, you say it is a different ball game, but I do not know what you actually mean by that in the context of this debate. The different ball game is that we have had a few years to see the provision in operation, not just nationally but also, for instance, under the Northern Territory Land Rights Act. I think the common experience is: to the extent that you have a non-adversarial process, you maximise the capacity for people to be able to produce their claims. Otherwise it really unfairly impinges upon that capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: My point in response to Senator Minchin was that we as a parliament would be sending a message to the tribunals and courts that we thought it was time for a bit of unwinding of the previous position. Senator Harradine, I wonder whether that is what you are saying—`We have a different ball game now, so let's unwind it.' If you are saying that, I think that is a matter of concern because there is no real evidence to lead to that conclusion. If you are not saying that, I think for us to accept the government's provisions in unwinding those two areas of the law which provide for total discretionary flexibility would be an unhealthy thing for this parliament to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —In the debate we had on the Hindmarsh Island bill we debated whether or not the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander natural heritage bill should be able to incorporate the ability to deal under law with the traditional law and practices of indigenous Australians. Interestingly enough, since that bill and in questioning the government, they found it all too difficult to even ask various people what they believed about Justice Elizabeth Evatt's report in dealing with the traditional law. They found it all too hard.

SPEECH.PARA: Ironically, in the meantime it was very easy for the government to come up snap with proposals that will limit even further the court's ability to deal with things like heritage issues in a way that acknowledges and honours traditional law in Australia. So it is quite clear that the government is saying these traditional practices are not legitimate.

The words `may' and `must' are quite important in this process. If a court must take into consideration traditional law, then it is quite clear that it provides means of dealing with that. It is quite clear that it must provide the ability for people to express traditional law. It must be quite clear that it needs to provide people to translate so they can tell their stories in their own words. `Must' is important in the way the law operates if we are going to honour and value traditional law. It seems that this government has no honour or value for traditional law.

BREAK.PARA: The word `may' means that somebody has to first fight the battle for the right of people to express their own words and values by their own methods. That is where the word `may' is most important. I urge the Senate to accept and value that there are more things than dreamt of in our heaven and earth. By this method we are saying that traditional law in Australia is not valued or that they must argue in advance that they can or should be able to use traditional law. I do not think that is good enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I have a response from Minister Minchin in respect of that point Senator Margetts has made? As she has indicated, 82(2) does use the word `may'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: In conducting its proceedings, the Court may take account of the cultural and customary concerns of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders, but not so as to prejudice any other party to the proceedings.

I assume that these are procedural matters that we are talking about—proceedings before the court and the prior proceedings. Why shouldn't the court take into account those cultural and customary concerns? As a general rule, why shouldn't it actually take those into consideration?

If the word were `must', then there may be some need to qualify the word `concerns'. For the purposes of the record so that we are not sending the wrong message to the court, I wonder whether the minister could give the committee an indication that it is the intention of the government and the parliament to have as a general rule the court actually taking account of the cultural and customary concerns of the Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders.

I suppose the question also arises: what then makes the court proceedings unworkable? I can see that point, but I do not know of any cultural or customary concerns of Aboriginal people making the court processes unworkable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important to remember that in 82(2) we are talking about the conduct of proceedings. It is our view that the legislature should give the court the appropriate discretion as to the way in which it conducts its proceedings. This is, of course, separate from the actual determination of native title. Because native title is the common law recognition of the traditional law and custom of Aboriginal people, in reaching a determination as to whether claimants hold native title, a court cannot avoid the inquiry as to the traditional law and custom.

SPEECH.PARA: In the conduct of its proceedings, we do believe, as a matter of proper balance as to the legislature and the executive and the judiciary, that the judiciary should be granted the appropriate discretion in this matter. We have said that in conducting its proceedings the court can take account of the cultural and customary concerns of Aboriginal people, but it should do so in a way that does not unduly prejudice other parties which are seeking to defend other interests when they come before the court.

So it really is from a point of principle about the relationship between the legislature and the judiciary. The legislature says, `We believe it is a matter for the court to use its discretion in the way in which it conducts its proceedings.' Obviously there should be discretion to take account of those cultural and customary concerns in the conduct of its proceedings, but it should not unduly prejudice others. That is separate and apart from all the issues which it would have to take into account in making its determination which by definition, in determining whether someone holds native title, will involve an inquiry into the traditional law and custom and the common law recognition of those in any particular case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add further to the debate. It is important to the actual running of the proceedings that it occurs this way. We have to remember that we have already dealt with the application section. We asked questions and Senator Brown asked questions as to why spiritual values could not be included in the application as to what trips over the line, if you like, and we were told that that would come later. We were told that physical connection, not spiritual connection, was necessary. Already spiritual connection crosses on the applications, and now we are saying that it is discretionary.

SPEECH.PARA: Remember, as has been pointed out, that the judges who are dealing with this issue are not indigenous Australians. There are no indigenous Australian judges. It may be too difficult for judges to deal with this. If there is no requirement or expectation that these must be taken into consideration, we will not necessarily get a situation where the court has with it the skills and resources to provide this service. Remember that the parliament's own Joint Committee on Native Title went to Broome and did not even think it was important enough to listen to the evidence given to them in the language of the people giving it. This is the kind of thing we are talking about.

If it is not required, there will not be that mechanism. If we have that mechanism in the courts as a natural process, as a resource available to the courts, it will happen. It will not always be necessary and it will not always be used. I would argue that, if it is not in there as a requirement, this process will not be there as a natural mechanism by which the courts operate. I believe that would be a travesty of justice in this very important issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to point out that one of our great difficulties with the ALP amendment is that it removes the qualification in 82(2)—that is, in taking account of cultural and customary concerns, it should not do so in such a way as to unduly prejudice any other party to the proceedings. That is completely absent in relation to the effect of the ALP amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that is quite inappropriate. We believe it is very important that the court understands that it has a range of interests before it and that certainly it should have the discretion to take account of cultural and customary concerns. We think it is very important to make it clear that that should not operate in a way which would unduly prejudice any other party to the proceedings. The problem with the ALP amendment is that it is removed entirely from the bill. We think that would be quite unfair and potentially prejudicial to other parties to the proceedings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear what Senator Minchin is saying, and I take account of what was said by Senator Bolkus and Senator Margetts. Unless there is anything else said in the committee that is ultimately persuasive, I am inclined now to vote against the proposal by Senator Bolkus and to move a further amendment to 82 in the bill to delete the word `may' in line 6 on page 162 and insert the word `must'.

SPEECH.PARA: In this narrow area on procedure, I believe it does attend to the matters raised by Senator Bolkus. As Senator Margetts said, the question of language is a very important question in the procedural sense. I did hear what Senator Minchin was saying. There is need to take account of the rights of other parties to the proceedings. The words would continue to be in there but not so as to unduly prejudice any other party to the proceedings. I indicate that at this time I will be opposing the opposition's amendment, and I foreshadow an amendment to 82 along those lines.

TALK.START.PARA: —In summary, our concern is that, by not having these cultural and customary practices taken into account, you unduly prejudice the capacity of the title claimant to make a claim. It is the other side that we are concerned about. But, having said that and knowing that our amendment has gone down, we are prepared to support Senator Harradine's foreshadowed amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government believes its wording is satisfactory but, in the circumstances, we would not oppose Senator Harradine's foreshadowed amendment.

—I remind the chamber that what the minister is suggesting is that Aboriginal cultural values expressed in a court would unduly prejudice a judge. He is suggesting that the Labor Party amendments could unduly prejudice the courts. It is not a jury court; it is a judge. You are suggesting that the necessity to include Aboriginal cultural values would unduly prejudice a judge in those cases. I find the situation ludicrous. The absence of that is more likely to be a problem in terms of the way that justice is served. The issue mentioned in the Labor Party's amendment about the court not being bound by technicalities and rules of evidence is also important. I would be concerned if the Labor Party's amendment was lost in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just make it clear that we are not talking about unduly prejudicing the judge. The words are clear: `not so as to prejudice any other party to the proceedings'.
—Well there is no jury. Who are you going to unduly prejudice?

—Many of these proceedings have hundreds of other parties all with their own legal interests at stake, which they have every legal right to protect. We are not talking about the judge. The words are `any other party to the proceedings'—that is, those who have other title to the land. That is the point that we keep stressing.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a completely different situation from 1993. We now have the capacity, which our bill allows, for native title claims to be made over land on which there are other titleholders. Obviously, they have an interest in the proceedings, a right to appear and a right to defend the title they hold. Their interests must be taken account of in any hearing. All we are saying is that, sure, based on Senator Harradine's proposal, cultural and customary concerns must be taken account of in the conduct of the proceedings, but not so as to unduly prejudice any other party. That seems entirely reasonable and fair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to clarify that: the people making the decision in the court decisions are the judge; the people coming into the court have their own opinions. The reality is that unduly prejudicing them is not going to make a bit of difference.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment (by Senator Harradine) proposed:
Schedule 2, item 20, page 162 (line 6), omit "may", substitute "must".

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to urge the chamber that the words used in the Labor Party's amendment—that the court not be bound by technicalities and rules of evidence—also be included in that amendment.
—They have just been defeated, haven't they?

—I know that the amendment has just been defeated. I am just wondering whether it is possible to amend the government's amendment to include those words—`that the court not be bound by technicalities and rules of evidence'. I am just trying to find the actual words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Margetts raises is an important point which can live with the point raised by Senator Harradine and responded to by the government. I can understand how Senator Harradine wants to mesh `must' with the other aspects of the government's provision which does pick up the `cultural and customary practices'. But what this provision does not pick up from the Labor Party amendment is that aspect in respect of `technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence'.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Margetts's foreshadowed amendment, which I suppose is an addendum to Senator Harradine's amendment, would cover all points. It would cover Senator Harradine's concerns with `cultural and customary concerns'. If we can put in `technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence' as well, then we have a regime whereby the court will not be unnecessarily hampered by such processes but will also have that rider of protecting any undue interference with the rights of others. I do not know whether Senator Margetts has been able to work out where to put the words whilst I have been speaking, but I hope she has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I have found the words; I have yet to work out exactly how to put them in. I would like to take the form of the words from Labor's amendment No. 246:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Court not bound by technicalities etc.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) The Court, in conducting proceedings, is not bound by technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence.
I would like to add that to the bill but I will have to find out exactly where to put that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was part of a Labor amendment which has just been defeated. We are now putting up amendments, again, which have just been knocked off.
—That's quite okay. The Senate is allowed to do that you know.
—We have already voted on that and defeated it. We will be here until the Christmas after next if we keep putting up amendments a second time after they have been defeated. Subclause 82(1) says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Court is bound by the rules of evidence, except to the extent that the Court otherwise orders.

That is the appropriate expression, in the government's view, as to the nature of the discretion which the court shall have in relation to evidence. Again, it reflects the fact that we are now dealing with a new situation with many additional parties involved in native title matters. It retains the discretion to the court in the appropriate way and the Labor amendment to delete that and return to the old wording has been defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We do have a new concept and what I suggest is that basically we to do to 82(1) what Senator Harradine has essentially done to 82(2), so that 82(1) would read:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Court, in conducting proceedings, is not bound by technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence, but not so as to prejudice unduly any other party to the proceedings.

We pick up that rider of the government and we water down the obligation in respect to rules of evidence of the government and replace that with one part of the Labor Party amendment. So I will move that motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government would oppose the amendment for the reasons we have enunciated and for the reasons why we voted against the earlier Labor amendment to reintroduce the current wording.

SPEECH.PARA: We think the current wording of 82(1) is the right balance and the right approach to this question of the discretion available to the court. We do believe that, now that we are dealing with native title claims which affect a whole range of other interests, we are not dealing with a situation which was that which the parliament faced before, where really it was a matter between governments and native title claimants, because you are essentially with Aboriginal land and vacant crown land. We now have land on which there are many other title holders and the Federal Court's rulings will have a significant legal effect. Therefore, prima facie, the normal way in which courts operate should operate, that is, the rules of evidence apply. But we do acknowledge that, because these are particular matters of a special nature, the court should be given a discretion by the legislature to otherwise order, in other words, to give it the discretion to set aside the normal rules of evidence. We think the wording in the section is the right balance, gives the right emphasis and the right relationship between the application of the normal rules of evidence, because you are dealing with the interests of whole range of other parties now, but that, again, the court should have a discretion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, I presume you are foreshadowing an amendment?
—I am foreshadowing an amendment to subsection 82(1).

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —No. Senator Harradine's amendment was to subclause 82(2). The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Harradine in respect of subclause 82(2) be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Amendment (by Senator Bolkus) not agreed to:

BREAK.PARA: Schedule 2, item 20, page 162 (lines 3 and 4), omit subsection 82(1), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Federal Court, in conducting proceedings, is not bound by technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence, but not so as to prejudice unduly any other party to the proceedings.

BREAK.PARA: Amendments (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
(242) Schedule 2, item 19, page 154, (line 21), after "(5)", insert "or (5B)".
(247) Schedule 2, item 20, page 163 (line 18), omit "paragraph 66(3)(a)", substitute "subparagraph 66(3)(a)(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v) or (vi)".
(248) Schedule 2, item 20, page 163 (lines 21 and 22), omit subparagraph (iii).
(249) Schedule 2, item 20, page 164 (lines 3 to 5), omit subsection (5), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (5) Another person is a party to the proceedings if the person satisfies the Federal Court that he or she has an interest (see section 253) in relation to the land or waters concerned or a part of them.

(5A) If the relevant Minister is a party, a person is not entitled to be a party to the proceedings only because he or she exercises or enjoys a public right of access to, or use of, the land or waters concerned.

(5B) If, in the absence of a relevant Minister, there are persons seeking to be joined to represent those enjoying public interests, the Federal Court may give directions to ensure that their interests are properly represented, but need not join more than one person to represent a particular interest.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:
(250) Schedule 2, item 20, page 165 (lines 25 and 26), omit ", 61A (which provides that certain applications must not be made)".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of amendment No. 250, I believe the National Indigenous Working Group's compromise amendment could prevent what could be a very unjust provision. I have mentioned before that, if other ameliorating amendments especially do not eventuate in relation to the bill from the rest of the Senate, including those in the balance of power, then I think it is very important that the compromise agreed to by the National Indigenous Working Group is put and voted on. So I am unable to support Labor's amendment No. 250.

SPEECH.PARA: The ALP's amendment should not be a requirement, simply because we believe that section 61A, which deals with restrictions on making applications, should not exist at all. So I indicate that I will not be supporting Labor amendment No. 250 because I think it has very serious implications for future development, especially in areas like my state of Western Australia.
Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (217) Schedule 2, item 20, page 165 (lines 25 to 27), omit ", 61A (which provides that certain applications must not be made) or 62 (which requires applications to be accompanied by affidavits and to contain certain details)".

Amendment No. 217, which is the compromise amendment agreed to by the National Indigenous Working Group, restricts the scope of strike‐out for lack of compliance with application forms and for seeking a determination in respect of previous exclusive possession act areas and seeking non‐exclusive possession act areas. I would urge the Senate to support this position to make sure that we have a situation where application forms are not simply struck out because of some compliance fault with the application form.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Margetts has raised some issues here. I would like to hear the government's response. In the view of the opposition, it would be a matter of concern for all concerned if the application was just struck out on the basis that there were problems with the detail. I wonder what the government has got to say about 217?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The ALP did not accept the Indigenous Working Group amendment because they thought it went too far. What we are being presented with is something that is, from the government's point of view, less attractive than what the ALP was proposing.

BREAK.PARA: The strike‐out mechanism is of course a normal part of the law. Any party in a democracy like ours has the right to go to court to ask a court to consider that it not hear the matter for a variety of reasons. This simply says that it is open to other parties to apply to the Federal Court in the normal way for a strike‐out of the application. The grounds are set out there. Basically, they are that the application does not comply with the pretty basic requirements that are set down in the application procedure. If the application does not meet the basic requirements then a claim can be amended so that it does meet the requirements prior to it being struck out. If it is struck out it can be redrawn and relodged so that it does comply with the basic requirements. This is a matter of ensuring that claims meet at least the basic requirements set down in the act.

Remember, this is not the application of the registration test; it is the application of the application test, which is much more basic. These are, basically, quite mechanical requirements in terms of the description of the claim, the rights claimed and matters relating to where the claims are being made over land on which there is exclusive possession. So we do not think it at all unreasonable to enable parties to apply to a court and argue before a court that the application does not meet those minimal requirements. It is a matter for the court to make the decision.

As I say, claims can be amended in the course of the proceedings so that they do comply. If struck out, they can of course be corrected to ensure that they meet the basic requirements set down in the act and be resubmitted. We think this is entirely appropriate, sensible and fair, given that native title claims now affect a whole range of other interests. That the normal rules of law should apply seems only fair and reasonable. By definition, because these matters have to be submitted to a court and only a court can make a determination that there must be a strike‐out procedure—and there is general agreement on that—the mechanism by which such strike‐out applications are dealt with through 84C seems entirely appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are probably heading to the nub of the situation where native title claimants believe that they are, in effect, almost declared guilty and have to prove their innocence. There is an assumption that they are lying and the assumption has to be broken by a very onerous application of section 62 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) A claimant application (see section 253):

PARA.TAB: (a) must be accompanied by an affidavit sworn by the applicant:
(b) must contain the details specified in subsection (2); and
(c) may contain details of details of:
(a) information . . .

TAB.TAB: (i) the area covered by the application; and
(ii) any areas within those boundaries that are not covered by the application; . . .

PARA.TAB: (b) a map showing the boundaries of the area mentioned . . .
(c) details and results of all searches . . .
(d) a description of the native title rights . . .
(e) a general description of the factual basis . . .

TAB.TAB: (i) the native title claim group have . . .
(ii) there exist traditional laws and customs that give rise to the claimed native title; . . .

SPEECH.PARA: This is all right. You have got to give descriptions of the laws and customs, but this is part of your affidavit. These are the things you have got to already have on your application. Section 62 continues:

PARA.TAB: (f) if the native title claim group currently carry on any activities . . .
(g) details of any other applications . . .
(h) details of any notices . . .

SPEECH.PARA: This is a minefield. People talk about double jeopardy, but this is a multiple jeopardy minefield. On the basis of this, a person could be struck out on a technicality in a sensitive area which is about basic human rights—a person's ability to claim native title rights. You are saying that people must have a lawyer, access to searches, and everything else under the `must' provision. If they do not, their claim can be struck out. That is what the government is saying. That shows a manifest and total lack of understanding of the issues involved in claiming native title for indigenous Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts makes a very strong and a very valid point. These requirements in the legislation go to a whole range of aspects of procedure and formality. Matters could very well be struck out, even though the claims made and the assertions made in them were substantially correct—and I emphasise `substantially'. Enormous injustices could be meted out to indigenous Australians because of the very strict requirements of the government's provisions that we are discussing at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a wide range of provisions. Strike‐out could happen on a basic formality ground when, in essence, all that is needed is a slight amendment or a slight revision of some of the grounds. Any good QC could find any number of defects in any particular application document no matter what the case, no matter what the jurisdiction. It seems unfair to provide that, in other circumstances, there is capacity through interlocutory proceedings to ensure a correction, but in this particular case you are talking instant death. We are supporting the Greens amendment on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be very sad if the way that native title claims are dealt with becomes similar to the handling of cases in a wardens court. We know that the history is that one miner will go to that court to try to find out whether or not another miner has breached one of the rules in relation to his lease. It is a pity that environment claimants do not get the same sort of hearing, but in reality I believe we should not end up having native title considered in a similar way to what happens in a mining wardens court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind everybody that we are talking about claims for very significant legal rights. There is a lot attached to a claim being accepted in the court. The claims then go to mediation. One of the most repeated concerns about the current arrangements is the number of claims that are now in the system which are frivolous claims, as Mr Robinson, the Deputy Chairman of ATSIC, has said. What is in this bill is ensuring that claims that receive the benefit of Federal Court adjudication and mediation through the Native Title Tribunal are dealt with in a way that ensures that, at the very basic level, there is some reasonable basis for the claim.

SPEECH.PARA: The most widespread and universally accepted complaint about the current system, from Aborigines in particular, is the number of frivolous unsubstantiated claims in the system which are denying justice to those who are genuine, serious claimants who ought to have their claims heard as expeditiously as possible.

At this application stage, the application is dealt with on the face of it. The detail required is not methodically or judicially tested in any way. The claim technically has to meet them, but they are not tested. Having the information is all about ensuring that mediation of claims, which is the next stage, can succeed, in the hope that agreements can be reached and we do not have to spend five years in court.

That is one of the problems. As those involved on both sides—including the Aboriginal side—will tell you, it is difficult to have effective mediation when it is not clear what land is being claimed, what rights are being claimed, et cetera. Given that there is effectively no rigorous test applied at the application stage, it is not unreasonable that there be the capacity to seek a strike‐out on the grounds that the basic requirements set down for applications have not been met—remembering, as I say, that claims can be amended in the process or, if they are struck out, they can be resubmitted in order that they comply with basic requirements.

I draw your attention to the fact that in the current Native Title Act, for a whole variety of reasons with which most of us are familiar, the schedule to the act sets down the require ments for applications under that act which, when this parliament passed them, were quite detailed. They required a whole lot of descriptions of the people making the claim, the area of land or water covered by the application, all information known to the applicants about interests, et cetera. You can read it in schedule 1 of the Native Title Act.

This parliament agreed that that quite extensive information should be supplied in relation to applications under the current act. Let us not move the goalposts completely. Let us remember what is being asked of applicants at the application stage. We are now dealing with a lot of other interests which are affected by native title claims. Native title claims are in pursuit of significant legal rights and attract the full force of the law when they are made because they are then eligible for the protection of the court and the full mediation arrangements which are provided by the people of Australia for native title claims. We believe it is an entirely appropriate process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder about the equity of this situation. In the case of a mining company which wants to put in, for instance, an environmental impact statement, it can keep going until it gets it right, unless it gets tired in the meantime. For instance, someone is employed to say, `This is not good enough. You have to fix up this, this and this.' I am not sure that that is actually the case here.

SPEECH.PARA: People have to submit their application for registration. You say they could resubmit it. Is there something in the bill that says they have the ability to resubmit it—if they have the money? What kind of delay is involved if their application is struck out? What is the reality of people ever getting back into the process again if their application is struck out on that basis?

Are there in fact the people available to advise and encourage on a one‐to‐one basis and to provide that information to the applicants? I am wondering whether or not the Commonwealth is going to pledge themselves right now to provide those people who can assist claimants in making that claim or are they going to have to pay for it themselves?

BREAK.PARA: In the case of a mining company having to submit things like environment statements, there is actually someone employed to coax them, to tell them what they have not done and to get them to redo it until they get it right. I wonder whether what you are saying is that you are actually going to provide resources and staff to assist native title claimants to make sure that they reach the standards that you have set which you are using as an excuse to strike out their claims.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts appears not to have read the whole bill. Is she not aware of the extraordinary lengths to which we are going to ensure that representative bodies fulfil that role? Is she not aware that our government is providing $40 million every year to representative bodies to perform that function? We are giving them that function specifically in relation to our amendments. The thrust of our amendments is supported around the chamber, as I understand it. That is why we give the representative bodies $40 million a year—in order to enable them to do just what you are talking about. I just do not understand your concern on this score.

SPEECH.PARA: The representative bodies have said to us that they want to ensure that the claims in the system have some substance and are likely to be claims that will succeed. Aboriginal leaders have been saying that to us. They say that one of the real problems with the current arrangements is that anybody can make a claim and get in the system. As I said, that is unduly prejudicing—if I may use those words—those who have genuine claims, who should be recognised and have determinations made in their favour.

We have all agreed that there has to be some filter on this. What we have set in place is a most appropriate filter. As I have said, we are providing the resources and the funds to ensure that genuine claims can meet all these requirements and that all the assistance available can be supplied. The bill does specifically set out in section 64 on page 150 the process for amending applications. So I would ask you to treat this objectively and with reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly on that point, the $40 million that you are talking about represents a cut to the funding of representative bodies. There is not 40 million new dollars to go to assist bodies in meeting these types of requirements. As I say, I am talking about the fact that, even with the money that is available to, for instance, mining companies in Australia, and so on, they also have the assistance of government bodies in states to assist them in putting in their applications, including environmental applications. That is the question I was asking. You are asking for extra, fairly onerous information on applications. I am wondering exactly what process you are talking about, whether or not you are giving extra funds to provide for the assistance that might be necessary to avoid a situation where a rep body puts in an application and is struck out. What is the process then and the time involved, the delay process, the funds involved and the possibility of revisiting an application in reality, considering there are not 40 million new dollars available for these onerous implications that you have in this new bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —When we came to office, the amount of money supplied to representative bodies was $25 million; it is now $40 million, nearly double. I do not know where Senator Margetts comes from in relation to funding—it is significant. We would expect—and I would have thought everybody would expect—that representative bodies would ensure that claims that they fund would meet these very basic requirements. If you cannot meet these basic requirements, then your chances of a successful mediation or pursuit of your determination must be questioned. I would have thought that any responsible representative body in funding a claim would make absolutely certain that it can meet these very basic requirements. You keep talking as though this whole issue is one between multinational mining companies and native title claimants. I do not know whether you have ever been to Kalgoorlie—you talk as though you have not.
—I have been there a hell of a lot more times than you would have been there.

—I met the old miner referred to in the Australian on 29 November 1997, Jack Otway, who is 82 and has not been able to go exploring on the nine‐hectare block on which he has sought an exploration lease, and has been caught up in native title claims for three years. You are not talking about multinational mining companies. I have met this guy; you may not have. He is an old explorer with an old truck and one drill on the back of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The way you talk is just extraordinary, as if this whole debate is about BHP and Aborigines; it is not. There are a whole range of other interests involved. Therefore, we believe it is most appropriate that, given the effect on a whole range of other interests, including the Jack Otways of the world, and farmers who are drought struck and cattle prices declining, and everything else, that therefore, when claims are made that affect their rights and their lives, they should at least pass these basic requirements and that, if they do not, there should be the legal right to go to court to seek a strike out. Ultimately, it is a matter for the court as to whether or not their claim is heard. If it is, they can always make the claim again.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would probably get through this debate much faster if the minister were a little more reasonable and able to pick up some of these points.
