There are wide ranging powers in the legislation and in the bill to strike out on substance and that is the important thing. If someone does not meet the requirements they have to meet in substance, the powers are there. They should not be struck out on technicalities. Get them on the substance; there are already powers there to do so and those powers will be enhanced. It is excessively unfair to impose a rigorous and oppressive procedural test as to the requirements and then, because someone does not fulfil all aspects of it, they miss out.

BREAK.PARA: As Senator Margetts rightly says, in any other jurisdiction you have a capacity to amend. Why not have it here? If the claim is not worthy, whether it is through fraud, false representation or not meeting the actual claims made there is provision already in the legislation. Let us give them a fair go in terms of process and give some flexibility and we will probably finish this bill sooner than we think.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that the role of government is to protect the most vulnerable, especially in relation to equity and access under the law. I have not met Jack Otway but I have met a lot of people in the goldfields. As I mentioned by way of interjection, I have probably been to the goldfields a lot more than the minister.

SPEECH.PARA: However, these are not basic requirements; these are quite onerous requirements. It means that a clever, well‐funded lawyer can pick off a claim in the Federal Court, and we all know what charges under the Federal Court imply. We know, when a community has just managed to get a claim to the Federal Court, that it has been extremely difficult. The government says they want certainty; the government says they want a process that is workable. Basically, they are saying they want certainty and workability for one side and one side only.
Amendment not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to register the vote of the Greens in relation to this issue because I think it is important.
—There being no further amendments to sheet 3, we turn to the amendments listed on sheet 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (66) Schedule 2, item 63, page 191 (lines 8 and 9), omit "that is covered by an entry on the Register", substitute "(whether or not covered by an entry on the Register)".
(67) Schedule 2, item 63, page 193 (line 4), after "section 63", insert "or subsection 64(4)".
(68) Schedule 2, item 63, page 194 (after line 6), after subsection (5), insert:

PARA.TAB: (5A) Before the Registrar has decided whether or not to accept the claim for registration, he or she may notify the applicant that the application may be amended under the Federal Court Rules.

SPEECH.PARA: (69) Schedule 2, item 63, page 194 (after line 18), at the end of section 190A, add:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Effect of withdrawal etc. of application

TAB.TAB: (a) before the Registrar has decided whether or not to accept the claim for registration; or
(b) after the Registrar has decided to accept the claim for registration but before the Registrar has included details of the claim in the Register of Native Title Claims;

the Registrar is notified under section 189 or 189A of a decision or determination to the effect that the application has been dismissed or otherwise finalised, or is notified that the application has been withdrawn, the Registrar must not:
(c) decide whether or not to accept the claim for registration; or
(d) enter the details in the Register;
as the case requires.

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing with the schedule of amendments under the heading `Registration test'. Generally speaking, I think there is support for an enhanced registration test. In light of the previous discussion we have had, what we are talking about here is the test to be applied to claims after they have been accepted by the court and sent to the registrar of the tribunal to determine whether they should be registered and, therefore, attract all the statutory benefits which flow from registration. This goes to the heart of dealing with what I think everybody acknowledged was the unintended consequence of the current Native Title Act, where we have a lot of multiple overlapping and competing claims which make dealing with native title extremely difficult, complex and expensive.

We have thought long and hard about the nature of the registration test. We first put forward amendments on this matter back in—believe it or not—June of last year; it has been a long saga. It has been subject to some alteration over that period but, essentially, we in the government have given much thought to the nature of that test. We believe the test that we have proposed is an appropriate test which will ensure that the register contains all legitimate claims.

All legitimate claims should have no difficulty in passing the test, but it will act as a filter to ensure that only those claims which have substance will be on the register and attract all the considerable statutory benefits that flow from registration, remembering that any claim that does not meet the registration test is not in any way affected in relation to the pursuit of a determination for native title. I repeat: this does not affect in any way the right of the claimants to seek a determination that they hold native title. The test relates to being on the register and the statutory benefits which flow from registration.

To keep numerical sequence, and given that amendment 66, although moved by us, was apparently not on the running sheet before, I have moved amendment 66, which relates to this whole area, in this block. Amendment 66 clarifies that the Registrar of the Federal Court must advise the Native Title Registrar whenever an application is withdrawn, even if that application has not been registered. Again, this is a technical amendment to ensure the proper maintenance of the register and one that I would have thought was unexceptional.

Amendment 67 seeks to insert a reference to subsection 64(4) into subsection 190A(1). The purpose is to ensure that the registrar is obliged to consider amended applications. To the extent that there was any doubt about that—we are not sure that there was—this will ensure that that is the case.

Amendment 68, new subsection 190A(5A), will allow the registrar to advise the claimant that the application can be amended under the Federal Court rules. For example, the registrar may wish to use this power when an application that is unlikely to satisfy the registration test would be able to satisfy that test if it were amended. This will give the claimant the option of amending the claim before the registrar makes a decision about registration. This is an amendment which I would have thought would meet with support.

BREAK.PARA: Government amendment 69 provides a new subsection, 190A(7), which explains that when the registrar is told that an application which has not been registered has been dismissed or otherwise finalised, the registrar is not to finish considering whether the claim should be registered if this consideration is under way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Minchin, may I just inquire as to whether you have moved amendment No. 69 now, or just 66, 67 and 68 together?

—We are generally dealing with the block of amendments together. There has been an understanding that we deal with them in a cognate sense and I have been adopting the practice, which I think has been acceptable, of moving all government amendments at the start of the debate.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment 69 explains that when the registrar is told that an application which has not been registered has been dismissed or otherwise finalised the registrar is not to finish considering whether the claim should be registered if this consideration was under way, or must not enter the details of the claim into the register if the consideration had been finalised. Again, it is a pretty technical amendment which I would not have thought would attract too much opposition.

Those are the fairly simple government amendments to what we think is a reasonable registration test. The physical connection issue is one which I know attracts a great deal of angst and some opposition from some quarters. I remind you that all we are saying in relation to this question of physical connection is that part of the registration test—remembering this does not go to the right of the claimant to seek a determination but to participate and have the full benefit of the right to negotiate; that is what this is about—is whether one member of the claimant group has or has had at any time a traditional physical connection with the area claimed.

If you oppose that, you are saying that you should be able to get registered and therefore attract the right to negotiate and the considerable benefit of that right even though not one member of the claimant group has ever had any physical connection with the area claimed. That seems to us quite an extraordinary proposition. We think our test is quite minimal. It is not saying that all members of the group have to have a current physical connection. It does not say that. It simply says that just one member—and you can have a claimant group of any number; there is no limit on the numbers in the claimant group; it could be 300 or 400 or whatever you like—at some stage in their life has to have had a physical connection with the area claimed.

To suggest that that should not be there is, as I say, to support the notion that you can be registered and attract the full right to negotiate even though no‐one in the claimant group has ever had in their life any connection with the area claimed. I would ask people to focus on what actually is in the bill in relation to the physical connection test, to see that it is not unreasonable and to contemplate what you are saying if there were no such test whatsoever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The starting point for the opposition in this part of the debate is that changes are needed to the registration test. In that respect, we share the motivation of just about everyone in this chamber. We have identified a number of areas, particularly the question of overlapping native title claims, and also the fact that there has been some capacity for what may be called overly optimistic ambit type claims in the process. It is fair to say that they are the concerns the government has. They are the concerns other people have. They are also the concerns that indigenous Australians have to some extent. What we say is that our response is a fairer balance than the government's. We do not want to deny many genuine native title holders the right to register their claims. We contend that the government does in fact do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Our response has three major features. We assign a clear role to the registrar. We ensure the registration process can pick up the false and fraudulent claims. We have special provisions which probably are a little more rigorous than the government's in respect of overlapping claims. The physical connection test is an issue that was mentioned. I will turn to that later on. In respect of multiple claims, we believe the government is too rigid. The government's provision is that, if a member of the claimant group is also a member of a group whose application has been registered, the subsequent claim cannot be proceeded with. We think that is too rigorous and does not reflect the social organisation and traditional law that is important to so many groups in the community.

In terms of specific complaints, the time limits of the registration test are impractical. We have a situation where, if a section 29 notice is issued over a claimed area, the registrar must consider the claim before the four‐month notification period. Okay, the government has expanded that by one month, but it is still too rigorous. If the claim has not been registered by that time, the native title applicant cannot be a party to future applications and loses their right to negotiate. We say these are too tight and too inflexible. Given the fact that an application may be lodged late in the period, there is a real risk that registration may not be completed in time for the time lines to be satisfied. That registration may not be completed at no fault of the claimants. In respect of registration of claims covering previous exclusive and non‐exclusive possession acts, we had a debate about that the other day. I would like to go to that later on in this part of the debate.

The ALP's position in a broad sense is that we do have a capacity for certification by rep bodies. That is important. Given the recognition that Senator Minchin has given to the role of rep bodies, I think it is important to stress that they do have a particular role here as well. We also import through our amendments a capacity for the registrar to oversee the process in a fairly substantial way. The registrar is not to register the application unless he or she is satisfied that the certification was reasonably made by the rep body. We have a provision to ensure administrative review. We have a provision that would cover fraud in an application. That is an important aspect in our proposal. We also have a provision to ensure that the process is a fast moving one. Our new provision, one that the government does not have, is provision 190AC which enables challenges to be made in the Federal Court as to the truth of the sworn facts in an application.

In essence, we have mechanisms in place that will test against truth, against fraud and against whether a claim was reasonably made. We think it is important for priority to be given by the registrar to claims in relation to areas over which section 29 notices have been given. That is covered by our proposed section 190A. We also have a real concern with the test on which the registrar is required to make an assessment of applications. We believe it should be a strictly objective test. We claim that the phrase `the registrar must be satisfied that' should be replaced with the phrase `it must be the case that', to give certainty to all. That objective test is important. We also have picked up some of the concerns raised in previous debates. It may not be possible for a subject area to be defined with the degree of certainty that is required by the government. Our 190B(2) allows for reasonable certainty which gives us a degree of flexibility through which there will be no unfair dismissal of people's claims on the basis of maybe not a precise description of the area.

There needs to be, under our provisions, an identification and clarification of the native title rights and interests. As I mentioned earlier, the connection test is an important aspect of this particular registration process. We think the government goes too far in impinging upon common law rights. We can live with the traditional physical association test proposed by the government but only if it is an alternative to other tests.

We believe that you can have that physical association test. But if people cannot meet that, there needs to be a test to cover circumstances where the traditional physical association would reasonably have been expected to be maintained but for the actions of governments or third parties in, for instance, barring native titleholders or claimants access to the land. That happened quite a deal in the 1960s after the equal wage case. I think the government's provision is much too rigorous and does not pick up any such denial or barring of access or continual lock outs that happen consistently now.

BREAK.PARA: We think the government also cuts back on common law rights in that they do not have another leg to their connection test—a leg to pick up the common law test which was spelt out by Chief Justice Brennan, then Justice Brennan, in Mabo. He used—and it is important for us to fix on this—the common law test:

. . . where a clan or group has continued to acknowledge the laws and, so far as is practicable, observed the customs based on the traditions of the clan or group in question, whereby the traditional connection with the lands has been substantially maintained.

That broader test is based on a cultural, spiritual and customary connection—particularly a cultural and customary connection. Were we not to pick it up and reflect it in legislation we would be cutting away common law rights. It is the test; it is the words spelt out in Mabo. I think it is reasonable for the parliament to pick those words up. If we do not then we would not be going as far as the common law currently provides for the basis of a claim and we would be leaving the government and public open for taxpayer funded compensation. It is important for us to have those three test in the alternative in order to meet the necessary connection for registration.

We are concerned about natural justice. Our amendment to 190B(7) and (8) picks up the point that where material is being considered by the registrar and that material is adverse to the applicants, natural justice dictates that they must have an opportunity to respond. There is a need for flexibility in the alternative. People should be allowed to claim for compensation in the alternative and our amendment to 190B(10) picks up on that.

I have mentioned overlaps which is a particular problem. Everyone talks about the Kalgoorlie situation. The government has a number of tests that need to be met. We picked those up. We also believe that we need to be a bit more sensitive about the overlap situation. It could very well be quite justified that there be overlap, but let us make sure that there is a capacity to bring the cases together. In the case of overlapping applications, for instance, and claiming common rights, the later application under our test cannot be registered unless it asserts the common law rights are held jointly with the earlier applicants. That is important.

I must say that we have picked up something suggested in the process in recent weeks, providing for a process of amalgamation of overlapping applications. This is based on the transitional applications, which I will go to in a few moments. The power of amendment of application needs to have some flexibility. The powers of the Federal Court need to be clarified in terms of the range of material which they can have before them.

I have mentioned overlap. We do have some provisions relating to that which I mentioned. Part of the problem is what you do with the cases that are already there. How do you handle the transitional situation? We say you can do that in two ways. The government does it in one way, and that is to essentially have a retrospective test. We think that has some real constitutional problems, some real just terms problems as well as the retrospectivity problem and the fact that it is based on taking away the rights of one particular racial group in our community.

We say that you should have an amendment which applies the registration test to applications lodged after 27 June 1996, which was the original date upon which the government announced that the new registration test was to take effect. The process provides for the appropriate minister to request that the registrar apply the new registration test to applications lodged after 27 June.

We say that, in the first instance, the registrar must give the registered claimants and rep bodies the opportunity to comply with the new test. If that does not occur within a short time, within 60 days, the registrar can then assess the applications as against the new test. It gives an important role for the rep bodies—a role that the rep bodies are well suited to cover. That takes you back to the middle of 1996.

We need to see how we can go one step further—that is, to look at the applications lodged since 1 January 1994. Our process provides for rep bodies to seek the amalgamation of applications through conciliation, such that all common rights and interests are subject to one application. If the claimant groups are unable to reach a resolution within six months, then the tribunal or a recognised state or territory body will arbitrate the amalgamation of the applications such that there is only one application registered over an area of land. We think that process is much more constitutional and sustainable than the government's and is one that allows a certain degree of time, though not too long, for a conciliatory approach to this particular process and, in doing so, does away with some of the constitutional problems the government's provision would have.

There is concern in respect of registration of claims covering previous exclusive and non‐exclusive possession acts. The government, in the debate last week, alluded to sections 47(A) and (B). I probably will not have enough time to go through the problems we have with the regime suggested by the government. In short, we have identified the problems with the regime proposed by the government with respect to claims covering previous exclusive and non‐exclusive possession acts. That regime is not broad enough, it applies only to beneficial legislation and it does extinguish. Also, the right to negotiate, which applies in those circumstances, is nothing like a full blown right to negotiate which would be appropriate.

I suggest to the committee, in respect of this particular part of the government's amendments, that we defer this in the way that we deferred amendment No. 229 on Friday until we resolve the extinguishment regime. Once we do that we will be in a better position to proceed with the registration of claims covering previous exclusive and non-exclusive possession acts. If we are not to do that, I will need to canvass this issue at greater length. I have tried to go through these issues within the 15 minutes required, and in doing so I hope I have not missed too many out.

There is a common purpose with respect to overlapping. We believe that our provisions are more workable in respect of the transition period. We also believe our provisions are much more constitutionally based. In fact, they are soundly constitutionally based when the government's are possibly not. With respect to the criteria, the benchmarks against which a claim is to be tested, we do have that wide benchmark covering false claims, fraud and a test of reasonableness of the evidence as opposed to the actual claims made.

I hope the government looks at some of these amendments positively. There was an indication last week that it may very well do so but, in any event, I hope in this particular debate we have a little bit more flexibility from the government. We believe that the measures we are proposing are measures that should be very easily picked up by it and by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —This section of the bill introduces a registration test to ensure that only claims the government considers to have merit are registered on the register of native title claims. The government has moved three amendments to this section of the bill. These amendments, firstly, specify that the registrar must reconsider applications which have been amended; secondly, specify that the registrar can advise a claimant that their application would not meet the requirements of the registration test unless it is amended; and, thirdly, specify that the registrar does not have to continue considering an application if it has been dismissed or finalised by the Federal Court.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats and the Greens (WA) are seeking to amend this section of the bill to ensure that claims will not be registered unless they comply with strengthened criteria; introduce strengthened criteria which require representative bodies to certify that requirements in relation to the identification of the area, the identification of the claimants, the rights and the interests claimed and the factual basis for the claim are satisfied; and provide a mechanism for dealing with overlapping claims on the current register and for dealing with claims registered since 27 June 1996 which may not satisfy the new test. The majority of the opposition's amendments are identical to those of the Democrats and Greens (WA). However, in addition, the opposition will seek to assign a clear role for the registrar and representative bodies in the registration process and to make provisions for challenges against false claims.

Senator Harradine will move an amendment which will require that native title claimants will have to prove not only that they have had an association with the land but also that they have had regular physical access to the land. While the ALP have indicated they will support Senator Harradine's amendment, the Democrats and Greens have indicated that they will oppose it. In moving this amendment, the Democrats do not believe that Senator Harradine has given enough consideration to issues such as those raised in the recent report on the stolen generation whereby many Aboriginal people were forcibly removed from their families and continuous physical relationship with the land was deemed impossible.

There is considerable support for the refining of the registration test. I think everyone agrees with that. But it cannot be so refined that it creates a situation where the registration test is so onerous that it effectively wipes out the accessibility to native title procedures. It really is an issue of access to justice. A harsh test is not the issue. The injustice flows from a harsh test in combination with unreasonably tight time frames from notices that will have the effect of impairing or extinguishing native title. The government is attempting to say to native title applicants, `Sure, you have native title. You even have native title procedures. Just use them.' It is very much a `let them eat cake' attitude.

The Democrat‐Greens (WA) amendments will ensure that there are no technical knockouts of native title. Professor Langton, whom I mentioned earlier in the debate, had this to say in response to a question from Senator Ferris on overlapping claims—the main excuse the government is using to substantiate such a massive high jump bar for indigenous people to access their rights:

So, in answer to Senator Ferris's question, I wanted to explain the problem in this way. I spoke before about how one of the principles which anthropologists have identified in order to ascertain the workings of an Aboriginal land tenure system is the motion of descent from an apical ancestor.

As with all human cultures, the apical ancestor may be real or legendary, to use a lay term. For instance, British royalty had at one time its constitution in divinity and it was believed that the king, or the queen, was the divine representative on earth. That is why the monarch is the representative of the Church of England, because of the doctrine of the monarch as divinity.

In a similar way, most human cultures have a belief system about ancestry. These days with DNA and RNA testing, some of this can be affirmed or denied, but much of it still is not amenable to scientific inquiry. Belief systems are belief systems and as we know with racism, generally false propositions which operate on an illogic are not amenable to facts. So in the same way belief systems are simply belief systems and there is no point in taking blood tests and doing DNA tests because it is not relevant to the exercise. One would not do a DNA test on the queen to see if she were, in fact, a descendant of God.
She went on to say, and I feel it is necessary to read the whole text here because it is important to note:

The issue of apical ancestry in Aboriginal belief systems is one of belief, particularly because of such things as, say, in some Aboriginal societies there is the taboo on speaking the names of the dead. Because of that you have very shallow genealogical information remembered by any particular generation.

Any particular generation will remember two or three generations back and then beyond that, the names of ancestors are somewhat mythologised because one is not allowed to speak their names. For instance, two brothers could be conflated into one person because of the details of their actual life histories not being remembered because of certain taboos.

Given that range of cultural factors which I have covered very briefly, you then have the impact of recent historical events such as the removal of children, the establishment of missions, the epidemics such as the Spanish flu following the First World War, labour legislation such as under the welfare ordinances in the Northern Territory, and various other impacts which disrupted populations. People have been separated across very wide distances by the practice, for instance, of locking up people who were perceived to be half castes or quarter castes and so forth in the Kahlin Compound and on Croker Island and the various other institutions.

The memory then of who was related to who for an indigenous cultural grouping is lost sometimes with such impacts. People now are only starting to find out, with the records being opened, particularly the Commonwealth archives in the Northern Territory, and access being made more easy for Aboriginal people, that this person and this person are brother and sister. But you find this out 50 years after their birth, or you find out that that is the case 100 years after their birth. So the actual remembered constitution of local Aboriginal customary groups has been disrupted by these events. It is quite legitimate then to try to reconstruct, from historical sources, the constitution of these groups. But, at the same time, one again comes up against the problem of belief.

One finds in preparing land claims that a group of people who have been separated from all of that part of the customary group by enforced government removals will have been brought up over a number of generations to believe that they are the descendants of a certain person and that person only, while this group over here believes that they are the descendant of another person and that person only. They may come to find out later, from an anthropologist, say in a land claim—and this happens—that those two apical ancestors were siblings. They were half siblings or full siblings.

So you have this problem of overlapping claims and it is very difficult then to sort out those relationships and also to sort out how the connections to land can be established. Although Senator Minchin puts it as though it is just a simple matter—you have a physical test and there you are, it is decided—the evidence which we received shows that that is very misleading. It is very misleading to make a physical test one of the bases on which these claims can be knocked out.

I want to give you some other illustrations from other cultures. The Jews were separated from the land of Palestine for about 1,500 years. One of the Jewish ceremonies which was held each year by Jews—who were certainly not in any way physically connected to the land of Israel—was that at the Passover they would say, `Next year, we will celebrate the Passover in Palestine.' Are we going to say to those Jewish people, `You have no right to return to Palestine because you have no physical connection; you have not had a physical connection for over a thousand years'? I am afraid you would find yourself in a very difficult position if you made that kind of statement. It is exactly the same when we say to Aboriginal people, `You cannot visit these areas because you have no physical connection that you can prove.' It is like saying to the Jews, `You cannot visit Palestine because you have no physical connection; you have not had a physical connection for over a thousand years.'

Let me give you my own experience. My father was killed when I was 2½ and I was raised by a Scottish grandmother. She often told us of Scotland. I certainly have no physical connection with Scotland, but I returned there last year and I discovered that one of the connections I had was to the Macgregor clan. I discovered in returning to Scotland that the name Macgregor was banned by the English for one hundred years. It was not even allowed to be used. I went to the grave of Rob Roy Macgregor and I saw an epitaph written, `Macgregor despite them'. I have to say to you that something very deep was touched in my soul, not because I had any physical connection to the place but because there was a very deep cultural and spiritual connection which for me was very real.

In the same way, I stood on Culloden moor, where the English in 1745 slaughtered thousands of Scotsmen. I went around that battlefield and I saw headstones saying, `Here lie the bodies of 150 Macdonalds,' `Here lie the bodies of 150 Macleods,' and so on. I had no physical connection at all to that place—this was 1745, over 250 years ago—but I had a very real connection in a spiritual and cultural sense when I stood in that place.

This is the problem when you say it must be a physical connection. How does one prove a physical connection, given all of the problems which Professor Langton has raised? How do you discount a cultural and spiritual connection to places like that? Are you going to say to the Catholics, `You may not visit the Vatican because you have no physical connection to the Vatican'? You can see the problem, I am sure. I do not think anyone in this place would be game to say that to a Catholic.

When we take into consideration the genocide that has happened to indigenous people, the provision of a physical connection test is an amendment that could have easily been drafted by the discredited historian David Irving. I appeal to the government and to the Senate to accept the Greens and Democrat amendments as fulfilling the need for a registration test which will sort out the various problems that have been enunciated.

We will in no way accept Senator Harradine's amendment because it is based on a false premise. Of course Senator Harradine's amendment does improve the government's registration test. But neither the government's registration test nor the improvement which Senator Harradine is moving fulfils the basic principle that I have enunciated—the principle that, in the end, there are spiritual and cultural connections to land which are far deeper than any physical connection and that sometimes those kinds of connections can last for 200, 500 or 1,000 years, as in the case of the Jewish people. I commend our amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a considerable amount of agreement between the Democrats-Greens (WA) amendments and the opposition amendments on the registration test. Even where the amendments are not identical, there is so little difference as to not be significant. As has been mentioned, the government's amendments are technical and need not concern certainly the Democrats and the Greens in relation to dividing or opposing them, but within these amendments there is, if you like, a line or a degree of difference.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators may remember that, in the 1993 native title debate, it was the Greens (WA) who argued that there should not be a threshold test. It is still our belief that that is the ideal. However, we do understand that it is the position of the National Indigenous Working Group that there should be some kind of small not onerous registration test that does not restrict bona fide claimants.

So the main point of issue among this group of amendments is the threshold test and that occurs around opposition amendment No. 267, the Greens-Democrats amendment No. 237 and Senator Harradine's amendment No. 2. It is my belief and the belief of the Greens (WA) that the requirement of physical connection should not be in the registration test. It is not necessarily essential to determine native title.

What native title is and where it remains are matters which should be left to the courts. It will very often be a complicated question of fact. It is not a matter that should be pre‐empted by a registration test. Whether there is sufficient connection to land to support a native title claim will vary from case to case and may well depend on the laws and customs asserted.

Under 190B(5) claimants have to satisfy the factual basis for native title. According to the Greens-Democrats amendments it must be prima facie to be sufficient to support the assertion that native title rights and interests claimed exist. If physical connection is relevant, it no doubt will be included in the statement of a factual basis on which native title is asserted. It is our belief that there is no benefit in making it mandatory. It can have the potential to only disadvantage Aboriginal people from being able to establish their native title because of what in some cases may well be Eurocentric assumptions as to the nature of the connection on which those assumptions are based.
I would like to quote the minority report of the Joint Committee on Native Title in relation to the physical connection test. It states:
The profound unfairness of this test will be apparent if it is "used in order to work injustice to Aborigines who have been locked out from the land".
That was a quote by Father Frank Brennan in Hansard of 26 September 1997. The report then states:

Secondly, the common law test is not one of "traditional physical connection" but of maintenance of observance of laws and customs "so far as it is practicable to do so." There will be situations where a claimant has not had physical access to certain land but retains the stories and knowledge of traditional law relating to his or her traditional country.
That is a quote from the submission of Australians for Native Title and Reconciliation of 2 October 1997. The report continues:

The amendments contained in the Bill are manifestly unjust because they fail to recognise the spiritual and cultural connection of Aboriginal people to land and prevent claimants obtaining the right to negotiate over their traditional country as an effect of being excluded by others.

It is my opinion that the issue brought up in the minority report on page 147 is not fixed by way of Senator Harradine's amendment. I would like to also quote the lead judgment in Mabo of Justices Brennan, Mason and McHugh that has been accepted as an accurate statement of the minimum rights available to native title holders. Regarding the physical connection they said:

Where a clan or group has continued to acknowledge the laws and (so far as practicable) to observe the customs based on the traditions of that clan or group, whereby their traditional connexion with the land has been substantially maintained, the traditional community title of that clan or group can be said to remain in existence. The common law can, by reference to the traditional laws and customs of an indigenous people, identify and protect the native rights and interests to which they give rise. However, when the tide of history has washed away any real acknowledgment of traditional law and any real observance of traditional customs, the foundation of native title has disappeared. A native title which has ceased with the abandoning of laws and customs based on tradition cannot be revived for contemporary recognition. Australian law can protect the interests of members of an indigenous clan or group, whether communally or individually, only in conformity with the traditional laws and customs of the people to whom the clan or group belongs and only where members of the clan or group acknowledge those laws and observe those customs (so far as it is practicable to do so).
This analysis goes on to say:
The common law test is not one of "traditional physical connection" but of maintenance of observance of laws and customs "so far as it is practicable to do so".
I would also like to quote briefly from the Hansard of the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Fund, which is dated 24 September 1997. Mr Terry O'Shane said:

The consideration by government of the threshold test needs to be framed with the evidence that has been presented regarding the stolen generation. You need to take that into consideration, because you talk about a physical connection when the policy of past governments of this country has alienated our children from their parents and alienated people from their land. If people are going to sit in government and say to us that we have to have a physical connection, and really mean that, then there is something terribly wrong in this country—terribly, terribly wrong.

I put this to you. Remember, we have various elements that we have debated where the spiritual connection has been downgraded, ignored, given a minor role or not even considered by this government so far. We have the situation where actions by non-indigenous Australia may well be denying on an ongoing basis the rights of indigenous Australians who have kept up the law, the knowledge and the stories of land to which they have been excluded through various means.

I do not think this is acceptable. I think in this case it might be useful to clarify the situation of how we can address these amendments. I suggest that when we get to that section we might first deal with Senator Harradine's amendment No. 2, and then we will know whether there is any need to clarify further the difference between the amendments of the National Indigenous Working Group and those of the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This threshold test is one of the key points to the bill. It is one of the most important issues in the bill. I would like to speak to it. The government has proposed that there be at least one person in the native title claimant group who has, or used to have, a traditional physical connection to the claimed area. That establishes a prima facie case. That weeds out a lot of claims that are ambit claims. It allows people on rural properties to know who they are dealing with.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the native title legislation, farmers have to either arbitrate, negotiate or litigate. In the end, if they have to sit down and negotiate with people, the legislation that is before the Senate at the moment would allow them to negotiate with mainly people that they know. If the Labor Party's amendments are carried or the Greens' amendments are carried, that would allow anyone from anywhere to come in and make a claim.

Not all of these claimants went of their own accord. They did not all go voluntarily. Some were moved, and some voluntary went to a better house in a better community, where there are schools and hospitals. But let us not get into who was pushed and who went.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?
—Because I do not think we will ever be able to find out who went voluntarily and who went unwillingly.

SPEECH.PARA: This might have happened 50 or 60 years ago. The property may have changed hands four times since then. For instance, in Cunnamulla there was a 500,000 acre property cut up in 1954. These people then left and lived in the town. Let us say that, even before that, these properties that these people lived on could have changed hands three or four times. So the people who are now living on the property will have to be responsible for something that happened up to 40 or 50 years ago. That is not correct. When these actions happened, it was legal. It is most unfair to imply a penalty on someone 40 years after.

I want to say that Sugar Ray Robinson said that the man on the moon could put a native title claim in now. If we pass these amendments, that will not change. What everyone is saying is that we have to reduce these ambit claims. These amendments will remove the chance of removing ambit claims.

Local people are prepared to sit down and hammer out agreements with the people that they know around the areas—people that they went to school with or that they have known in the local town. What is happening after they negotiate these agreements is that someone else then comes in and puts a claim right over the top of them. Some lawyer comes and assembles a claim with a couple of hundred people who do not even know where they came from or whether the claims are genuine.

I say to the chamber that I think the government position is fair. Graziers and pastoralists would have preferred a tighter test but they will accept this particular test which is `has or previously had a traditional physical connection with the claimed area'. Their preferred position would have been `a current traditional physical connection to the whole of the land under claim', but they are prepared to accept the government's 10-point plan.

If this physical connection is downgraded, then ambit claims are going to mount everywhere. We are going to see what we have seen with the 670 claims that have already been lodged and that is black claim on black claim on black claim. We have seen three black‐on‐black claims around the Charleville area. Unless you can get some physical connection test, then we are going to have ambit claims coming from everywhere. It is not going to be in the interests of Aboriginals or in the interests of pastoralists.

I want to say to Senator Woodley that, when he made his visit back to the old country, he visited there. He did not go in and claim the land that his forefathers owned because he had some sort of physical connection; he went and visited the place and obviously had a pleasant time. He did not go in and claim the area that the Macgregors owned 250 years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aboriginal people just want native title rights to visit.
—You dope.
—You obviously don't understand what native title is because it has never been defined.
—Senator Boswell, it might be helpful if you just ignore the interjections and carry on with your contribution.
—I withdraw the word `dope'.
—Thank you, Senator Woodley.
—The Acting Leader of the Democrats obviously does not know what native title is. She asks me, `Did I?' and the answer is: no, I do not know what native title is, because it has never been defined.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Woodley said he just wanted to go and visit, which implies that the Aboriginals just want to go and visit the properties. If they had wanted to go and visit the properties, I would say there have been very few times that the graziers have ever denied them rights. We are not talking about access; we are talking about native title. They are two totally different animals.
This is a very important part of the government's legislation. I would ask the chamber not to water it down because it will just increase ambit claims from everywhere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a bit concerned about Senator Boswell's contribution that he made on behalf of his constituents. One of the things he said was that litigation will grow and costs will be incurred. I do not like hearing that argument either in this particular field or in other fields. In Victoria at the moment, for example, there has been an abolition of common law in cases where people are injured through the negligence of their employer. All sorts of restrictions have been placed on common law rights, based on the proposition that lawyers cost too much and that there is too much litigation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is of great concern to this society if we are going to cut down the rights of people—whether they are indigenous people, whether they are workers, whether they are people who have been injured on the roads or whether they are people who have had their houses damaged around Albert Park. It is a very worrying trend that people are not able to exercise their rights. It has become a mantra—not only by this government but also by governments all around the place—that lawyers must not get money, that people's rights must be cut down, that people have fairly tenuous rights and therefore they should have them abolished. It is a very bad trend. It is a trend that is going on here.

Having said that, if I could ask one question about the registration test and the fact that if a claim for registration is refused then that can be reviewed by the Federal Court. Does that mean reviewed both as to the facts and as to the law; is it a re‐hearing? If it is, then in effect the Federal Court is going to hear an application for registration in any event rather than the registrar. What would happen is that people would put their claim before the registrar and, if it was knocked back, they would then go to the Federal Court and have a full hearing anyhow. That would seem to me to be the effect of proposed section 190D.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I draw the committee's attention to sheet 810 which contains my proposed amendment to this schedule. Subsection (7) at the present moment says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Registrar must be satisfied that at least one member of the native title claim group currently has or previously had a traditional physical connection with the area covered by the application.
Then I am proposing to add:
If not so satisfied, the Registrar must be satisfied that the absence of traditional physical connection has been caused by conduct of a grantee of an interest in the land or by an act of government.

I am not sure that I understood Senator Woodley, and he may be able to elaborate for me. Senator Woodley seems to indicate that this amendment would in fact exclude the children of the stolen generation. Clearly, that is not my intention and I cannot see for the life of me how it would do that because that clearly was an action by a government. I am putting it to Senator Woodley and other honourable senators that they should perhaps have a look at that and, if it does, perhaps we could clean it up along the way.

The committee see this particular area as very important. The benefit of registration to native title claimants is, of course, that it enables them to exercise certain statutory rights. It is a trigger for the exercise of those rights between the time of registration and the determination of their native title claim. Specifically, it gives them the benefit of the right to negotiate and access to the National Native Title Tribunal and its mediation services, so registration is a critical issue.

I think everybody in this chamber wished that certain things had not occurred at the time of the NTA debate in December of 1993, because the threshold at that time was far lower than the government at that stage wanted. It is a matter that has given considerable concern, as has been expressed around the chamber, to many of the Aboriginal groups who believe that this is a matter that should be rectified; that the threshold should be increased.

Going to the question itself, there have been many native title holders who have enjoyed continuing and unhindered access to their traditional country. Others, for a variety of reasons, have not. I refer to evidence to the joint committee at pages 995 to 999 of native title holders being denied physical access. A past history of locked gates and exclusion beyond the control of indigenous people must not count against them in the registration process for the mediation of native title claims. Indeed, to require a physical connection criteria for registration of claims solely would discriminate between native title holders in this country in that they could register an application for mediation. Those who have unhindered physical access would possess a superior native title to those who have not.

This is an intolerable distinction, especially when it is considered that it results from an injustice perpetrated against indigenous people. Accordingly, my proposed amendment provides that physical access is deemed to have been regular up to 23 December 1996 if native title holders have been denied access.

I come back to the point made by Senator Woodley. I fear that there may have been a misunderstanding because my previous sheet 810 did have under `Registration test' amendment No. 2, which really was to do with access and will be dealt with under topic No. 14 when we get to it. The proposed states:

(3A) For the purposes of paragraph (3)(a) physical access to land is deemed to have been regular up to 23 December 1996 if a government or the grantee of any interest in the land has regularly denied members of the native title claim group physical access to the land.

In fact, I will have a further amendment to delete the `regular' there because that could have been intermittently denied. This `regular test' is too high indeed. It may well have been as a result of looking at that particular amendment that the misunderstanding has occurred.
Through you, Madam Chair, I would ask Senator Bolkus and also the minister about the Brennan Mabo test. If you look at that test—and you can correct me if I am wrong—it states:

Where a clan or group has continued to acknowledge the laws and, so far as practicable, observed the customs based on the traditions of the clan or group in question, whereby their traditional connection with the land has been substantially maintained—

As I understand it, that is the test that you are talking about. I ask Senator Bolkus and you, Minister: would the government's provisions in (6), (7), (8) and (9) be sufficient to encom pass that particular test, with the addition of my amendment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, you should be glad you got in first with that question because I was going to ask you the reverse question. My question was going to be: you know the Brennan test in Mabo. How can you maintain that your proposal goes anywhere near that in the non‐physical sense? So take that on notice as I answer your question in respect of (6), (7), (8) and (9).

SPEECH.PARA: I think there is a very important distinction, which I am sure you appreciate, between the government's proposals, your proposal and (a) and (b) of our proposal: they are all, in a sense, based on a physical connection. But what the High Court did say in Mabo was that it could be a little bit more broad than that and that there could be sufficient connection based, as Justice Brennan said, in the words that we use in leg three of our three‐legged connection test. Justice Brennan said:

Where a clan or group has continued to acknowledge the laws and (so far as practicable) observe the customs based on the traditions of the clan or group in question, whereby their traditional connection with the land has been substantially maintained.

I think `traditional connection' may sometimes not be a physical one; it may be an intermittent physical one. It may be that the land is of some customary and traditional significance. Access to it from time to time would be important.

Obviously, under option three of our connection test the level of what is being claimed, sought, would differ in most circumstances from that which is being sought under (a) and (b). I think that is an important point to make there: that in those circumstances what is being claimed would be substantially different from circumstances where there has been a physical association. But I think we would be on dangerous ground if we were not to embrace something like the Mabo test. As I said at the start, (5), (6), (7) and (8) of the government's clause 190B on page 195 do not really pick up what the High Court thinks is necessary and what is reflected in Mabo by Justice Brennan.

BREAK.PARA: Of course, that is one concise reflection of what the common law is; it is not the only one. To the extent that we do not go as far as that, I think we are clearly taking away the common law rights of this particular Aboriginal race. The taxpayer may very well have to pay for something they would not have to pay for if we were being fair and careful. I just do not know why the government has not gone to the extent of the common law. They should. As a closing point, I ask you, Minister, why your provision does not pick that up or do you think it does pick it up?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —My answer is also in response to Senator Harradine's question. Of course we must remember that what constitutes a traditional connection for the purposes of the Brennan test, presuming that remains the test that the High Court applies, is entirely a matter for the courts. Our bill leaves that entirely to the courts when it comes to a determination of native title.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there was a lay presumption when the Mabo decision was handed down that what the court was basically talking about was physical connection. But because, obviously, in the case of the Mabo claim there was clearly demonstrably a physical connection, that word was not used in the test. I think there was, as I say, that lay presumption, but in each case it will be entirely a matter for the courts to determine what constitutes traditional connection and whether the claimants in each particular case can meet the court's test of traditional connection, whatever that may be in the particular case.

Our bill does not affect that in any way. We are talking here about the registration test for the registration of claims for the purposes of the statutory rights and benefits available under the Native Title Act. We are not talking about a claim being accepted by the Federal Court for the purposes of the determination of native title, which is entirely a matter for the court, as I say. There is no attempt by the bill to put in place any sort of threshold for the purposes of a determination of either a spiritual or physical connection. We are talking about registration and the considerable benefits that flow from registration per se.

As I say, our test simply provides that just one member out of a claim group—that can be as big as the claimants like—must have had at some stage in their whole life some physical connection with the area. If you take the obvious, you are suggesting that claims should be registered and attract the benefits of registration even though not one member of the claim group has ever had, at any stage, any physical connection with the land in question. Therefore, on the reasonable person test we think what we are proposing is entirely reasonable. However, we have had a good look at Senator Harradine's amendment and we would be prepared to accept that amendment.

In the light of the comments that have been made around the chamber, we think that is a not inappropriate amendment. But I would remind you that the general lay assumption that there was at least some physical connection with land, even though we say that is entirely a matter for the courts, was at least in circulation. The clear presumption was that a lot of Aboriginal people would not be able to successfully claim native title because of dispossession. That is why the previous government set up the Indigenous Land Fund. We supported that Indigenous Land Fund. We continue to support that Indigenous Land Fund. It was and is about enabling Aboriginal people who have been dispossessed and will not be able to sustain a native title claim to buy the land.

We are putting, out of the budget, $120 million a year into the fund so that it will reach $1.3 billion in seven years. It will then be able to be used to buy $45 million worth of land every year, for eternity. They can buy $45 million worth of land for ever. That is the arrangement that was entered into by the previous government, which we supported, in recognition of dispossession. We are supporting that.

Given that we are not affecting in any way the right of claimants to pursue their claim and prove whatever connection they believe meets the test—that is entirely up to them—we believe that the registration test is at a bare minimum: one member must, at some stage in their life, have had a previous physical connection. It is the most minimal test that you could put in place in this regard. If we accept Senator Harradine's amendment—which, as I indicated, the government is prepared to do—that is an entirely appropriate threshold to place on this matter.

In terms of this understanding about physicality, I again draw your attention to the regulations of the current act and the native title determination applications, which refer in A9 to information about any physical connection that exists or existed between the applicants and the land. The regulations to the act passed by this parliament, which could have been disallowed, refer to physical connections. Let us not entirely rewrite history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to Senator Harradine's question to me some time ago. I should also apologise to Senator Boswell—he is not a dope. I know that he holds very sincerely the views that he puts; I just disagree with him. I probably disagreed a little too vigorously.

SPEECH.PARA: I was looking at Senator Harradine's earlier amendment, but we have now had a look at his subsequent amendment and, while it is an improvement on what the government is proposing, we still have problems with it. No physical connection test was mentioned in the Mabo judgment, so it is imposing an additional test, and I think a very rigorous one, which was never envisaged under Mabo.

Even though the amendment is an improvement on the government's original proposal, the test puts the onus of proof on indigenous people to prove traditional physical connection and whether or not there has been conduct by a lessee which has prevented that physical connection. An act of government is much easier to define; it is much clearer.

Another reason why we believe there is still a big problem with Senator Harradine's amendment is that it may not have been the action of a grantee or a government; it could have been an action of the churches which removed people. Certainly, going back several generations, the churches were involved in the removal of people from their traditional lands. The churches have apologised for that. I know that, in particular, the Uniting Church has been involved in a ceremony on Croker Island to say sorry. The churches were involved in removals, but they are neither grantees nor government.

For instance, in some of my writings I have recorded the story of how the Reverend Alice Bramley took children from the Camooweal area to Brisbane, a couple of thousand kilometres away, during the Second World War, and some of those children never returned. These are the problems we have with Senator Harradine's amendment, even though we acknowledge that it is an improvement on what the government was originally proposing. The principle of physical connection is still the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I share the concerns that Senator Woodley has outlined in relation to Senator Harradine's proposed amendment. I agree that the registration should not be restricted to physical connection. We believe that spiritual and cultural connection is actually more important. It is ironic that the high jump for registration should actually be higher than the high jump for determination. That does not make any sense at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Under Senator Harradine's amendment, the claimants would have to satisfy the registrar that absence of traditional physical connection has been caused by conduct of a grantee of an interest in land or by an act of government. This could be considered to be insulting to many indigenous people. There may well be circumstances in which absence of traditional physical connection is caused by parties other than a grantee of an interest in land or government.

For example, as Senator Woodley pointed out, it could be the action of a church, or they could be driven off by people managing a pastoral lease, an if the word `grantee' is in the legislation, it becomes the law as is practised. I would like to share a couple of stories of people with restricted access which has not been caused by either grantee or government. One example is from chapter 1 of a book called Recognising Native Title. It gives an example of connection preserved through long absence from country which was in the Kaititj Walpiri land claim of 1981. It says:

One of the witnesses was a woman in her seventies who had survived the Coniston Massacre in 1927. After the massacre she had been taken away and did not return to her country until the preparation for the land claim in 1981. Rosie Nakamara was to give evidence about part of the claim area that was inaccessible by vehicle so she was taken in a helicopter to this place she hadn't been to for 50 years.
Neither the grantee nor the government was restricting that access.

In relation to another example of which I have been recently appraised, in Western Australia Robert Bropho from the Swan Valley fringe dwellers mentioned a story in which a particular site was one with which he had been familiar as a child, but he is the only member of his clan group who had physical connection and has memory of that area. The stories were known amongst the clan, the law was known amongst others in the group and the spiritual connection was strong, yet, because he has a heart problem, that may well be lost to the clan should he die before a claim is processed.

So there could be ongoing problems. It could be the death of the one person from a clan group who has had connection with that land. That person may well have passed on the law, the stories and the knowledge to other members of that group. I really do not think we are being realistic in making, as I say, the registration higher than the determination.

Senator Minchin said, `Let the court decide.' He is not allowing the court to decide. He is saying that we will legislate away those rights for those people who the court may in fact decide to grant determination. So he is cutting them off at the pass and saying, `No, we'll stop you before you go any further.' I urge Senator Harradine to take into consideration those cases where there really is evidence that there are bodies other than those of a grantee or government who may have restricted access, and there may well be physical and spiritual connection to the land because of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not yet moved my amendment and I take the point made by Senator Woodley and Senator Margetts on the question of whether this denial has been caused by the conduct of any grantee of any interest in the land or by any act of government—I suppose I could put `any person' there. I come to the situation now of examining whether or not I ought to proceed with my amendment or whether I should support the opposition's amendment. As I see it, the opposition's amendment takes up the government's proposal in A(1). In A(2) it would, in effect, take up what is contained in my amendment and in B, given an alternative, the opposition's amendment would take up the Brennan test in Mabo.

SPEECH.PARA: I am wondering whether that particular amendment would not expand the claims which were ambit type claims. Irrespective of what we do, my advice is that claimants could simply go through the courts if we do not include this in here. My proposed amendment relates specifically to the registration test set out in 190B. My advice is that traditional physical connection is not part of the common law test of the existence of native title and the test expressed by Brennan, as has been said around the place, is such. I will not go into all of this. I have had plenty of advice and a lot of legal advice on a number of things, but it is quite clear that claimants could proceed by way of interlocutory injunction seeking such. Therefore, we had best put something in the legislation which reflects the common law. I am now inclined to support the amendment that is put forward by Senator Bolkus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I indicate the government's attitude to the ALP amendments and go through them one by one. At this stage, we have no objection to amendments 262 and 265. Our difficulty with amendment 257 is that its effect is to enable representative bodies to apply the registration test and to determine whether claims should be registered. We do not think that that is appropriate. We think that would amount to a conflict of interest. Our amendments go a long way to enhance the role of representative bodies in the process to enable them to facilitate the claims, but essentially they are the proponents and facilitators of claims. For the integrity of the system, it is essential that there be, and be seen to be, an independent assessment of the merits of a claim prior to its registration. So I do not think we can possibly support that particular amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: That also goes to the question of challenges against claims. The other part of opposition amendment No. 257 is the issue of challenges to be made against claimant applications. I suppose at one level you can see the merits of such a proposition, but the problem is that it would really amount to enormous delays and uncertainty in the whole process. As I understand it, it would mean that the whole right to negotiate is put on hold while a Federal Court challenge is heard on the claimant application, which we think would be entirely unsatisfactory and not supportable.

Amendment No. 258 relates to amendments we are bringing forward later in relation to the right to negotiate. I think you will appreciate what we are doing in relation to timing. Consideration of applications for registration is, as you know, to extend the time period to three months and allow another month in which claims can then be registered. So you would lodge a claim within three months, there would be another month for it to be registered and then a total of six months for the negotiation period—the same as is currently the case. We believe the amendments that we are moving under the right to negotiate process will deal with the problem that the opposition seeks to address in amendment 258.

Amendment No. 259 would limit the capacity of the registrar to have regard to information provided by the Commonwealth, a state or a territory when applying the registration test, notwithstanding that that information may be very relevant to deciding whether or not the application satisfied the registration test. We do not think that is appropriate at all either. We think that governments should be able to provide information relevant to the application for registration. There seems no earthly reason why you would seek to limit or prevent that.

Amendment No. 267 guts the registration test by effectively removing four of the nine conditions. It waters down the registration test to a point where it will not achieve the purpose for which I thought the opposition joined us—that is, to ensure that only claims of real merit would be able to be registered through an objective process. If you have a test which really amounts to enabling an assertion that you hold native title to be sufficient to have it registered, that is no test at all.

Amendment No. 269 would not prevent separate claims being made by members of the same native title claim group. We think it is fundamental to a sensible registration test that you have a mechanism in it so that you do not have people in the same native title claim group making their own separate claims. If you talk to the Indigenous Working Group, ATSIC and the Aboriginal people, you will know that that is one of the big problems they have at the moment in terms of competing claims by members of the same claim groups. We do not think the procedure proposed by the opposition under which applicants can apply to the court for an order to amend or replace the application that has already been registered is going to work. It would produce considerable uncertainty if these registered applications can then be amended or replaced by subsequent applications. We think that is unworkable.

We also have a problem with amendment No. 273. We have already set down in the bill a mechanism by which there can be judicial review of a decision of the registrar. But this seems to invoke a mechanism by which there can be a review of the actual merits as opposed to a judicial review and have the Federal Court remake the registrar's decision. We do not think it is appropriate to have what would amount to a review of the merits.

Amendment No. 274 would enable applicants to apply to the Federal Court for an extension of time for registration after the issue of a section 29 notice. Again, we think that is completely unworkable. If you are allowed to go to the Federal Court and have a hearing as to whether you get an extension of time for the registration of your claim, the whole right to negotiate process would be set back while that sort of claim was being heard. Then, subsequently, there may be an extension. As I have said, we have extended the time from three months and we are adding another month to enable claims to be registered, so that is four months. We think that is appropriate. The extension is there and it is clear. It is a definite time frame; it is one that should be supported. We should not be all back in the Federal Court waiting for court decisions as to whether and to what extent there should be extensions of time in response to a section 29 notice. We should not be subject to all the consequent delays that will ensue in relation to the right to negotiate process.
For those reasons, with the exception of amendments Nos 262 and 265, we find ourselves unable to accept the principal ALP amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously we are somewhat disappointed by that. I would like to take the opportunity to go through some of these amendments and maybe respond to Senator Minchin in respect of some of them. The minister says we give too much power in amendment 257 to the representative bodies in terms of a registration process. I ask the committee to keep in mind that what we do is allow a capacity for the rep bodies to certify and, of course, the government allows a capacity for the rep bodies in the process as well.

SPEECH.PARA: But we say that the registrar has a role. Anyone can seek to pursue either the rep body route or, alternatively, go to the registrar. If anyone has a concern, they go to the registrar. It is very much within the alternative, and nothing forces them to go down the road of having the rep body do the certification. We say that, regardless of whatever route people take, in our proposal the registrar has a capacity to be satisfied that the certification was reasonably made. That gives the registrar a degree of latitude. The process then allows for a situation in cases of fraud, which is something that is quite necessary. I think we all agree that that is an area that should be focused upon.

We also, under our proposed section 190AC, enable challenges to be made in the Federal Court as to the truth of the sworn facts in the application. You have truth, reasonableness and fraud covered in different ways. Senator Minchin says, `Oh, well, if you've got these sorts of reviews and judicial review, then it extends the process for too long.' But under the government's proposal there is a capacity to go to the Federal Court in some circumstances. What we are saying is give people the choice and the alternative. Give the rep bodies a role—they are in a good position to satisfy that role—but ensure that, for anyone who may be concerned, there is a mechanism to go down the registrar route. We have three or four mechanisms in place that will ensure protection against bodgie claims. I do not think we can be fairer than that. If the concern is as to time, as I say, there is a capacity under your proposals to go to the Federal Court, and under ours as well.

Some of these things are quite reasonable. We spent a lot of hours trying to work them out and work them through to get the right words and whatever to try to get a process that flows and that does not have injustices. For instance, our proposal to make the registrar have to give priority to consideration of claims in relation to areas under section 29 notices is a pretty important one. Why shouldn't the registrar give priority to those processes? They are fairly important. They are ongoing. The need is to get an outcome. I do not know why the government is opposing that proposal.

I should have indicated earlier that we withdraw amendment No. 243. The test we propose in amendments 261, 263, 264, 266 and 267 as to having the registrar operate on strictly objective grounds is, I would have thought, a test which is in the interests of certainty. There is a bit of flexibility there that could have been picked up. In terms of the information provided, once again, I do not know whether Senator Minchin said he would pick this up, but it is hard for people to identify with 100 per cent precision a location or area subject to the claim. I think the words `reasonable certainty' are quite reasonable there. We are not in the business of unfairly bouncing people's claims when they substantially have a legitimate claim.

We have discussed the connection test. We think it is important that natural justice applies. If there is material before the registrar on which he or she is going to rely which is adverse to the applicant, natural justice dictates that they should have an opportunity to respond. If there is a legal dispute thereafter, under Brandy that has to be considered by the court. What is wrong with that flow of information?

In relation to overlaps, everyone expects that, in respect of an area of land, there may be in fact competing indigenous interests. To say that one has to be excluded by the other is a bit rigid. What we say is that there will be rare situations where rights claimed in a late application are different, but they have to be consistent with the ones in the prior application. That is a test which reduces the overlap. As I said earlier, we have a process to pick up the overlap and to bundle claims to ensure a speedy process. You will be meting out injustice to some people unless you give a degree of flexibility. As I say, they have to be consistent. When there are common rights claimed, the application cannot be registered unless it is agreed that those common rights are held jointly with the earlier application. What is the resistance to a capacity to amend an application? As to the powers of the Federal Court, once again, we have this reaction rather than assessment by the government.

Let me finish with the transitional applications because I think it is important to look at what happens here. If you take your transitional regime back to before 27 June 1996—take it back to December 1994—you are going to have some pretty substantial constitutional problems.
