No matter what case you look at in recent years—Newcrest, Georgiardis, Mewett, the Voyager cases and so on—there are existing rights. You have to be careful about retrospectively taking from a particular racial group the rights that they have.

BREAK.PARA: What we say is that it is important that we try to get a transitional arrangement in place which can bring applications together and which can reduce and eradicate the overlapping. What we say is: take your test back to 27 June 1996 when it was announced. It was fair cop from then on; it was prospective as to its application. Further back than that, give the registrar a capacity to get the rep bodies to try to amalgamate these applications to try to get conciliation of all the rights and interests into one application. Try to force it through the rep bodies. If they do not do that within six months—and let us face it, your process with a registrar with the resources they have is going to take longer than that to do—then get the tribunal or a recognised state or territory body to arbitrate the amalgamation on the applications.

As I said at the start, we have not just fallen upon this position. A lot of work has been done. A lot of precise discussions have taken place as to how we can provide a process which would not just eradicate overlapping but also sustain itself constitutionally. We have put a lot of thought into this. The font of all wisdom is not necessarily with the government on these matters, and we do not claim to have a monopoly on it either. But I would maintain that the suggestions that are embodied in our amendments are a really good balance, a constructive way through and a more certain way through because I think we have overcome the constitutionally related problems that the government has not overcome. It is disappointing that the government has not picked them up. I hope that, in the course of the voting, the Senate can pick up some more of these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor amendment No. 268 is the same as Democrat amendment No. 238. Amendment 268 relates to the application which includes in the alternative a claim for compensation. —I think Senator Harradine did blink because I did not have much time to go to it. Amendment 268 is an amendment which will allow compensation to be claimed in the alternative. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The structure of the bill is such that the question of applications for native title is dealt with separately from applications for compensation where native title has been extinguished. The sort of logic is that, if you are seeking to assert your native title, that is one process. If you are seeking compensation for the extinguishment or impairment of native title, that is a separate process.

SPEECH.PARA: That is simply the reason why in this case, when we are talking about registration claims in relation to claims made for native title, to seek determinations of native title you have to go to the register so that you have access to the statutory right to negotiate in relation to activity on land which you claim to be native title land. That is the whole gist of our registration test. There are, of course, all the provisions in the bill and in the act for making claims for compensation, and we just do not see the point in having this alternative procedure here.

The point of registration is in relation to a claim for a determination that you hold native title and that you wish to have the appropriate statutory procedural rights relating to that claim on land on which you claim to hold native title. It is sort of a contradiction in terms to be registered where there has been extinguishment. If you are seeking compensation for extinguishment, obviously there are all the procedures available for that. It is a fairly technical point, but it just does not seem to us to make any sense to include in this proposition the claim in the alternative. We are talking about the registration of a claim pursuant to a claim for determination that you hold native title.

TALK.START.PARA: —It just goes to flexibility. Take it one or two steps back. We would like the agreement process to play a role. That agreement process would have all sorts of considerations put to it, including in the alternative compensation. I cannot see why the government has any resistance to a claim for compensation in the alternative. The other party does not have to accede to it, but it may in fact provide the other party, the respondent, with a very convenient way through it.

The government obviously has a responsibility in this particular regard to have a piece of legislation which is internally coherent. Whilst we might disagree on certain policy matters and perhaps, who knows, major policy matters, in these particular areas it has the responsibility to have an internally coherent piece of legislation. I am just taking the attitude that I would support that objective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Payne, Sen Marise

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to direct some remarks to the observation of World AIDS Day. Observed each 1 December, World AIDS Day is designed to encourage public support for programs to prevent the spread of HIV and provide education and awareness of issues surrounding HIV‐AIDS. This is the ninth observation of World AIDS Day. It was observed for the first time in 1988, after an international meeting of health ministers called for greater exchange of information on HIV‐AIDS. This year's World AIDS Day theme is `Give children hope in a world with AIDS'. It challenges people around the world to contemplate the long-term repercussions of the AIDS pandemic, without losing sight of the fact that AIDS affects everyone.

SPEECH.PARA: Through the 1997 campaign, UNAIDS and its partners aim to bring to the attention of the international community the many facets of the epidemic's impact on the lives of children. The campaign offers a platform for children and their communities to voice their concerns and aspirations in relation to the epidemic and to support the development of appropriate responses.

UNAIDS estimates that there are over 23 million persons infected with HIV. Of these, approximately 40 per cent are women. In some of the worst affected countries, up to 40 per cent of women attending antenatal clinics in urban areas are HIV affected. By the end of this year, an estimated one million children aged under 15 years are expected to be infected with HIV. Of these, approximately 90 per cent live in developing countries.

The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child in the context of HIV‐AIDS has spelled out principles for reducing children's vulnerability to infection and for protecting children from discrimination because of their real or perceived HIV‐AIDS status. This human rights framework can be used by governments to ensure that the best interests of children with regard to AIDS are promoted and addressed.

As Senator Herron said today in question time, there is still no cure or effective vaccine for HIV. It is worth noting the following statistics: in 1996 alone, 400,000 children under the age of 15 became infected with HIV, bringing the total number of children in this age group living with HIV to 830,000 at the end of 1996. Since the beginning of the epidemic, according to UNAIDS and World Health Organisation estimates, well over two million HIV-infected children have been born to infected mothers and hundreds of thousands of children have acquired HIV from blood transfusions or through sex.

As HIV infection often progresses quickly to AIDS in children, most of the close to three million children under 15 who have been infected since the start of the epidemic have developed AIDS, and most of them are dead. Of the 1.5 million people who died of AIDS in 1996, 350,000 were children under the age of 15. The US Bureau of Census estimates that by the year 2010, if the spread of HIV is not contained, AIDS may increase infant mortality by as much as 75 per cent and mortality in children under five by more than 100 per cent in those regions most affected by the disease.

Poverty is a key reason why children die more quickly of AIDS in developing countries. If children are sleeping three or four to a room, for example, which is common in poor households, they are far more likely to transmit and contract TB or other respiratory diseases if any one of them has those infections. If they are poorly nourished, their immune systems will weaken. If families do not have access to clean water, they are more vulnerable to waterborne diseases, including diarrhoea.

Children with HIV commonly experience wasting and delayed development and are often killed by typical childhood diseases like diarrhoea, measles, TB and other respiratory infections. Because these diseases are often the same as those that kill other children, it is sometimes difficult for health workers in poor countries, without access to testing equipment, to distinguish HIV-positive children from others. This can have at least two important consequences. Firstly, children with HIV might not receive the special care they need and, secondly, a general apathy about child health can arise and that has consequences for all children.

The dominant mode of transmission of HIV in newborn babies—in developing countries, in particular—is so-called vertical transmission from their mothers. While in poorer countries some babies are still being infected through contaminated blood or medical equipment, virtually all HIV positive infants have acquired the virus from their positive mothers during pregnancy or delivery or acquired it through breastfeeding.

The vexing issue is that, while breastfeeding can kill by transmitting HIV, bottle-feeding is also dangerous and increases risks to child health. In recent years, the World Health Organisation and UN health organisations have been heavily promoting and encouraging breastfeeding, and for good reasons. It affords vital protection against deadly childhood diseases. It is a natural, cost free method, whereas the cost of infant formula, and even the simple clean water and fuel needed to prepare it, are often beyond the means of poor families in developing countries.

So HIV-positive mothers of newborns face a difficult dilemma—choosing between breastfeeding and bottle-feeding. The context differs depending on the country and the woman's own socioeconomic status. The policy of UNAIDS and its co‐sponsors is to encourage HIV-positive mothers to be given as much information as possible on the relative risks so that they can decide whether to breastfeed or not. There is no universally valid recommendation on which way to go, but only women in possession of all the information are in a position to make fully informed choices.

UNAIDS has made one of its highest priorities improved access to all drugs needed for the treatment of HIV disease in the developing world. For this purpose, it is conducting a trial in five sites in South Africa, Tanzania and Uganda to evaluate the efficacy and tolerance of three simpler, shorter regimens for the prevention of mother to child transmission of HIV in populations where breastfeeding is the norm.

No‐one knows exactly how many children have been orphaned by AIDS worldwide, but UNAIDS estimates that, by mid-1996, nine million children under 15 years of age had lost their mother to AIDS, more than 90 per cent of whom were living in sub-Sahara African countries. The relationship between HIV, impoverishment and denial of human rights is apparent in the impact of the epidemic on children who have been orphaned by AIDS. Discrimination in accessing health care is a major form of social exclusion faced by orphans.

Evidence suggests that AIDS orphans may be at a greater risk of dying of preventable diseases and infections because of the mistaken belief that, when they become ill, it must be due to AIDS and therefore there is no point in seeking medical help. The poverty and isolation that results create a vicious circle, placing AIDS orphans, particularly orphaned girls, at greater risk of contracting HIV themselves.

An ever increasing incidence of sexual abuse also takes its toll upon young children in two forms: commercial sexual exploitation and sexual abuse in the home or the community. No‐one knows how many child sex workers there are in the world. Because of the nature of the trade, there are not precise figures. The belief that children are less likely to be infected has raised the demand for younger sex workers in recent years. Studies everywhere indicate that rates of HIV infection among child sex workers and street children are often very high. Surveys of Kenyan girls living on the street indicated that as many as 30 per cent were HIV positive.

In a world with AIDS, the injection of illicit drugs—always a risky behaviour—carries the additional danger of HIV infection. When people of whatever age share needles and syringes to inject, microtransfusions of blood occur and these are relatively efficient for transmitting HIV and other microbes. Drug injecting is thus a phenomenon that policy makers, educators and HIV prevention workers concerned with child protection cannot afford to neglect.

AIDS has changed the world for children. The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child provides a framework to protect and promote their rights which can minimise the impact of the epidemic on them. Yet despite its almost universal ratification, the response to infected, affected and vulnerable children remains inconsistent. Internationally programs for children have been ad hoc and fragmented and have lagged far behind those for adults. In many developing countries, poverty and other factors, such as wars and the resulting social break down of many communities, worsen this situation.

In a world with AIDS, children must become everybody's responsibility. In Australia we have to look at the importance of our regional approach. In east Asia and the Pacific there were an estimated 100,000 people living with HIV‐AIDS by the end of 1996. In south and South-East Asia, that number was 5.2 million. Between two and five million people are now infected with HIV in India. In Bombay, HIV prevalence has reached 50 per cent in sex workers, 36 per cent in other STD patients and 2.5 per cent in pregnant women attending clinics for prenatal care. In China, there has been an estimated tenfold growth in the number of HIV infected people between 1993 and 1995.

My visit to Vietnam earlier this year only confirmed my concerns about the importance of Australia's regional role, with an increase in the HIV rate from nine to 38 per cent in the sex worker population in Vietnam in fewer than five years. Today Minister Downer announced that Australia is hosting a meeting of Australian and other HIV‐AIDS experts in Bangkok to develop coordinated solutions to the escalating problem of HIV‐AIDS in the Mekong subregion of Asia. This and other initiatives are the most important ones for Australia to take. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the adjournment debate to address the issue of crime and punishment in the Northern Territory. Tomorrow the Australian Democrats will be moving a motion condemning mandatory sentencing. Now that the Democrats have removed the paragraph from that motion calling on intervention by the federal parliament to overturn the Northern Territory's laws, I hope that all honourable senators will support that motion.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators may recall, I outlined a number of my concerns in this regard to the Senate on 28 October. At that time I informed the Senate that the Country Liberal Party government's mandatory sentencing laws for property offences had totally skewed the scales of justice in the Northern Territory. Senators may recall I outlined a number of cases that had been determined already under these laws. They included a 23-year-old single mother who had been sentenced to 14 days gaol for unlawful entry and stealing a can of beer valued at $2.50 and a 20-year-old man sentenced to 14 days imprisonment for stealing fuel worth $9 from a car. Magistrate James Hannon told the court that he intended to fine the man until the police prosecutor pointed out that he no longer had any discretion to do so.

The mandatory sentencing laws continue to be an onerous burden on Northern Territory magistrates and, I might add, taxpayers. Since I last addressed this issue, a one-legged pensioner with no prior convictions has been sent to prison for 14 days after being convicted of trespass and causing $200 worth of damage to a fence. Magistrate Dick Wallace told the court last week, that 23-year-old Trinity Hudson was not the sort of person he would normally send to gaol, but the mandatory sentencing laws removed his discretion.

It has been estimated that it will cost territory taxpayers up to $2,500 a day to keep this man in prison. So instead of making a contribution to the community by way of a fine or community service, the mandatory sentencing laws will cost the community up to $35,000 for a $200 offence. I have also had the opportunity to read the recently released report from the Australian Law Reform Commission entitled Seen and heard: priority for children in the legal process. It is a damning indictment of the treatment of young offenders in the Northern Territory.

The report shows that, at the beginning of this year, there were 717 children aged from 10 to 17 in juvenile corrective institutions in Australia. The Northern Territory rate is more than double the national average. It has a detention rate of 68.8 per 100,000 of the child population compared with the national average of 35.5. That comparison is alarming enough, but the bells really start ringing when you compare it with Victoria's figure of 14.9, which is the lowest figure of any of the states.

The Northern Territory is the only state or territory jurisdiction, other than Western Australia, that has introduced such laws. But the Territory laws are even tougher than those in Western Australia. In the Territory, the regime for juveniles is two strikes on a property offence and you are in. A magistrate must impose a period of detention on a juvenile, defined as anyone who is 15 or 16 years of age, who has been found guilty of one of a list of prescribed property offences and has at least one prior conviction for a similar offence. These provisions apply regardless of how minor the second property offence may be.

For adults, it is one strike and you are in. This is whether you have committed a previous offence or not. One offence against this mandatory sentencing act in the Northern Territory and you are in prison. A first offence is met with an automatic 14 days imprisonment, an automatic 90 days gaol for a second offence and a minimum of 12 months in prison for repeat offences. In Western Australia, it is three strikes and you are in for both adults and juveniles convicted of home burglary.

The schedule of offences in the Territory runs to car theft, criminal damage, breaking and entering, and stealing. The Law Reform Commission report says that the mandatory sentencing laws in the Northern Territory and Western Australia breach a number of international human rights standards and common law principles. The report states:
They violate the principle of proportionality which requires the facts of the offence and the circumstances of the offender to be taken into account in accordance with Article 40 of CROC.
CROC stands for the Convention on the Rights of the Child. The report goes on to say:
They also breach the requirement that in the case of children detention should be a last resort and for the shortest appropriate period, as required by Article 37 of CROC.
Mandatory detention violates a number of provisions in the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights, including the prohibition on arbitrary detention in Article 9.
Both CROC and ICCPR require that sentences should be reviewable by a higher court or appellate court.
By definition a mandatory sentence cannot be reviewed.

The inquiry considers these violations of international and common law norms so serious that it recommends federal legislation to override the laws unless the parliaments of Western Australia and the Northern Territory repeal them.

I have stated before in relation to another matter that I do not believe this parliament should be used to override the laws of any state or territory, but I certainly do believe that the Northern Territory parliament should repeal these mandatory sentencing laws and the continuing injustice they are causing, particularly for young offenders—and the sooner, the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I join Senator Payne this evening in rising to talk about World AIDS Day. Its focus this year is on giving children hope in a world with AIDS. It is estimated that, by the end of this year, one million children under 15 will have AIDS. A very large number of these will be in sub-Saharan Africa. For instance, eight per cent of all children in Zimbabwe have lost their mothers to AIDS, and three in every 10 children whose mothers have AIDS will die from the disease.

SPEECH.PARA: The United Nations AIDS program estimates that nine million children have been orphaned worldwide by AIDS and that this figure will reach 40 million by the year 2010. More than one million children worldwide enter the sex trade every year. In Bombay, the average age for the 250,000 sex workers is 15. Of course, AIDS is the reason why the clients of sex workers are demanding younger women.

I have some other shocking statistics. In Botswana, 18 per cent of the adult population has HIV. In Zimbabwe and Zambia, 17 per cent of the adult population has HIV, and the infection rate is increasing at more than 25 per cent every year. Burma, Cambodia, Vietnam and Laos are expecting an explosion of incidents of HIV‐AIDS. These countries are amongst the poorest in the world. The impossibility of coping with such large numbers of people in the public hospitals means that ambulatory and home care systems must be developed with great urgency. Ninety per cent of HIV infections are concentrated in the developing world, yet in 1991 only six per cent of the $2.2 billion spent on AIDS was used in developing countries.

This morning Senator Herron made much of Australia's contribution to fighting AIDS overseas. It is certainly true that the work being done in Thailand and Vietnam—where a party of members and senators visited during July this year, courtesy of the Rockefeller Foundation—is making a very small difference to a problem of devastating magnitude.

It should come as no surprise to anyone that AIDS and extreme poverty go hand in hand. In Australia we have AIDS under control. Senator Herron reminded me this morning that there were only 500 new cases Australia wide this year. Australia has had massive education campaigns, ready access to condoms and the money with which to pay for them. Needle exchange programs and the like have kept our problem to manageable levels.

Many people diagnosed with HIV in Australia go on to live for many years with good health care, good diets and drug treatment. Of course, this is not the case in the poorest countries of Africa and now Asia. Thailand has 60,000 new infections each year, and more than two per cent of its population is HIV positive.

The point I want to stress tonight is that AIDS prevention and family planning go hand in hand, particularly in populous countries. Vietnam's current population is around 70 million. By the year 2010, the population is expected to stabilise at more than 120 million. Vietnam will only limit its population to that 120 million if the so-called replacement rate is just over two children per family. This is a major shift for a country in which large families were the norm until very recent times.

To feed another 50 million, it is likely that Vietnam will have to import enormous quantities of food some time in the future. Forty per cent of children are malnourished in Vietnam, as are a high proportion of adults. The country is making headway in improving the nutrition of their children, but malnutrition is linked to poverty, and seventy per cent of the population is rural and extremely poor. The poorer families are, the higher the likelihood that children will be forced into prostitution. The lower the status of women in these countries, the less likely they will be able to plan their families and care for their children. So the cycle of poverty continues.

Poverty drives men from rural areas and into the cities in search of work for long periods of time. In most Asian countries, there is an unstated acceptance of prostitution, at least by the male population. AIDS is often brought back to the village and the family by these men. The first case of AIDS in Vietnam was in the army in 1995. AIDS in Asian countries is spreading into the general population at an alarming rate.

In Thailand there is a saying: family planning is death planning—and this does not just relate to HIV‐AIDS. Vietnamese and Thai people understand the relationship between large families and the inability of those families to properly care for their children. Since 1992, Australia has provided around $2 million to Vietnam's HIV‐AIDS program. International aid to Vietnam for this purpose totals $US32 million. Most of the AusAID money goes to non-government organisations for research, development of literature pitched at young people, and making the connection between family planning and HIV prevention. It also pays for curriculum development in secondary schools, communication skills and education for women.

Australia's aid projects in both Vietnam and Thailand take on a holistic approach to assistance. We have said there is little point in providing microcredit schemes without assisting to elevate the status of women. There is no point in providing only one form of contraception when it suits only some women. There is no point in chastising women for relying on abortion, when they do not have access to better methods of contraception and when men take no responsibility for family planning.

BREAK.PARA: It is not too long ago that 60 per cent of all pregnancies ended up in abortion in Vietnam. The toll this takes on women's bodies in a country where health services are seriously under‐resourced is enormous. There is no point in promoting vasectomies or IUDs, when people are contracting AIDS because they lack the education, the power or the money to protect themselves.

In Vietnam people who are HIV positive in particular face discrimination in their families and in the community, and support in the form of social services is very limited indeed. By February this year, Vietnam had recorded 5,113 cases of HIV infection, and the highest rates were among injecting drug users. More than 80 per cent of these were males, but the rates among women continue to rise and several cases of mother-to-child transmission have already been identified.

The very low screening rates, however, obscure the real figures, and 68 per cent of the Vietnamese government's budget for AIDS is now being spent on testing. More than 60,000 people are estimated to be HIV positive in Vietnam and, in just two years, this figure is expected to rise to around 350,000. That is a tragic waste of human life and human suffering on an enormous scale.
Current Australian AIDS specific projects include:

an integrated English language program at the Red Cross to facilitate access to the global body of knowledge on AIDS prevention, counselling and care; assertiveness training skills for women from a variety of walks of life for protection from AIDS; 10 pilot projects to enhance STD and AIDS prevention and to enhance family planning knowledge, particularly for youths, women in child‐bearing age, sex workers and drugs users; a pilot project for sexuality education and HIV‐AIDS prevention, particularly for youth leaders; and an AIDS education and awareness project to reduce high risk behaviour.

Most of these projects operate in a very small number of provinces alongside agricultural, sanitation, microcredit, primary health care and family planning projects. Our delegation travelled out to one of these provinces to visit communes, to talk directly with women and to discuss family planning, women's reproductive health services and awareness of AIDS. Open dialogue about such matters with foreigners—let alone strangers—would have been very difficult for those with whom we met not so long ago. The people of Vietnam and Thailand realise that openness within their communities and more broadly is essential, and sensibilities have been put aside in the interests of saving human lives.

The AIDS pandemic is shifting to the South East Asian and Pacific region and to our nearest neighbours. The effects on our region do not stop at health impacts. AIDS has huge economic implications as well. Australia's contribution to overseas HIV‐AIDS programs is just $17 million this year. I suggest that if we seriously cared about our neighbours and the long‐term prospects of children in the poorest countries in our region, we would give much more and we would do much more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems appropriate as we near the end of the parliamentary year to raise a subject which has dominated the headlines throughout the year—a topic of much consternation both domestically and internationally; an issue that has been bandied around in private discussions and public forums, usually accompanied by rhetoric, raw emotion and inflammatory language; a concept which largely remains too difficult to challenge and too sensitive to touch; and a single word which all too readily evokes division, disagreement and alienation—I talk, no less, of racism.

SPEECH.PARA: In the words of Jacques Santer, racism is `more than the denial of differences, it is the denial of a fellow human being because of those differences'. Historically, Australia has struggled to come to terms with allegations of systemic racism. The First Fleet brought to these shores 160,000 convicts and their guardians. Grants of lands were made to new settlers on the assumption that the land did not belong to anyone—an assumption which 200 years after it was constitutionalised as the basis of Australia's land tenure system was rightly rejected as a legal fiction by the High Court in 1992 in the now famous Mabo (No. 2) decision.

Against the background of a mosaic of laws, legal precedents and existing land grants, the by-product of what is essentially a debate about land tenure management has turned into an ugly and derogatory name throwing exercise that we are witnessing in the current Wik debate. This is not an isolated incidence. Every time the size and make-up of the immigration program is questioned, the legacy of the White Australia Policy is regurgitated—a policy enacted in 1901 and incrementally disassembled from 1949 when 800 non-European refugees were granted residency.

Australia met overwhelmingly the postwar challenge of `populate or perish'. Since 1945, almost 5.6 million people have come to Australia as new settlers. Today, the migrant program is global, using one set of criteria for applicants anywhere in the world, with migrants originating from more than 170 countries.

In the last financial year over 85,700 new settlers arrived in Australia. Of these, nearly 12,000 came under the humanitarian program. An additional 90,500 people received visas allowing them to take up temporary residence. As well, 3.1 million visitor visas and over 68,600 student visas were granted. Today, nearly one in four of Australia's 18.3 million people were born overseas. Is this a policy of a racially intolerant nation?

Yet every boatload of illegal entrants arriving upon our northern coastline gives way to a baseless fear that the floodgates have opened and tide of human flotsam will be never ending. The reality is that, since the collection of data of on-shore refugee applicants commenced in 1989, 72 boats have landed upon our shores carrying a total of 2,916 illegal entrants. Despite the perpetuation of the fear of the `yellow peril' flooding Australia, the number of boat people arrivals equates to around one per day, with the success rate of individuals being granted refugee status at around 20 per cent—hardly an alarming figure.

BREAK.PARA: Then, on 10 September 1996, the independent member for Oxley, Pauline Hanson, burst on to the political stage claiming, amongst other things, that Aboriginal people receive privileges that other people do not receive because they are Aboriginal; that it is false to assume that Aboriginals are the most disadvantaged people in Australia; and that Australia is in danger of being swamped by Asians. Whilst we have long been curious about her tactics, her relentless attacks on immigration, foreign aid and indigenous people, the recent publication of her videoed last will and testament did irreparable damage to her credibility. If the opinion polls are accurate, there is every indication that voters have deserted One Nation. News polls suggest that since the party's launch in April support for One Nation has more than halved.

But while support for One Nation is languishing domestically, her politics remain central to international perceptions of Australia. That tourists, exporters and other representatives overseas are judged according to her discriminatory brand of politics is grossly unfair; that all Australians are tarnished as racists personally offensive.

So what does this tell us about ourselves? Visiting anti-discrimination crusader Jane Elliott says she knows what a racist looks like because she is one. Elliott says that if you were born, raised and educated in the United States, then you are more than likely a racist. The former grade school teacher is currently on the international lecture circuit raising awareness about discrimination.

The now internationally famous Blue Eyes program originated in a classroom of third grade primary school students in Riceville, Iowa the day after the assassination of Martin Luther King. In trying to explain to her all‐white, all‐Christian students the extent to which discrimination was responsible for the death of King, Elliott developed a behavioural exercise separating the students on the basis of their eye colour. Elliott chose to separate the children by a physical characteristic over which they had no control and to which were attributed negative elements.

Elliott told the brown eyed students that they were smarter, nicer, cleaner and deserved more privileges than students with blue eyes. Those with brown eyes were decreed as being superior, more intelligent, and quicker learners than the blue eyed. They also had complete power. To emphasise their inferiority, the blue eyed children had to wear a coloured sash around their neck. Elliott chose eye colour because during World War II the Nazi regime used it as the distinguishing physical characteristic to determine whether or not one went to the gas chamber.

The outcomes of the Blue Eyes exercise were dramatic and long lasting. On the positive side, even her students with dyslexia achieved and surpassed academic milestones. On the negative side, Elliott's own four children were taunted and harassed by their teachers, classmates and community members and her father's business was boycotted because his daughter was labelled a `nigger lover'.

The Blue Eyes program is powerful because it lets people experience discrimination first hand. The program acknowledges that most people do not notice racism because it does not happen to them. On the effects of racism, Elliott says:

But as well as crushing other people's talents, it ruins your own humanness. You are limiting yourself, your experiences, your education. It really cripples everyone. Racism is a handicap. It keeps you from being what you could be.

After delivering the seminar around the globe, Elliott has seen white executives temporarily deprived of power over others turn into people who can barely speak, read and cannot make decisions, and there is no doubt that the audience was left speechless after SBS televised the program last night.

Regardless of whether or not the Blue Eyes program can be directly applied to the Australian experience or whether it needs changes at the margin to accommodate cultural differences, there is no doubt that Jane Elliott has a lot to teach. Her visit to Australia is timely. Whilst she did not join in the current debate in this country on native title, nor comment in depth at the recent, but now waning, wave of Hansonism, she did leave us with the following thought, which I want to share with the Senate:
Ghandi said "civilisation is the encouragement of differences." We really need to wonder whether our country—yours and mine—are becoming more civilised or less.
Jane Elliott said that her anti-discrimination crusade was inspired by a Sioux Indian prayer:
Oh great spirit, keep me from ever judging a man until I have walked a mile in his moccasins.
I suggest at this critical time in the Senate it is a mile we should all walk.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 14 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why was a grant of $92 000 made to Lenah Game Meats under the Rail Reform Transition Program.
(2) What relationship do the activities of Lenah Game Meats have to the functions of Rail Reform Transition Program.
(3) Was this grant given to facilitate exports of possum and wallaby meat by Lenah Game Meats.
(4) Is it a fact that there is no approved Wallaby Management Plan for mainland of Tasmania or for Flinders Island.
(5) On what basis was it decided that exports of wallaby and possum by Lenah Game Meats are environmentally sustainable.

(6) (a) Who is the Minister responsible for this decision under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act; and (b) was an environmental impact assessment or public environmental report prepared; if not, can a statement of reasons for the decision be provided.
(7) Is the Minister aware of the health risks associated with eating possum and wallaby.
(8) What steps have been taken to ensure that the health of consumers of the products of Lenah Game Meats will be protected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1 and 2) The Rail Reform Transition Program's objective is to support measures which will create real and enduring jobs through economic development of the regions most adversely affected by the restructure and subsequent sale of Australian National. Support is available for a wide range of initiatives provided that they are capable of creating long term jobs.

The Lenah Game Meats proposal met all the Program's assessment criteria; in particular the expansion of Lenah Game Meats is projected by the proponent to create 19 full time jobs in Launceston where most of the Tasrail employees are located.
(3) Yes. The export of wallabies will be subject to Federal Government approval of a Game Management Plan which is currently being prepared.

(4) A draft Game Management Plan for Wallaby which appears to meet the Federal Government's requirements has been prepared. Public consultation on Flinders Island has shown that there is broad community support for the draft plan.
It is expected that the draft plan will be submitted, within the next few weeks, to the Federal Government for its approval.
The Lenah Game Meats proposal does not envisage exporting wallaby harvested from the mainland of Tasmania.

(5) Possums are harvested under the stringent guidelines of the Game Management Plan for Brushtail Possum, which allows the harvesting of up to 250,000 possums per year, and is supervised by the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service.

A Game Management Plan for Wallaby, once approved, would similarly be subject to Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service supervision and management, and would ensure that the number of wallabies harvested was environmentally sustainable.
(6) (a) The Minister for Transport and Regional Development.

(b) No. The export of indigenous species must be covered by a Federally approved Game Management Plan which ensures that the harvest of the species will be sustainable. Permits would also need to be issued under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982.
In these circumstances, further assessment under the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 was not considered warranted.

(7 and 8) All meat processed by Lenah Game Meats is in accordance with Australian Quarantine Inspection Service requirements. The company is also seeking accreditation to export its produce into the European Community.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 6 November 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) Is it a fact that in the 11 weeks subsequent to the enforced closure and transfer of patients from Derwent Court Nursing Home, 10 of those patients have died; and (b) how many had died in the 10 weeks preceding the closure.

(2) Have the causes of death of patients transferred from Derwent Court been assessed; if so, have the following been identified as contributory factors in any case: (a) the trauma of being suddenly relocated from the environment and carers they were familiar with; and (b) lack of sensitivity and support afforded to patients during their sudden relocation.
(3) Did the Commonwealth pay a one‐off grant of $90 000 to Rosary Gardens Nursing Home subsequent to the transfer; if so, (a) what was the reason for the grant and (b) when was it made.
(4) Did the Rosary Gardens Nursing Home also receive a $250 000 repayable loan from the Commonwealth subsequent to the transfer; if so (a) what was the reason for the grant; and (b) when was it made.

(5) (a) Were any facilities, other than Rosary Gardens, given the opportunity to apply for extra bed licences in the event that Derwent Court might close; and (b) were any other facilities in a position to make such an application.

(6) (a) How was Rosary Gardens in a position to apply for a 40 per cent increase in its number of bed licences; (b) had Rosary Gardens previously applied for such an increase and been refused; (c) what kinds of process allowed the additional 51 licences to be granted within 48 hours of application; and (d) was the allocation contingent on the notice of intention to revoke the licences at Derwent Court being implemented or was it independent of that decision.

(7) Is the Minister satisfied that: (a) the sudden closure of Derwent Court was in the patients' interests; (b) the rapidity with which the transfer took place did not have a detrimental effect on patients' health; and (c) the decision to transfer all beds, without tender, to one institution was made fairly in accordance with due process.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) 9 former Derwent Court residents have died in the period since 6 August 1997.
(b) 4 residents died in the 10 weeks preceding the closure.

(2) The cause of death is not a matter on which the Department collects information. It is assessed and noted by the attending medical practitioner. I am unaware of the reasons for death given on the death certificates for each of the former Derwent Court residents who has died since moving.
(3) The Commonwealth offered assistance to Southern Cross Homes Inc through an acquittable advance of $90,000 from Aged Care Program Support.

(a) the advance was made to defray costs associated with physically moving the residents, supporting the Advocacy Service, and carrying out minor alterations to meet safety requirements at the Carruthers wing;
(b) the advance was made on 23 July 1997.
(4) The Commonwealth provided an advance of $250,000 in the form of recurrent benefit repayable over 3 years.

(a) the advance was made to enable Southern Cross Homes Inc to obtain additional furnishings such as new beds and services such as a dementia consultant and training for staff in response to the sudden influx of residents from Derwent Court Nursing Home;
(b) the advance was made on 31 July 1997.

(5) (a) The allocation of approved places to ensure continuity of care for residents from Derwent Court was not done through a select tender or other public process. Discussions were held with Aged Care Tasmania, the State branch of the Association of Nursing Homes and Extended Care Australia, the State Department of Community and Health Services and Advocacy Tasmania to identify facilities with the capacity to take all of the residents of Derwent Court Nursing Home on the basis that there was a risk that the approval of Derwent Court Nursing Home would be revoked. As a result of these discussions, staff of the Department inspected a number of facilities and spoke with a number of individual service providers.

(b) All of these service providers had evidence of providing a better quality of care for residents than that being provided at Derwent Court but none, apart from Rosary Gardens Nursing Home, had the potential capacity to take all of the residents from Derwent Court Nursing Home at very short notice.
(6) (a) Southern Cross Homes Inc had surplus space within the Rosary Gardens facility and the opportunity to lease part of the Carruthers wing from the State Government.
(b) No, Southern Cross Homes had never applied for additional nursing home approved places at Rosary Gardens.

(c) The approval process was set out in the National Health Act 1953. Although the approval process was conducted within 48 hours it was made following a series of discussions between February and July 1997. These discussions were conducted on the basis that there was a risk that the approval of Derwent Court Nursing Home would be revoked. Neither Mr Dellar, State Manager, Department of Health and Family Services, Tasmania, or Southern Cross Homes could do anything further until such time as a decision (if any) had been made. Once the decision was made, there was a need to act swiftly to ensure that those residents whose families had indicated a desire to move could be accommodated without delay.

(d) The notice of intention to revoke the approval of the nursing home was made by the Minister's delegate Ms Halton and served on the proprietor on 21 July 1997. The Minister's delegate, Mr Dellar, decided to allocate 20 places to Southern Cross Homes on 24 July 1997. The allocation was therefore made subsequent to the decision to give notice of intention to revoke the approval of the nursing home. The process of deciding on a response to the very poor quality of care at Derwent Court was conducted independently of Mr Dellar's consideration of allocating places given the risk that Derwent Court's approval might be revoked.

(7) (a) I am satisfied that the Minister's delegates' decision to revoke the approval of Derwent Court Nursing Home was in the patients' interests. The evidence from the Standards Review Panel of Tasmania, chaired by Dr Penelope Flett, was clear—the quality of care at the home was unacceptable and there was nothing to suggest that the proprietor understood what was required to address the problems. I note that the delegate's decision has since been affirmed following a review of the decision. Southern Cross Homes Inc. have a demonstrated record in providing a better quality of care for residents than that which was being provided at Derwent Court.

(b) Any change of circumstance for frail aged nursing home residents is stressful. The Acting Director of Nursing at Derwent Court Nursing Home as well as staff from Rosary Gardens worked together to minimise that stress. I am satisfied that the rapidity of the transfer did not have any more of a detrimental affect than any transfer at a later date would have had.

(c) I am satisfied that the delegate's decision to transfer all of the beds outside of the annual approval round normally conducted by the Department was made fairly and struck a reasonable balance between the need to investigate available options and ensure that continuity of care for residents could be maintained in possibly urgent circumstances.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Primary Industries and Energy: Staff

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 18 November 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Department recently let a contract for the provision of temporary staff; if so: (a) when were tenders called; and (b) which companies were short‐listed.
(2) When was the contract let and what was the value of the contract.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, the Department has let a contract for the provision of temporary Executive Assistants.
At the time of going to tender the Department has 90‐100 Executive Assistants of which approximately 20% were temporary contracted employees.

The Department went to tender for the supply of temporary Executive Assistants on 5 July 1997. Sixteen companies responded to the request for tender with documentation. A panel shortlisted seven companies for interview on 15 August 1997. They were: Manpower; Drake Overload; Metier; Quest Staff Solutions; Kowalski Consulting; Alectus Personnel; and Western Staff Personnel.
(2) The Department entered into a contract with Kowalski Consulting starting 1 September 1997 for

a one year trial period. The terms of the contact are for the supply of temporary Executive Assistants on an as needs basis. The value of the contract will depend on the demand and subsequent usage rate of the service. The hourly rate is consistent with that across the industry.
